Green Hell captivates players with an incredible story and breathtaking aesthetics. The game offers a challenging experience in a positive way. To survive, you must comprehend the rules and resources of the rain-forest. Just like in real life, situations can take a downturn swiftly, so preparation for anything is crucial. However, once you grasp the basics, the game becomes a relaxing and immersive adventure.

One noteworthy aspect is that many players might not be aware that the game has a complete second storyline - 'Spirits of Amazonia.' This expansion not only extends the gameplay but also presents a longer and more challenging narrative. If you find yourself engrossed in the main story, don't forget to explore this additional content.

Overall, Green Hell is a solid 10/10 survival game. It's evident that the developers poured their souls into the game, creating an experience that truly resonates with players. I highly recommend it.

I once narrowly dodged away from a rattlesnake, only to then immediately get bitten by a spider. I bandaged my wound with tobacco dressing to counteract the venom, but the fever and low stamina made me an easy target for a jaguar as I tried to make it back to my camp.

This is the one survival game that actually makes survival the primary focus. Nature itself is always trying to kill you, and you must manage your time, food, water and energy carefully to avoid getting caught.

I recommend playing on King of the Jungle difficulty to get the full experience. The story is alright, but I think where this game really shines is Survival Mode and Spirits of Amazonia, where the story doesn't get in your way as much, and you're left to explore and survive at your own leisure.

Green Hell is an absolute gem of a game, offering a captivating and immersive experience unlike any other. From the stunning visuals to the intense survival mechanics, every aspect of this game is finely crafted to keep you on the edge of your seat.

The lush jungle environment is breathtakingly beautiful, yet it also presents constant challenges that keep you engaged and eager to explore further. The attention to detail in the world-building is remarkable, making every step feel like a true adventure.

The survival mechanics are incredibly realistic, forcing you to scavenge for resources, manage your health and sanity, and navigate the dangers of the wilderness. It's a thrilling test of skill and strategy that keeps you thinking on your feet at all times.

But what truly sets Green Hell apart is its immersive storytelling. The narrative unfolds in a series of mysterious flashbacks, gradually revealing the secrets of the protagonist's past and the true nature of the jungle. It's a gripping tale that keeps you hooked from start to finish.

Overall, Green Hell is a masterpiece of a game that delivers both excitement and depth in equal measure. Whether you're a fan of survival games or just looking for a thrilling adventure, this game is an absolute must-play. Better I request number of max player can be increased.

This is one of those times Steam needs an in between rating. Weak story and my not fun, go-in-blind initial playthrough give this 2/5. However, survival mode is much better, but you still need to look things up because trial and error gets old quickly. It makes sense a scientist wouldn't know survival skills, but I would've preferred a few more base knowledge things like how to boil water, how to make a bidon, and how to make a spear. I would love to pair The Forrest protagonist with this world. 

My initial play-throughs of the story: Not too thrilled by this game. Even a walk in the park is not a walk in the park if you can't find anything to help you. I've been searching for at least two hours for any nuts/fatty items, I can't find antivenom things, I can't figure out how to boil water - putting it on the fire puts out the fire - how to use the plants like tobacco, and so on and so forth. I would think a person who voluntarily goes into the jungle would know more than this PC does. That, and the save system. I thought sleeping in a bed saved, but no, only sleeping in certain beds. So when I died after four hours of gameplay, I started from the very beginning and I quit. I hate to have to read up on how to do everything. No hand holding really means your character is dumb, and it requires you to stay put in one spot for a long time to try everything out. Even then, things don't make much sense. I don't need that many nuts in a day. I should be able to easily boil water on a fire. I should know more about the plants and how to use them, or at least how to cook them or craft with them since trial and error seems to do nothing. Do not recommend unless you are prepared to pre-read everything before attempting to play. 

I finally gave up and played on Tourist mode to do the main story. It was okay. There are logic issues that are caused by the tutorial, which is never a good thing. Does the story make me want to recommend this game? Not really. However, if you read up on everything first so you go in prepared, then you can give it a shot, especially the survival mode with no story involved. It needs a better save system, tweaks to the nutrients system (you really, really don't need that many nuts in a few days), and more logic behind the water. 

Wait for it to be on sale, and read on how to play beforehand.

If you disable "Tiredness" and set "Nutrients Depletion" to low, then this game is kind of playable. Otherwise, you are a fat guy that weights 200 KG (440 Lbs) that either cant run for 50m, can't stay more than 1 hour without eating or drinking and cant stay more then 6 hour awake, the survival mechanics in this regard are very unrealistic. 

You stay 80% the time eating, searching for things to eat, passing out and dying because you either got bitten by a rattle snake (that basically only makes noise if you step over it), drank water from the river and got parasites (all the time, which is very unrealistic, if the water comes from a pond, them it makes sense, but from a flowing river/waterfall, it doesn't) or a worm is draining all your energy and sanity. Also if you die, the important things will disappear, which is ridiculous.


WARNING: there is a game breaker bug in CO-OP near the end that resulted in my brother and I giving up on this game (we were already frustrated due to the mechanics mentioned above). ONLY ONE PLAYER, THE HOST, must use the "test sample machine", otherwise it bugs. This bug have been reported multiple times since 2021 and the devs simply don't care.

Updated 2/17
After staying away from Green Hell for a few years, I'm glad to say it has seen dramatic improvements. The issues I experienced before have not come back, the frame rate is always consistent, and even loading times seem to be a little quicker. I've been enjoying my time back in Hell.


Glitchy as hell.  So much for a 1.0 release.  I love the idea of a realistic survival game that has a focus on gathering food, supplies, and maintaining physical as well as mental health.  What I absolutely hate is the fact that enemy spawns are absolutely broken as hell.  My friends and I got ambushed by somewhere around 30-40 tribal warriors and I can't imagine that is supposed to happen.  We killed off dozens but dozens more replaced them instantly.  We watched the enemy warriors duplicate themselves out of thin air.  There were so many enemies spawning and running around at once that I'd go from a solid 60fps to less than 10 whenever I was in the same game cell as them.  Very disappointing.

At the time of this review, Green Hell is one of the most brutal survival games I have ever played. It truly is an experience that will test you. The jungle is an unforgiving place, where a scratch can literally kill you. The crafting system is very realistic and tedious, as unlike other games in the genre, you will have to gather each individual item. Also, unlike other survival games where food and water are less important and don't really hinder one's experience, your well being and sanity will depend heavily on these elements. Overall, this game is a true challenge for fans of the survival genre. As the mechanics associated with these games are dialed up to the max and put your knowledge to the ultimate test.

Its a simple game, not incredibly big, not incredibly long, but it has enough care and detail to make each and every hour satisfying, from the very well done story to the survival mechanics that you can lose dozens of hours in.

Hard to find a satisfying game these days, and this one seems to be a passion project that keeps receiving updates, like an entirely separate story that I haven't touched yet, some sandbox features too, its plenty and all quality.

If you like a good story, survival games, or feel the pull of the jungle setting, its definitely worth more than the asking price, and is an easy recommend.

This game ticks so many boxes for me in the survival crafter genre. It's challenging enough to keep it interesting even late game, and one wrong move or preparation can end your game/kill you. The base building is satisfying as well as the crafting. It's relaxing, frustrating, and anxiety inducing. It's gotten constant updates, has multiplayer, and new game modes/additions that keep the game fresh for someone like me who comes back to play after a hiatus. The harvest interaction is something I haven't seen in another survival crafter yet and adds another layer into the whole gathering resources mechanic. It's a lovely game, and I look forward to the next project for CreepyJar.

Game corruption makes runs unplayable, stealing whatever time you've invested in base building, skill increases, item collection.  Interactions, such as using elevators or water bottles, can become inaccessible.  The game can glitch and prevent you from drawing the bow.  Game corruption can drop you from 150 FPS to 12 FPS.

I loved the story, and I really like survival games, but the loss of progress due to game corruption is a deal breaker.  Play this game if you want to do short runs, if you want to be a nomad and don't expect anything outside your inventory to persist.

There is also an abundance of resources and no way to tune it.  Don't expect to struggle much in finding food, water, shelter, particularly once you figure out how to make a bow and that you can eat pretty much everything you find once you cook it in a coconut shell.  The resource spawning is a check that is made as you view the spawn points, so you might be looking at an empty banana tree, turn around and turn back, and now there are bananas to harvest.  The difficulty of the game is just jump-scare style fights with tribal raiders (which often don't spawn due to other bugs) and jump-scare style fights with big cats (which aren't a threat if you have a bow and see them coming).

I really wanted to like this game, but there are too many progress-stealing bugs.

UPDATE: Hotfix 2.7.1 seems to have fixed this particular issue

Green hell is a relativily realistic and hardcore jungle survival game. You need to eat certain types of food, take care of your mental health and avoid toxic plants, dangerous animals and humans. The game at first tells you minimal information but after some time in the jungle you start to learn and feel at home. What at first feels "scary" and frustrating turns into a rewarding natural progression. 

You can even craft certain tiers of equipments and buildings and even cultivate plants or tame animals. The campagin story is surprisingly well done and interesting, this was the biggest surprise for me. There also came a free update with a dlc story which is the prequel to the original campaign. It is suppposed to be even better, but I did not play it yet.

There is also a survival (endless mode) coop and a new challenge mode. By now you can even play both types of campaging in coop as well. The last update also released a horde mode, which I did not test yet.

If you like survival games you should most definitely buy this game.

The core survival gameloop is fun. It can be annyoing at times, dealing over and over again with same simple things like eg. leeches, but mostly its fun. You will die a lot in the beginning, which is fine, but why would you lose random inventory items then - extremely frustrating. As you get better you will die less often of course.
The environment is interesting in the first few hours, until you realize that there is just not that much going on. Same goes for the building system. It is far from unique and quite shallow with not that many options.
Sound was ok, the comments and sounds the player makes over and over again get annoying quickly, eg. when drinking unsafe water.
The story felt surprisingly unrewarding and not satisfying to finish at all, and I was really disappointed with the endings. Biggest let down of the game besides the shallowness of environment & building.
All in all an ok game with quite some annoyances and frustration. Would give neutral rating if possible.

Would love to see a more polished and extended version/second part though.

While the game is proportionately better with Friends in Co-op, I still feel like the game over complicates everything to the point of frustration. You cant 'play' the game because you are always micromanaging your needs, illnesses, wounds and lets not get started on the clunky inventory. The negative effects and ailments that you are picking randomly occurs way-way to much. Armor is practically useless against leeches and bees. The animation lockout (e.g. when crafting or being hit by bees or ants) on your characters without a way to cancel it will result in your death or at least a few bandages. The game also generates alot of GPU heat.

It's basically the forest, but annoying. Hard, unfair, complicated, with a lot of tedious step's for everything you do and an awful ui.

I surely recommend the game, it can be played both in multiplayer and single player mode, with two story lines to choose from or just play survival.  

It keeps surprising enough also, the other day while wandering the map, well equipped and armored, usually pretty much everything can be tackled that the game hits at you. Well, within the next five minutes, I had wrecked my close to 100% bone armor, used up all my 12 arrows, was snakebit, shot two jaguars and had missile and close combat with two groups totaling five hostile natives. Result, no energy left, fever, snakebite wound, one bleeding wound and an another wound, two btoken pieces of bone armor and two at about 20%. Yes, limping back to base...

The game does have some bugs, personally, I didn't encounter any in the single player story lines, however, multiplayer seems to have a few. The main story line is quite enjoyable. I appreciated the theme throughout the game that we need to preserve our jungles, most of our new drugs are found in the numerous species that inhabit a typical tropical rain forest. Some species we even have yet to discover.

Green Hell is a really great game that takes a little time getting into. It's a little learning by doing type of deal, but I actually really like that aspect of survival. 
If you are an expert at survival games this one might be a worthy challenge.

It's not perfect but there is so much detail in the world. Pros: detailed survival mechanics, large open world, tons of crafting and building options. Cons: almost nothing is explained in game, tutorial is barely helpful, weird visual bugs like parrots sitting feet above the rocks they are perched on. If you look up the basics about what you can craft and build online then its a ton of fun. Oddly enough I find the animal attacks in this game way less scary than the wolves in The Long Dark.

First of all, why is it so hard to find a rock??

Second, why are the tribesmen's hairstyle shaped like their main village's layout in the story. THAT'S WHACK

Anyway, I love survival games and green hell is definitely in my top 5. The story was good and there's multiple endings. I predicted both endings correctly but it doesn't make it any less emotionally traumatic. 

I love how immersive it is, the environment is also your enemy. I like how the health bar is split into four sections where you have to maintain your protein, carbs, fats and water intake. Building and crafting system is pretty good.

The part i don't like the most is when you can cure venom bites with painkillers. I know there's a tobacco dressing for the venom wound but why can't we extract venom from snakes If we can extract poison from the poison dart frog?

Monkeys would be cool to add, although i hate the idea of monkeys kicking my ass and stealing stuff from my base.. that would be really cool.

For survival mode, I feel like there should be more maps or at least be like a randomly auto generated map/seed like minecraft because I have already memorized most of the map even though it's large.

This game has so much potential to be good. There are a few irritating things that keep me from taking this game seriously.

1. This game has way to many issues with crashing. My game crashes constantly. I can't play for more than a few hours on coop without the game crashing. I can't load into the game and talk on discord at the same time or the game crashes. 

2. Bandages don't work properly. If you get bitten by a snake you are supposed to apply a tobacco dressing as per the wiki. You get about 15 seconds to do that unless you are peak mental and physical condition and it literally never works. Scorpions, spiders, frogs, none of the bandages work. 

3. Time invested in maintaining the character is way too long. You could spend a solid hour or more getting your team up to a point where you can travel from your camp and a tiger attacks or a tribe attacks or within 10 minutes be all dead or limping back home to spend the next 90 minutes getting ready to go again. It really takes the fun out of the game when you only make it out of camp 50% of the time. 

4. Crafting is a chore and serves minimal benefit. There is so much effort involved in creating anything coupled with maintaining your character that it's borderline not even worth it. Throw some coconut shells on the ground to collect water. You might be saved from a tiger if you craft a decent shelter but a tribe will tear it all down pretty quickly.

5. Navigation is meh. I get it, I get what it's about. It's still cumbersome when you have everything stacked against you. I have been bitten by spiders and attacked by tigers looking at my map - and good luck getting home before you die if that happens. 

To be honest, if not for the crashing, I would give this game a positive review. It's just so disheartening to have your game crash after finally progressing. You can't be saving every 5 minutes and if you finally get moving and get out to explore for 30 minutes and the game crashes it's basically like "what's the point".

Green Hell is great! It's had 19 content updates since I purchased it and I think that's pretty dope.

You'll find a lot of reviews mentioning how this game is like The Forest. It's a fair comparison on the surface, and it's fair to say you'll enjoy Green Hell if you enjoyed The Forest. Green Hell co-op is like The Forest co-op, but with a lot more glitches (and The Forest has its fair share) and a LOT more threats. I died. Spectacularly. And often.

Within the first five minutes, a rattlesnake bit me and I died. Upon respawning, I decided to take a nap to replenish some energy only to wake up covered in worms. I attempted to kill something for food and bones (because my notebook insisted bone shards would help me with worms), but I failed. So, I drank some water instead because my guy kept complaining about being thirsty. I ended up with 4 stacks of parasites. Trying to figure out how to cure them and panicking about the flashing symbols on my HUD alerting me of my imminent death, I picked up a poison dart frog without bothering to read that it was a poison dart frog. It sapped what little health I had left and I died again. After I respawned yet again, I was dead within about 30 seconds when I ate something that gave me food poisoning. As my character continued vomiting every few steps, my macros plummeted. It didn't take long for me to fall over and die a third time. This cycle of dying and respawning happened for my first several hours of gameplay, and keep in mind that my squad was also repeatedly dying around me so our collective sanity was abysmal. I turned down the game's volume for fear of actually losing my sanity to the constant voices in my head as I watched this poor guy curl up into the fetal position in the mud, pass out from exhaustion, and subsequently die because I didn't know how to keep him alive for longer than a few minutes.

The learning curve was steep. 90 degrees, I'd say. I went in blind, and it ultimately made the survival element a [b]lot[/b] more satisfying once I figured out how to, y'know, [i]not[/i] die every few minutes.

The game has beautiful and immersive sound and visuals. Lots of audio cues that can help save your life.

We've experienced a lot of glitches in co-op mode: invisible natives that only appear when they die, weapons vanishing from hands, storage boxes randomly sorting and mixing items up, the inability to pick things up or interact with anything that's fixed only by a reset, items flying across the screen, getting stuck in the water, dead fish endlessly splashing in and out of the water making this loud buzzing sound, and just overall lag. None of it has kept me from enjoying the game, but it might bother someone looking for a more seamless experience.

My other gripe has to do with the guy you're playing. While I haven't played story mode yet and don't know his deal, I get [b]very[/b] tired of his almost [i]constant[/i] whining. I get he's in a terrible situation, but his persistent moaning and groaning got very annoying very quickly.

Overall, Green Hell is a pretty intense and rewarding experience if you jump into it blind, and I highly recommend that you do.

Green Hell is not a game. It's an experience. In this leech removing simulator, you play as Jake Higgins, an absolute imbecile of a man who can't walk over logs or tell which part of his body hurts without inspecting every limb and packs his bag like a die-hard Tetris fan. He can't carry more than 50-pounds on his back without crawling on the ground and thought it was a good idea to wear t-shirt and shorts to one of the most dangerous environments in the world. At least he had the foresight to not wear sandals or crocs. Jake Higgins is simultaneously a strong man and yet one of the weakest men you'll ever meet. You'll be able to tear apart logs with your bare hands and carry 2 logs on your shoulder at once but be unable to carry 7 banana leaves. He has a 2-inch vertical jump and can run for about 200 feet on a good day.

You'll start your game out with normal nutrient depletion not realizing Jake has every single tapeworm in Brazil in his body and then go turn it down after you realize you just spent the past 5 hours of game play foraging for food to keep your vitals up. Perhaps to augment his unusual body composition, you will learn that he needs a full 8 hours of sleep every 4 hours and needs to eat his body weight in food in those 8 hours and runs the risk of dying by dehydration no less than 3 times in those 8 hours. He has an aversion to eating human meat and spiders but is down to snack on human bones and rubbing those spiders into a wound.

But enough about him, let's go onto the actual game. Green Hell is a survival game where harvesting resources is incredibly easy but tedious and slow. Harvesting resources is a matter of pressing E randomly while walking around or a few swings with an axe. Like most survival games that use wood, you can't cut down like 90% of the trees but the trees you can cut down takes like 4 swings of the axe to drop. Trees drop 2 logs and 2 long sticks but recipes will need 3 logs or long sticks. You'll get at most 10 rocks in your play through so make sure you treasure them. Food and water is a non-issue because eating random things off the ground as you travel around will not only suffice, they can and will cure any ailments you have.

You can hear literally every threat to your well being before you see them and pull out your trusty level 1 bow to instantly kill the aggressor. Once you have your trusty level 1 bow (something you can get 10 seconds into the game) and 2 arrows (just in case you miss your first shot), you are set to beat the game. Once you get armor (something you can do 10 seconds into the game), it doesn't even matter if you missed your first shot as you have become immortal.

The base building portion of Green Hell demonstrates how strong mud walls and jungle tribal men are. Tribal enemies will be able to decimate any mud wall with nothing more than a knife and 3 swings. Sometimes the structures you build are so flimsy and porous, enemies and animals will just walk through them to attack you without damaging the wall at all.

Directional audio is actually amazing once you get past hearing random leaves rustling, random wooden items banging around and Jake Higgins complaining about being hungry, sleepy or thirsty or simply angrily swearing every few seconds.

You start off with a watch that can do everything except wipe your rear end and assemble a plane to fly out. You're trying to find your wife who has been a champ to put up with your 94 tapeworms and demanding sleep requirements. In summary, the two good points of Green Hell are the directional audio and the actual story and plot. Green Hell touts itself as difficult and realistic but the only realistic part of the game is going insane when playing it.

Green Hell is slow-moving, somewhat unforgiving, and decently challenging -- but you should be prepared to meet it where it's at. It's a great survival game, up there with games like The Forest, Subnautica, or Raft -- but what it's trying to do is very different from what those games (and especially a "survival" game like Rust) are trying to do. For instance: no tech tree, little real progression, and combat is pretty monotone.

Green Hell's core mechanics revolve around eating, drinking and gathering resources to build with -- but what sets it apart from other survival games is (1) its interface and (2) its pacing.

The interface is challenging. Especially for people accustomed to having a slick inventory screen where many things happen. Instead, Creepy Jar is trying to keep you in the character's head. So your inventory is your backpack, your crafting screen is basically what's on the ground around you, and it's not always clear what will and what won't work together. Or cooking, for example. There's no cooking workstation -- instead, you build a fire and place food at the fire. The food cooks over time, but if you forget about it, it can burn or spoil.

The pacing slows down A LOT once you have a stable living/sleeping spot, understand where to get clean food and water, and can protect yourself. After that, you're exploring. And it turns out that it is REALLY easy to get lost wandering around the Amazonian rainforest.

I love Green Hell. I think it's super fun, has interesting challenges, and it's absolutely worth the low price point. But don't buy it if you're looking for a base-builder like 7 Days to Die or a combat-focused game like Rust.

I'd be more entertained doing household chores than this miserable virtual drudgery that does nothing for me. If this was the reality I was actually stuck in, I wouldn't [i]want[/i] to survive in it. If your survival game defeats your players through the 4th wall, then you've failed.

The right shoulder button brings up the watch on your character's [i]left[/i] hand, that's how hard their UI people need to be fired. Then I tried with the keyboard and mouse, but the hints become literally unreadable because the text overlaps, and everything requires too many separate key-bindings, instead of combining their functions in any sensible way. 

I'm uninstalling after 3 hours because life is too short, and they've completely failed to interest me enough to suffer through this shit interface.

Bear Grylls, born on June 7, 1974 in the Isle of Wight, England, is a British explorer, host, writer, and producer. From 1994 to 1997, Bell served in the British 21st Airborne Special Service Regiment, and later retired due to injury.
From 2006 to 2011, the adventure series "Into the Wild" hosted by Bell was broadcast. The show aired for a total of 7 seasons. Bell was also dubbed "standing at the top of the food chain" because of the amazing things he ate on the show. man" title. The program was nominated for the Outstanding Original Interactive Program at the 71st Emmy Awards in 2019 and the Outstanding Interactive Media Award at the 49th Annual Daytime Emmy Awards in 2022. Bell himself also won the Outstanding Program Host Award. In 2007, Bell made eight series for British Channel 4 called Bear Grylls.
In 2009, Discovery Channel teamed up with Bell to film the program "Survival in the Wild China Special" on Hainan Island, China. In 2015, Asia's first nature exploration program "Follow Bell's Adventures" was broadcast. In August of the following year, Bell participated in the recording of the Chinese version of the program "Cross Country". From 2021 to 2022, Bell's new programs "Bear's Wild Adventure" and "Running Wild with Bear Grylls: the Challenge (Celebrity Wilderness Survival Challenge)" will be broadcast one after another.
Character experience
Early experiences
Bell has been climbing and sailing with his father, a member of the Royal Yacht Fleet, since he was a child. When he was a teenager, he became a second-degree black belt in karate, and later learned yoga, ninjutsu and skydiving.
Bell served in the British Special Forces for three years from 1994 to 1997, belonging to the 21st SAS Special Forces Regiment. During his service, he learned many survival skills, including hand-to-hand combat, desert and cold area combat, medical care, parachuting, signaling, climbing and explosions, etc. . In 1996, Bell injured his back due to a parachute malfunction while performing a parachute mission in Africa.
In 1998, Bell reached the Ama Dablam peak in the Himalayas, becoming one of the youngest climbers ever to reach the summit. He was also entered into the Guinness Book of Records as the youngest British climber. Two years later, he published a book "Facing" tells the story of his climb to Mount Everest. The book was nominated for the 2001 Boardman Tasker Literary Award.
career experience
period of personal adventure
In 2000, Bell and his teammates rode a jet ski around the British Isles in aid of the Royal National Lifeboat Association. In 2003, Bell led a team on a hard rubber boat to complete the first ever adventure of crossing the North Atlantic and Arctic Ocean in a rubber boat, and recorded the adventure in the book "Survival in the Wilderness (Facing the Frozen Ocean)", which won the William Hill Sports Book Award. In June 2005, Bell, together with mountaineer Hempleman-Adams and Lieutenant Colonel Alan Veal, set a world record for the highest open-air dinner at an altitude of 24,262 feet, and parachuted back to the ground after eating dinner.
In 2005, Bell filmed a TV program called "The Exile of the Legion," which was divided into four parts and briefly reproduced the basic training organized by the French Foreign Legion in the Sahara Desert with Bell and 11 other "recruits." .
"Wild Survival" Period
From 2006 to 2011, Discovery Channel began to cooperate with Bell, with Bell serving as the host. An adventure series called "Survival in the Wild" was broadcast. The program was broadcast for a total of 7 seasons. In the program, Bell went deep into inaccessible places. Region, he demonstrates various survival methods according to local conditions, conveying persistence, tenacity, dreams and beliefs to the audience. In order to better demonstrate his wild survival skills to people, Bell eats almost everything, including scorpions in the desert, bugs in Zambia, and zebras. Corpses, as well as various bugs that he jokingly called "high protein", were therefore dubbed "the man standing at the top of the food chain". During its broadcast, the program became the most popular cable television program in North America, and Discovery Channel became the largest non-sports cable television channel and one of the most watched programs in the world, with more than 1.2 billion viewers watching the program. It was nominated for the Outstanding Original Interactive Program at the 71st Emmy Awards in 2019 and the Outstanding Program Interactive Media Award at the 49th Annual Daytime Emmy Awards in 2022. Bell himself also won the Outstanding Program Host Award. In 2009, a 9-year-old boy in the United States got lost with his family. He relied on Professor Bell's survival skills on the show to find a way out and left clues for rescuers, and was finally rescued safely.
In 2007, Bell first produced eight series of programs called "Bear Grylls, Born to Survive" for the British Discovery Channel, and then published the book "Born to Survive", which won the most popular TV series for ten consecutive weeks Ranked among the top ten best sellers in the Sunday Times. Regarding the many dangers he encountered while recording TV shows and other challenges, Bell said: "I encountered a lot of dangers, but it was these moments that taught me how to save my life when I was in danger. These experiences taught me to overcome dangers. Become stronger, this is how we grow. When we face danger, we will learn relevant survival skills, and then we will become true survivors."
In 2009, Bell became Chairman of the Scout Association of Great Britain. Not only was he the youngest Chief Scout ever in the UK, he was also the first Chief Ambassador of the World Organization of Scouting. In the same year, Discovery Channel teamed up with Bell to film the program "Into the Wild China Special" in Hainan Island, China. This was also the first time that "Into the Wild" was filmed in China, showing the original Asian style and oriental culture to global audiences, as well as the sinister jungle in the middle of Hainan Island. The swampland also made this adventure full of challenges. The broadcast of the program also played a good role in deepening and expanding the Hainan tourism brand. In 2010, Bell launched the show "Everyday Survival and Self-Rescue Manual" on the Discovery Channel. Bell demonstrated how to survive in life-threatening situations. Anyone can use this knowledge and skills to escape and rescue others. In December 2011, Bell produced two special programs called "Bell's Survival Classroom" for the British Discovery Channel. In the program, Bell led two of the most famous British stars Miranda Hart and Jonathan Ross through two unforgettable weeks. Unadventured journey.
In March of the following year, Bell was fired because he and Discovery Channel could not agree on a new show. As a result, he lost the opportunity to participate in two shows that the channel had prepared for him.
"Extreme Rebirth" returns
In 2013, Bear Grylls returned to Discovery Channel with a new series "Extreme Rebirth". This series is an evolved version of the global hit program "Into the Wild". Bear will be exposed to the same dangers and scenarios. Recreating their survival experience when they were trapped in extremely terrifying dangers, the show has an IMDb rating of 7.1, and is ranked 21st on BBC Americ TV shows and 117th on survival TV. In May of the following year, "Bell's Desert Island Survival Experiment" was broadcast on Channel 4. Participants in the program were led by Bell and placed on remote uninhabited Pacific islands to test their survival skills. The program won the 2015 British Academy of Film and Television Awards for Best Reality and Constructed Factual, Royal Television Society Award for Most Popular Factual and Feature. In July of the same year, Bell collaborated with NBC to film the show "Celebrity Wilderness," which featured Bell leading some of the world's most famous celebrities

This game is an odd one for me. Granted, I have only played this game in multiplayer mode but I think my points will still stand. Firstly I want to say that I love survival games: The Forest (though that was its own steaming hot pile of garbage in its own charming way) and Subnautica are both paragons of the genre, and I really enjoyed the fact that this game takes place against the backdrop of a lush rainforest environment. While the graphics are generally nice to look at, my main gripes involve the mechanics. The story is rather average for a survival game. Firstly, no matter what difficulty we played this game on, we were barraged with constant snake bites, random attacks from the PO'd locals and a ridiculous shortness of stones (which are basic crafting materials and integral to your survival) and food that wasn't nasty little yellow snails. And this remained the typical even as we explored the majority of the map and meticulously searched every corner for consumables and crafting materials. Mind you, we played on every difficulty and got the worst material spawns every time. I'm not sure if it was just our luck or what. The game itself is nothing remarkable, as I mentioned with the storyline being fairly generic for this genre of games. Overall, I can't necessarily recommend nor tear Green Hell to shreds. My review is basically this: it's a meh survival game with decent graphics but the gameplay is sort of lacking. Certainly not something to spend $25.00 USD on...

Building in the jungle, collecting supplies, and surviving is for some reason very peaceful, until I get attacked or fall off of something then I panic slightly. All in all I love Green Hell, and find it relaxing and challenging at the same time. I absolutely recommend this game.

I wish there were console commands or better cheats online for this game cause I will not be constantly playing this game when I die cause I cannot stand getting some blueprints over and over. The reason I recommend it is because it's a fun game but I just hate the blueprint system, I find it useless, annoying, and overall game-ruining. I know where the log bed is but 99% of the game spawns I get won't spawn me anywhere near it. Then when I go looking for it I need a grappling hook, but afterwards I get the grappling hook I go up looking for it to NOT find it.

EDIT: I would love the game to have console commands and or have a setting to give all blueprints at the start.

After all of the positive reviews, I expected better honestly.  I didn't play very long at all before uninstalling, so I'm sure someone will hit me with the "oh it's good once you know all the mechanics and have 40 hours in the game!"

-Movement is frustratingly slow.  Walking is the equivalent speed of standing on top of a roomba, sprinting feels like 75% IRL walking speed.  
-Mechanics are so incredibly poorly explained that I felt like I was playing a Dark Souls knock-off.  Your players should not have to DISCOVER how to perform basic functions in your game.  I don't want to fumble through the jungle bashing rocks against things until something happens.  You can not have a 1-step objective like "build a fire" when there are 10 or more steps involved.
-Probably the worst implemented (and worst explained) crafting system I've ever encountered.  "hey look at this journal with a poorly drawn thing.  You recognize those terrible sketches?  Good, use those to build the thing."  And then you get to look at a bookbag with garbage strapped to it, pick things off the back, and turn them into other things so you can craft the thing.  Realism works just fine in real life, but it should always take a backseat in favor of streamlined UI and mechanics, especially core mechanics (crafting in a crafting-survival game).  Games like Grounded, Subnautica, even Raft don't require you to jump through hoops and layers of UI to perform basic core gameplay functions.

Maybe I'm just grumpy, was having a bad day, etc, but I don't understand the hype.  But that's ok, a game can't get good reviews from everyone.  Maybe I'll give it another shot later down the road and things will click

Green Hell is an absolute masterpiece in the world of survival games! Embarking on this virtual journey into the heart of the Amazon rainforest was nothing short of legendary, and my wife and I had an unforgettable experience.

From the moment we entered the lush and dangerous world of Green Hell, we were captivated by the sheer realism and attention to detail. The vibrant, yet perilous, ecosystem of the Amazon threw every imaginable challenge at us, from jaguars lurking in the shadows to poison frogs, crocs, spiders, and scorpions at every turn.

Surviving in Green Hell is an immersive and intense experience that truly pushes the boundaries of the survival genre. The game's mechanics, combined with its stunning visuals and atmospheric soundscape, create an authentic sense of tension and danger. Each encounter with wildlife felt like a life-or-death situation, and the thrill of overcoming these challenges was incredibly rewarding.

The co-op gameplay added a layer of teamwork and strategy, making survival even more exhilarating. My wife and I found ourselves strategizing, problem-solving, and celebrating every small victory together. The game seamlessly blended exploration, resource management, and crafting, offering a comprehensive survival experience that kept us on the edge of our seats.

In the end, Green Hell stands out as one of the best survival games I've ever played. It's not just a game; it's an adventure, a test of skill, and a thrilling journey into the heart of the Amazon. Kudos to Creepy Jar for crafting an unforgettable and truly legendary gaming experience!

Following the recent updates, I felt compelled to revise my review of this game. Green Hell is a great game if you're looking for a challenging experience and something different in terms of base building. The developers recently made some much needed changes to the storage system and added a means of transportation, both of which have greatly improved the overall experience. 

There is something to be said for a company that is still making improvements on their product and adding new content years after the initial release without charging their customers additional fees to enjoy them. 

I absolutely do recommend this game.

Green Hell:

I love survival games. Green Hell is right up there with the best of them. It is hard but way more fun with friends.

Get lost and survive the Green Hell.

I understand this game has its fans and there's nothing wrong with that. I actually played this before I played The Forest. If I had never played The Forest though, I probably would have shrugged and said this was just a meh survival game. Once I played The Forest, however, I realized just how much worse this game is in comparison.

The best way I can describe this game is like driving a car that breaks down every five minutes. You're constantly wondering when you're going to have to stop to fix something, and by the time you reach your destination you're just glad it's over.

- Game runs poorly even on high end rigs
- Crafting is a chore and finding even a simple rock is a tedious game of hide and seek
- Story is subjective but having the main character talk through everything was boring compared to finding clues and discovering the story out for yourself in The Forest
- The extra "survival mechanics" offered here are more like constant annoyances that you have to check and fix every time you do literally anything. You have to pull leeches off your body, treat fire ant bites, and treat scrapes every time you do so much as walk for two minutes
- The sheer amount of injuries your character sustains from the simplest actions is absurd. This guy is so ridiculously fragile that he could stub his toe and be hospitalized for weeks. How this guy survived every day life up to this point is nothing short of a miracle
- The nutrition macro system seems complex to encourage a more robust diet and change the gameplay to suit the needs of your character, but as others have mentioned it's easy to figure out the recipes that trivialize this mechanic
- Sanity is another mechanic that again, only serves as another annoyance that you have to babysit
- Lastly, price. I spent $15 on this game, played for 7 hours, and will never touch it again. I spent $5 for The Forest, played for 25 hours, and I'll eventually buy and play the sequel too. Take that as you will.

Overall if you enjoy Green Hell, hey, more power to you. As for me, I don't recommend this to anyone who played The Forest, and I don't recommend this game over The Forest.

I like that there's a different "hunger" system with the carbs, proteins, fats and water intake separately shown. There should definitely be another performance related update. Sometimes even without any animals / enemies in vicinity, the frames would drop to 35. My 6GB GPU , i5 cpu and 32GB of RAM shouldn't be the problem. The game is also on my SAMSUNG SSD, so this is definitely still a unresolved issue that needs to be fixed.

TL:DR 
Do not spoil this game with spoilers. Forget the internet, enjoy the jungle. Learn through suffering and dying and enjoy the treasures Amazonia offers as you find them. 
This review does not contain any spoilers.

Full review:
Originally negative review after 20 hours in coop with friends. Add more 40 hours, both coop and solo, and I am changing my review to positive. The game is quite enticing, compelling and fun. It can suck you in, you'll live in the jungle. And you can easily, and often, get sidetracked by many to-do / to-find / to-figure-out ideas you may have. I love this in games.

Dying in many different ways and figuring out a way to stay alive was a great learning curve for me, and I enjoyed finding a solution (or multiple ones) in-game to each and every issue I had. I am very happy that I did not google a single thing for this game. Well, apart from a few mods - but as of now I play mostly vanilla.

I still find Green Hell rather shallow, very similar to The Forest, which I played and completed, but did not like it too much. It tries to be hardcore realistic in some ways, but there are a lot console-game, arcade style aspects which break the immersion significantly. And in coop it has some annoying glitches like frequent sound of huge object falling/breaking nearby, every minute or so when near your structures.

Viewing distance is very short in this game, so don't bother building huge bases, as you might not see objects you built 50-100 meters from you. And you won't see anything beautiful in distance from high towers you may try to build. But as soon as you don't go crazy fortress builder mode, you're fine.

Tip: If you fancy a nice treehouse, find the huge trees. Smaller platform can definitely be useful, but trying to build bigger structers on that requires a ton of patience and the result won't be as great anyway. I love myself a nice treehouse, happy to see the option in this game.


Reasons for my previous negative review:

In first 20+ hours, during CO-OP Game crashed on my PC every 1-2 hours. Didn't find any solution to it, have new graphics drivers, I even lowered graphic settings as advised, even when on very high it ran smoothly. My brothers played it without a single CTD, so it only affets some hardware I guess.

In the end I found solution via try and error - to unplug my ever-favorite Logitech G-13 keyboard. Without this keyboard, playing was worse, as I really love using it, but I had no crashes at all in about another 20 hours. Later playing solo, I plugged it back in, still had some crashes, but only during certain actions like removing armor etc. and only once in 5-10 hourse, so it's kind of bearable. Less than 0.1% PC gamers use G13 keyboard, so don't worry about suffering the same crash bug.

Then I had issue with super-fast time flow in the game, but it's possible to get used to it and to have not many issues with nutrition and energy, as you get the hang of the game. I originally wrote: "Also it has very short day-night cycle, and extremely high consumption rates. Most of the game you just care about eating or sleeping, even though all food is abundant around you in the Amazon rainforest. Before you wander few hundred meters, you are already exhausted, starving and it's night, even though you started in the morning fully stuffedn and full of energy. Luckily, this issue can be fixed via mod named ModTime. "

This is absolutely fantastic. I've got just over 50 hours in this, over a couple months of play, and It's not dull yet. 

Cons: The audio mix can be a little odd. Naturally things are louder as they get closer to you, but at times the animal sounds seem quite a bit louder than they should be. That's all I can come up with. 

Pros: This is the best balance of realism and fun in any survival game I've played. The level of detail from nutrients to first aid, growth of the flora around you, design of structures, etc. You've got to keep your head in the game and pay attention to all the detail or you won't make it far. But it's not so granular that the whole game is just a chore-chart activity of work. 

The ongoing support from Creepy Jar, adding additional content based largely on player feedback, has really kept things fresh. 

The map is huge, considering the pace you need to take in order to survive. Lot's of things to discover and dangers to encounter. 

The "learning" system is fantastic. You have a journal that starts largely empty, and it is filled as you experiment and experience different things. Everything you encounter is "unknown" until you do something with it (eat it, make a bandage with it, make a brew, etc). You learn how to make different equipment by discovering it in the wild, or experimenting and stumbling across the "recipe" on your own. 

I highly recommend, and I haven't even played the story mode, only survival. Great single or multiplayer, though it is much more tense and stressful in single player.

[h1] Scores [/h1]

[b]General scores[/b]
Graphics: 8
Audio: 9
Gameplay: N/A (yet)
UI/UX: 7

[b]Game specific scores[/b]
Simulation: 10
Scenario: N/A (yet)

[h1] Target audience [/h1]

If you like tapping bricks in a casual game - look for another game.
If you like survival, realism and hard games - this game is a must-play.

[spoiler] And if by any chance you played "Stranded 2", and wanted a graphics upgrade - you found it! [/spoiler]

[h1] Full review [/h1]

[b] Graphics: 8 [/b]
Why: Decent textures, models, lights. Looks and feels pretty good for an indie game.
Why not 10: Doesn't have graphics of 2019 - no ray tracing support and other advanced techniques.

[b] Audio: 9 [/b]
Why: Sounds are realistic. Items, walking, jumping, environment sound pretty good. You'll feel like in jungle.
Why not 10: There are few (or almost no) soundtracks in the game.

[b] Gameplay: N/A [/b]
Why: Haven't finished it yet to know all the game mechanics and scenario. Will update after finishing.
Note: The game can sometimes be so addicting, that you may ignore the main mission and start building and living your own life in a beach.

[b] UI/UX: 7 [/b]
Why: Generally UI fits well into the theme.
Why not 10: Menus could be improved to be accessible easier. Not very intuitive to go to notebook to build buildings, traps, fire. Takes some (little) time to get used to.
Below is a personal opinion, which was not counted in the in the score.
Instead of 3 scales for fats, carbs, etc there could be 2 scales - Nutritions (call it anything), and Energy. In that case each food could give both - X nutritions and Y energy. 
That would make things a little bit easier to [i]track[/i]. Yet could be implemented in a way so that it did [i]not[/i] make the gameplay easier.

[b] Simulation: 10 [/b] 
Why: Get used to dying. There are plenty of ways to die, and they are all very realistic. 
Crafting and buildings are diverse. You could learn some real survival skills from the game, which may be useful in forests and jungles.
Why not 10: Well, what?

[h1] The Game [/h1]

Here are the first impressions from the game after 10 hours.
The main game starts [spoiler] after the wife gets lost. Checkpoint. [/spoiler]
Jumped off the cliff, as if it were GTA. Dead. Restarted from the last checkpoint. 
Jumped from few meters. Dead. Restart. 
Jumped from 1-2 meters. Got wounded (yes, alive!). Ignored it. Walked through jungles. The wound got infected from dirt. Got sick of it. Dead. Restart.
This time didn't try to test jumping. Oh, great, found a cave! Lets check it. Scorpion bites. Didn't notice it. It bites again. Poisoned. Seeing how life goes down, can't find leafs/mushrooms with antivenom properties. Dead. Restart.
Oh, lets build! Building a hut... Forgot about drinking water. Thirsty! Ocean water nearby. Argh, its too dirty! Got parasites. Ignored. Continued to build. Hut is almost ready, whooray! Lets eat banana... with dirty hands! Got more parasites. Thirsty, again! Drunk that bad water. Got lots of parasites. Got sick of it. Dead. Restart.
Lets do it right this time - food, building, water etc. Not wounded, got only few parasites, half on food - its okay. Lets explore the beautiful jungles! Nice! Heey I see lizard! Lets hunt it. Got it! Oh, got tired and sleepy. Hut is not nearby. Lets sleep in the jungle... under a heavy rain. Woke up. Had fever. Can't treat it. Dead. Restart.
Oh, and this is just the beginning. Haven't yet seen those tribes, big animals, fishes, snakes... which will kill me too!

Update: Yes, I've played 50+ hours, but haven't finished the main story yet. Why?
Imagine jungles, beach, sea... a palm tree on the beach, and a hut on top of it.
Now sit there and enjoy the beautiful view... when the sun is going down the sea...
Or look back and see jungles... a waterfall in front of you, with a rainbow above it, colorful flowers beneath it, and god-rays coming from the sun behind the tall trees...
Perhaps that's why they call it a "deadly beautiful" place!
Yes. I stopped the mission and started to build a complete settlement on one such place :)

[h1] Meta [/h1]

Review date: December 13, 2019
Playtime before writing the review: 10 hours
Price: $9.99, Black Friday sale

[h1] Verdict [/h1]

Thought you can't die in nature without dragons and dungeons?
Well, you haven't been in the Green Hell, yet!

Thanks for reading!

Not trying out this again after finding out its still unfinished after 3 years.

Edit note: This is not the only thing i have about this game, personally i don't enjoy the story of this cuck of a character. 

But the game overall is unfinished, items are still unusable like it was 3 years ago, you still get the same bugs from 3 years ago where you get stuck on an invisible hitbox, the ui is still awful, you have graphical glitches with distant shadows and it still feels like an early access title from 3 years ago with a major update to the storyline (with a few items so you can build like in The Forest).

This is legitimately one of my most favourite games. The story is great and heartbreaking. The survival can be challenging, and super fun to play with your friends. 

And the devs are still fully supporting it, with regular updates and bug fixes. 

The only negative thing I can say is if you're playing on a laptop -- make sure it is a really really good one.

I would never thought I would say that a survival horror can be so relaxing, well to be frank I am not very good at survival games but I do like them as I feel they help with giving courage to face life itself. This game is very good at it to be honest(in terms of survival realism to some sense) and the best part is as you get better at it, it gives you the confidence to just keep going. So point is, give this game a shot, you might like it even if you suck at such games. The strategy for me is to stay put at the start point until I get the hang of it, and to be honest I feel like you can even treat it as a outdoor camp vacation if you would ignore the main objective of finding the mc's wife and getting help hahaha, I will probably get around to doing so in the future. The graphics tho, so realistic, love it, the mechanics can be alittle unrealistic at times(placing a tree trunk into a tree plateform build without any means of getting up there first) but hey that's nice in itself.

You can only save in certain areas (Bed and some structures) BUT there are places if you slip of the edge you don't die but get stuck and slowly die as you are stuck and cannot get out of it. The game does not have an option to get out of the situation, and there are not console commands fro the game. So if play for say... 3 hours and cannot save, than you lose all that you have done! Not because you were killed, but because you got stuck  between cells in the game!

ORIGINAL REVIEW Jul 9, 2020
Only played Story - pretty unforgiving but not in a "git gud" kind of way. There's a vicious cycle of having an infection, not having enough time/ability to find antibiotics or maggots, and then also not finding any dang bandage plants. Some areas seem completely devoid of them. Make sure you use multiple saves because if you save in a bad condition/spot, you may get very frustrated. I'm sure it'll be better down the line, but this is a pass from me for the time being.

REVISITED Dec 23, 2023
Well, I got attacked/killed by a jaguar 4 times in a row in the first village when I was trying to make the brew back-to-back-to-back-to-back. Still can't find the bandage plant anywhere. When you die it still reverts you to the last save, so that sucks. I am going to check out Custom Mode though... maybe the story is good?

FINAL REVIEW
Ok, story was kind of interesting. Had a feeling it was going that way. Definitely no point in base building or sticking around - push through the story. Feels like it could have been great like The Forest but fell flat.

Loving the game so far, I’ve always had a soft spot for survival games, and this one I feel is top notch, especially for an early access game. 

That being said, I do have one complaint. Currently, you can’t save your progress without exiting and going to the main menu. It’s a little frustrating when you have hours of work done, only to die and have to start back from when you last exited the game. It definitely need at least an auto-save function every few minutes, and a manual save option as well. I don’t like having to “Save and Quit” every so often, as it detracts from the gameplay. 

Otherwise? Amazing job, please support them! Well worth it!

I dialed in the settings and enjoyed the single player story with no combat. I built a couple of bases and explored. The story is pretty interesting. I built a few bases around the map in the story mode and a separate save in survival mode.

The Spirits of Amazonia mode isn't as optimized so the frame rates are far lower than the base story mode. Hopefully that is updated and fixed. The SoA mode also is a huge reputation grind with factions; not a bad way to whittle away of ton of time per se but with the stuttering performance I didn't feel like sticking around.

Overall it's a pretty cool game.

If you enjoy simulation survival games, you should probably just buy this one out of sheer principle. 

This is one of those games that I had wishlisted veeeeery early on. Never got into it even around its official release. I was always simply skeptical of it for some reason. You know how some of these survival games kind of FEEL similar and amateurish? I always figured this would be one of those. 

Well, at some point I saw that it was getting semi-regular, big-content updates. At this point the reviews were constantly positive, way more than before, and the updates just made people happier. So I got it and ended up completely blown away. The game feels great, it looks great, and the simulation is juuuust detailed enough to add variety and realistic needs that it doesn't bog you down completely, MOST of the time.

And since I got it, the updates have just kept rolling out. FREE updates. Seriously, the only "DLC" is the soundtrack. This game came out in 2019, folks. These devs have been committed to the game for well over 4 years and that alone deserves recognition. 

I tried building a home over some water and had a few issues. A few months later, an update came out that made building these water-involved bases waaaay easier. They made a great game, and now they're refining it to be the best it can be. Its rare that a dev makes me excited for when they announce the end of updating and moving onto their next project. These folks won a fan in me.

Played it a few years ago, was fun. Coming back 1+ years later, I would not recommend to anyone. 

The player movement is awful. Jumping takes stamina, and if you have none, you cannot walk over the 4 inch branch laying on the ground in front of you.

Enemy combat is clunky, unrealistic, and just has very poor quality animations. They do the same lunge animation before jumping backwards, 100% of the time.

The ground of the world is not smooth whatsoever. This means you will constantly be running into little rocks and debris that halt your characters movement. 

Collecting resources is slow and tedious. 

With every living thing in the game being pretty much able to kill you, you are constantly healing yourself from the poison dart frog, scorpion, snake, or spider you didn't see on the ground (probably because it was hidden under a bush or a rock). 

The harder difficulties do not make the game more "difficult", it just drastically increases the amount of food and water you need to survive. 

The story of the game is interesting, but once you have seen it once, it is very very boring. On the creation of a new save, you are FORCED to sit through the 5-10 minute long cut-scenes, with no skip option. For the first time you every play the game, it won't be that bad, but every save after makes you want to play the game less and less.

Survival simulation games often have mechanics allowing player to shoot themselves. In Green Hell, this is drinking dirty water which will cause parasite infections, or eating random plants that are toxic. Players will learn from their deaths, and never press those wrong sets of buttons again.

Green Hell provides plenty of foot guns like this and little guidance to its mechanics. This makes the first few hours frustrating to play. Once you figure that out (either by trial and error, OR reading the wiki), you are left with the "correct" way to play the game.

At this point, Green Hell's core game play starts to disappoint:

* The player has many needs, which needs to be satisfied. They are broken into 5 gauges - water, sugar, protein, fat, and energy. This seems complex initially, until you realize that 1) resources are extremely plentiful and everywhere, and 2) there are overpowered and unrealistic recipes (e.g. bone soup) that can cheaply fill several needs at once.
* The combat exists solely to have a combat. Hunting and fighting is one dimensional and trivial.
* Base building exists but isn't necessary, since resource needed for survival are plenty.
* Exploration is boring. Since the view distance is small due to heavy forage in the jungle, you are left with just following the GPS + Map. I lost interest in exploration because everywhere looks the same, and have the same resources.

This is a game that is hard to learn initially and easy to master. Once you realize that there is no long term goal, no challenge, and no joy in exploration (invisible spiders), the game quickly loses its appeal.

"Green Hell" transports players deep into the heart of the Amazon rainforest, delivering a gripping survival experience that's amplified when played with friends. Struggling to survive in an unforgiving environment filled with deadly creatures, diseases, and environmental hazards, the cooperative mode adds a layer of companionship and shared problem-solving. Together, you and your friends must gather resources, build shelter, hunt for food, and fend off the dangers lurking in the jungle. Communication and teamwork become essential as you navigate the game's challenges, making for an immersive and intense multiplayer experience. Exploring the dense and beautifully rendered rainforest with friends elevates the suspense and excitement, creating unforgettable moments of triumph and survival.

For a quick and cool experience to simulate survival, this game does the best job so far but I am keeping my eyes peeled for the next best thing everyday because of how frustrating building in this game is. It's been over 2 years that many people have complained and they still haven't fixed it, they have however added more content to the game and recently the ability to have pets and breed animals... which would be nice to have if you could build a huge base right? Nope instead you have to settle for structures that are unfinished or disproportionate that look as though they were designed by a moronic game developer... The quality of the game reflects its maker(s) after all, it is self evident and if that's what they've settled for I tell you: they've settled for making your building experience a shitty one.

Now there's many other things this game promises to deliver which I'm sure they fall short of, I am not so well experienced or aware of those things... like multiplayer for example. I've had this game for awhile and I've gotten pretty far into it. However after the new building update i decided to pick it up again and start fresh. I set all settings to easy as i just want a chill play through this time but still have to worry about dangers and enemies eventually. What i can't believe is that there is still no save option?? i made it to the first camp, gathered supplies made some tools, had just boiled water and had a real meal to eat. By this time it's late and i made a bed roll and slept for the night. I wake up eat, drink water, and im about to go craft a spear when a tiger shows up. Ok no big deal it's to be expected i guess. I manage to get a couple hits and it runs off. Cool. Immediately after two tribesman show up with spears and start attacking me. Im constantly blocking and manage to kill one and stab the other one at least six times yet he's still standing attacking me. I feel like one or two more hits and he's dead but by this time I've bled to death and died... Ok no big deal i think because i had just slept through the night so i figured there would be some auto save feature right? wrong. I start over at there very beginning when you first wake up... almost two hours of taking my time and gathering what i need and enjoying the game gone because there's no save or auto save feature. Yet there's a save and quit feature!? so you're telling me if i want to save my game i need to completely exit the game and come back in? That's dumb asf. I could understand on a higher difficulty but the lowest difficulty setting? Some of us have jobs and live's and kids and don't have the luxury of having hours of progress thrown away. Add a save feature and maybe i'll try again.

Edit: I remembered that in order to save you have to build a shelter however my review still stands. In my situation i just described it didn't make much sense to go through the trouble of building a shelter just to save it when i have a bedroll under a prefab building anyway still in the beginning. If there's a "save and quit" option and you're on the lowest difficulty there's no reason to not have a save at will feature.

Beat the story twice, once on "Green Hell" difficulty, but I don't think I can recommend this one.

Everything about this game is basically designed to be annoying for a new player. They give you very little info about what anything is and it requires a lot of trial and error (or the inter-webs) to know what things do. Just save-scum so you can f around to find out.

And that's really the thing, once you "know" the game is pretty simple. For example, drinking dirty water becomes no problem when you know which mushrooms easily take care of parasites. My run with permadeath on only took a few hours, with the biggest threat of death being falling off a cliff. 

The story requires you to constantly move and unlock new areas, so building a base is a gigantic waste of time. And the worst part about it is building ANYTHING in this game is such a chore. On top of this, you need to build a shelter to save your game. Yikes.

The story was probably the best part. I liked the way it all came together, but the bad ending is so much better than the good ending.

TLDR: Solid 5/10, not horrible, not great. Good story. Crafting and base building is awful and useless (similar to The Forest). The survival stuff is only hard for the first few hours, then you just run around the jungle finding POIs.

Green Hell is a work of art in survival games. Jungles are replicated well, along with various prey and predator. In addition to remaining hydrated, players must ensure they maintain healthy levels of proteins, fats, & carbohydrates; along with getting regular sleep and even maintaining a positive mental state. Yes, you can go insane in this game. Even worse, there are a multitude of various wound and injuries possible, from food poisoning to parasites and accidentally dropping from exhaustion can lead to nasty worms embedded under the skin. Finally, local headhunters will seek out the source of any long burning fire on a regular basis, so crafting and obtaining weapons & armor skills is a must. 

With a well put together story line and various exposure to new crafting items and unique hardware, the experience is both challenging and rewarding. Multiplayer works well and greatly aids survival. With such high attention to detail to provide an true amazonian survival experience, this game is well worth the price. Honestly a required addition to any true survivalist gamer's library.

I played Green Hell a few years back around when it first came out and it was a genuinely fun game. Difficult, anxiety and paranoia inducing, and unforgiving in all the best ways. Now? I don't know what happened but the game is entirely unplayable because things happen with no rhyme or reason and each one will kill you on their own never mind when they happen back to back. In 10 days of in game time I was unable to so much as make it out of the starting area because every time I did I was either attacked by jaguars or hostile tribes. Not sometimes, not often, but every. Single. TIME. Every time I left that little starter area I would immediately take 2 lacerations which I couldn't get the right tools to treat because those herbs aren't in the starting area and then I would have infected wounds which absolutely tank your health and energy and I would end up passing out on my way back to my bed which was maybe a couple hundred meters away and because I slept without a bed I would contract 2-3 worms which require bandages to heal which I can't get because guess where those materials are? Not in the starting area.

It immediately became a cycle of "I need X to treat Y but if I leave to get X then Y will happen but because Y happened I need X but if I leave to get it Y happens so I need X but if I leave...." around and around until I die a stone's throw from the starting area.

First off, I have to say: this game will forever be my all time favorite survival game to play.

This is a game where you'll have fun playing alone or with friends and it can be played multiple times because of the rich story line regarding Jake and Mia Higgins that just leaves players wanting to find out more. After completing the first play through, players can also choose to continue to play the epilogue to find out what happened to Jake and Mia prior to getting "lost" in the Amazon rain forest. The story line with the natives and the main character's development through both the first and second play through were very interesting to me and my friends which was the very reason that got us hooked into playing the game in the first place.
Even on the easiest difficulty, it still offers a "survival mode" where (yes, if you don't treat your wounds, cure poisonous bites, use protective armor for combat, etc. You WILL die.) Personally, I love survival games with realistic/semi-realistic punishments like this one where players can learn what to do and what not to do (i.e. eating poison dart frog meat whether it be cooked or uncooked, will make you lose your mind because of the poison, consuming human meat will significantly decrease your sanity).

Smaller details to note:
The developers really paid additional attention to the music (when in combat/hunting/relaxing) and the ambiance to make sure this game is as "realistic" and as exciting as possible. You never really know what to expect in this game as your camp can get raided, you can turn a corner and get stung by a stingray in the river, get jumped by big cats, etc. Compared to other games like The Forest, this game gives me more of an adrenaline rush and it just makes more sense to me realistically and logically; down to inventory space (even though I am not a fan of the weight limit).
When it comes to graphics, I'm a big fan of the realism - which this game does indeed meet my picky requirements (i.e. if it rains, the leaves "look" wet, the ground becomes slippery, the water is either clear or murky, etc).

Minor issues: Considering this game is about 4 years old already, there are bugs. Lots of them. Good and bad. It's not too bad to deal with while playing, though, some common ones that I wish could be fixed are:
-The natives glitch into the rocks or up the mountains when in combat.
-Natives' bodies start twerking on its own even after they are deceased (I find this one funny but sometimes the bodies just fly into the air or disappear completely).
-Chopping down palm leaves or trees to get long sticks may cause them to sometimes have a seizure (this is random, and yes they have a mind of their own).
**One of the bugs that I actually found to be annoying is anything regarding fish. Specifically Arowana. When you catch or collect an Arowana from a fish trap and you have no inventory space, the game automatically drops it which may cause it to be unavailable for pick up. The option to pick up the fish is just...not there sometimes.
Sometimes when picking up the Arowana fish, it will magically float out of your backpack when you open it, resulting in your backpack looking empty but you cannot place anything in the space that the fish is occupying nor can you grab the fish either because it just flies instantly every time you press Tab.

Overall, the game itself is still a blast to play and besides the minor bug issues, it's a really solid game.
My personal overall rating of this game would be a 9/10. I love the game design and its mechanics. Would definitely recommend.

I've been lost in the lush and perilous world of Green Hell for a whopping 230 hours, and let me tell you, I haven't even scratched the surface of the story mode yet! That's right, every single hour has been spent exploring the vast depths of the jungle in sandbox mode. Green Hell has truly become my digital Eden, and here's why.

Customizable Difficulty:
Green Hell offers a level of customization that few survival games can match. Whether I'm tweaking the speed at which my nutrients deplete or adjusting the intensity of jungle threats, every playthrough feels uniquely challenging. From angry tribals to leeches, the game keeps me on my toes, and the ability to fine-tune the experience adds an extra layer of immersion.

Visual Splendor:
Even on my modest, low-spec PC, Green Hell is a visual feast. The game's stunning graphics manage to captivate, pulling me deeper into the heart of the Amazonian rainforest. The attention to detail, even on lower graphics settings, is commendable, making every exploration a breathtaking experience.

Solo or with Friends:
Whether braving the wilderness alone or teaming up with friends, Green Hell provides a dynamic and engaging multiplayer experience. The shared struggles and triumphs in this virtual jungle amplify the game's immersive qualities, and the cooperative play adds a new dimension to the survival narrative.

Crafting Complexity:
The crafting system in Green Hell is a masterpiece of complexity. Every item feels like a hard-earned achievement, and the game's emphasis on realism adds a sense of urgency to every crafting decision. From improvised tools to essential survival gear, the crafting system is as challenging as it is rewarding.

Versatile Building System:
Building my own base has been a highlight of my Green Hell journey. The versatility of the building system allows for complete customization, from the location and shape of my base to the materials used. It's not just a shelter; it's my sanctuary, reflecting my choices and strategies in the harsh jungle environment.

Devoted Developers:
I've eagerly anticipated and celebrated each new update from the developers. Their commitment to refining and expanding the game demonstrates a passion for delivering an ever-evolving and enriching experience. Green Hell feels alive, not just with the dangers of the jungle but also with the ongoing support from a dedicated development team.

In conclusion, Green Hell isn't just a game; it's an immersive, challenging, and visually stunning journey into the heart of survival. With 230 hours spent and countless more to come, I can't recommend this game enough to fellow adventurers seeking a truly remarkable survival experience.

One of the standout features of Green Hell is its jaw-dropping realism. The lush, dense foliage, the realistic animal behavior, and the dynamic weather system all contribute to an immersive experience that feels like a virtual trek through the Amazon itself. The attention to detail is simply stunning, making it easy to forget you're in a game and not navigating through the actual jungle.

The challenging aspects of the game are a true testament to the developers' commitment to delivering an authentic survival experience. From crafting your own shelter to foraging for food and dealing with the constant threat of illness and injury, Green Hell demands strategic thinking and adaptability. The game doesn't hold your hand, and every decision you make has consequences, creating a sense of urgency and excitement that few games can match.

What sets Green Hell apart from other survival games is its exceptional multiplayer mode. Joining forces with friends in the unforgiving jungle adds an entirely new layer of enjoyment. Cooperation becomes crucial as you tackle the game's challenges together, sharing resources, expertise, and the thrill of overcoming obstacles as a team. The multiplayer aspect turns Green Hell into a social adventure, where the camaraderie forged in the heat of survival is as rewarding as the triumphs themselves.

The graphics are top-notch, and the sound design further enhances the immersive atmosphere. The haunting sounds of the jungle, the calls of distant animals, and the patter of rain on leaves all contribute to a sensory experience that draws you in completely.

Everything in this game shows the dedication the developers put into it.
