A grand day out in the Amazon taking hallucinogenic drugs with your friends. 

Graphics- Pretty smooth, although enemy humans will glitch into a tree or boulder and still be able to attack you at range. Overall genuinely feels like a trek through the Amazon. 

Story- Surprising decent for a survival game and did not go into the direction I thought it would. Don't expect the ending to be life changing just enjoy the ride.

Gameplay- Fun, if unforgiving for the first few hours. Do NOT skip the tutorial. Enjoyed hunting food and scavenging for supplies as well as defending against enemies. Sanity plays a lot more in this then most survival games, so don't go crazy.

Sound- Soundtrack is awesome, very minimal during exploration (lets the natural sounds of the jungle do the work) and picks up good atmospheric tunes during hunting or fights. Give the main menu screen's track a listen in full, its a banger.

Co-op- This setting worked well enough, however my teammate and I couldn't understand the loading Saved Game system for a good while, as well as the re-spawn requirements. To save peeps time: Be sure to sleep and save game at the same location 'together' as often as possible. 

Building-Crafting the basics is very straightforward. Building shelters can be nit-picky due to needing to build foundations on a flat surface, not easy to find in the jungle in the middle of the night. The advance crafting (metal based tools and weapons) are a bit more  complex but don't really offer much for game progress and aren't necessary. 

8/10

Hopefully your Teammate does not fancy themselves an interior decorator and spend countless hours on base home improvement

This is a review after 100% the game.
If you like to build stuff this is not it. But if you like the survival vibe this game is a must play.
Story mode took me 25 hours to clear first run on normal difficulty (WtTJ) BUT took me 2 hours for the second run on hardest (GreenHell) with good ending. A lot of stuff you can do but its optional really.

Overall 7/10   I like the story/lore and how they present it.
Combat 1/10  EVERYTHING combat related is JANKY AF (Enemies flying around doing goofy dance)
Building 2/10 Cannot turn off snap. Can't build half of the time because of terrain. *There's no floor* 
Crafting 5/10 There's very few QoL it's pretty bad
Optimization 8/10 there's no stuttering / crash in any of my session so it should be good stable fps

//Except the story I think everything else is worse than the forest.

This seems to be a survival focused not a mega base building or hoarding stuff.(But I did build one mega-base wasted 30hrs on that thing that should've taken like 10-15hrs in other games) They took more realistic approach to survival than most. Melee is super unreliable and sometimes you can get the game breaking bug when getting hit. Only thing you can do is save and reload so it's pretty bad. You get less of this if you wear armor but still get it if unlucky. So to avoid getting hit you just have to use ranged and oh boy it's OP. There's no enemy that can take 3 spears stuck in the head. Normal mobs only takes one. For me who loves to build super efficient and neat base this is like super duper bad so it was a major let down. There's no building you can invest your time in and it would payoff in the long run.(Modes of transport/cultivating/husbandry *they have the 2 latter one but it's a waste of time(Have 10+ farm plot and all it gave was a minute resources that took 5 mins of gathering to farm, husbandry you need to clean the pen and feed them food quite often so you can't go too far and the map is HUGH)) While combat and building is really bad I think what got me was the lore and some nice surviving mechanics. Leeches drain your sanity and it's frustrating to click them off every 5mins but you'll learn to manage your sanity and not walk through the bushes/water to get them. How they narrates the story is pretty nice also (these genre usually have weak story + telling in general). Many mechanics are intuitive so you don't have to search stuffs on internet. Don't know why someone would read this but thanks lol

A quick tips
-DON'T do ironwork/husbandry/plant cultivation
-USE the easiest(weaker) tools you can craft. I used just bamboo spear the whole game on every modes and it works just fine. The more you craft the tougher your tools will be. Usually weaker tools are lighter than more advanced one so the trade off is only damage. But you can one hit kill by headshot 7/10 times.
-Early crafted tools will break like paper but keep using the cheap stuff it'll get tougher!
-Obsidian Axe is pretty tough it's worth it if you're going to cut lots of tree. (obsidian respawn in caves)
-Bait archer for their arrows if you're to lazy to craft it.
-Boiled blue mushroom give 5 more energy.
-Lookout for piranhas in the water.
-Bone broth is a thing.

"A nice walk in the jungle" they said, "it'll be fun" they said.  No more walks, no more fun, only my mud skyscraper on its way to pick a bone with the gods.

This game has much more depth than other survival games I've played (granted, I've yet to play Subnautica  ^^).  The amount of content the devs managed to incorporate in a fairly short Early Access period impresses me.

In my current run (sandbox), I've passed the 200 day mark, & have yet to feel bored; & beyond that, there was a point in time when I realized that playing this game actually feels like surviving to me.  That seems like an obvious thing, but by comparison, other games have missed that mark for me.

The choice of game modes & customization options available are excellent, & the game runs very well for me, despite my playing on a laptop.  The models are well done, & there's a plentiful variety of flora & fauna to gather & hunt.  I especially appreciate the seasonal change, even though the game's setting limits it to two (rainy & dry).

I haven't been focusing on building too much, but I've seen screenshots of structures that amaze me.  So if building is your thing, you should also be covered.  ^^

tl;dr:  I highly recommend this game.  I have nothing but respect for these devs, & couldn't be happier that I (finally  ^^) purchased it.

Update:  I've now done more building, & found it to be somewhat buggy.  It hasn't detracted from my enjoyment of the game, but I thought it bore mentioning.

Update #2  ^^ :  The devs are in the process of adding free DLC, Spirits of Amazonia, which will be delivered in three parts, adding new maps & story segments.  Part one dropped about a week ago; I played the new map in sandbox, & am now playing the story, something I normally never do w/ survival games.  I'm having a blast, & even more convinced that CJ are among the best dev teams around.  ^^

Update #3  ^^:  And the devs just keep adding more goodness.  <3

Surprisingly Compelling.

Immediately, [i]Green Hell[/i] presents itself as a janky Amazonian survival game. Death finds you at every turn, survival is a steep climb, the physics is untold nonsense, and the first thing you need to do is [i]craft[/i]. Green Hell reeks of the generic game that its dime-a-dozen tags suggest - and behaves the part, as well - but trudge through the challenge long enough and you'll find a well-crafted story.

Sure, the trifecta is all there. Green Hell employs an open-[i]ish[/i] world which you're free to explore. Shelter, cooking, healing, and hunting are all critical components. Crafting is required and done through experimentation and discovery. From the survival-crafting perspective, Green Hell isn't too special, but it breaks the mold by feeling like [i]Primitive Technology[/i], the video game. Shelters are a slog and require lots of gathering. Foraging and hunting are a game of trial-and-error, with your knowledge of plants and animals coming from eating or cooking them. You even need to maintain balanced macronutrients in addition to merely "finding calories". In addition, as you collect just enough resources to get by, the environment presents relentless and unpredictable challenges that keep you on your toes.

What genuinely impressed me was the story. I wasn't prepared for it at all, but it's integral to the game and [i]captivating[/i]. Green Hell tells a meaningful and topical story through the lens of an amnesiac re-discovering it himself. Whenever you think you understand what's going on, the game is quick to subvert your expectations. Those twists and the story's evolution give [i]Green Hell[/i] a profound depth that kept me hooked.

There's catharsis in being pleasantly surprised by a game - and Green Hell is a refreshing and healthy dose of shattered expectations.

I watched a stream of the "developers" playing, hoping to figure out what the deal is, but frankly, they didn't look like they knew what they were doing. That's very odd.

I'm confused, and I really don't want to play anymore until I find out if it's a bug, a feature. I can't believe anyone would leave it at that. 

I guess it's a "no" until I get more information; you know, like the kind that should have been included IN THE FREAKING TUTORIAL.

Well all I can add if you really love survival then this is one of the best.
However!  it still has learning curb and like any game without effort you may get hurt and die.
Green Hell works with Macro Elements setting it out from other survival.
Macro Elements= player must learn to how to manage  proteins Carbs Fats water. 
We now have 3 levels to choose from.
A Walk In the Park allows the player to experience survival with nature itself learn the skills and what native animals  / plants to watch out for. 

Then try the normal mode Welcome to the Jungle level where you will experience the whole game with tribes/ predators and sanity.
Keep both levels and switch between them.

This game is unlike any other survival game I have played , it takes some players time to realize the only goal is explore learn and survive against very real and lifelike predators.

If you have ever watched Lost or Naked and Afraid.
Build shelter find food and water craft your tools explore.. Watch out for spiders snakes but they give a warning sound when near by.
It's so addictive, failure is not option for many players who then get frustrated as the only way was to learn by their mistakes and start again.  
Save  manually often reload when you die, learn, move on and avoid. :)
Save is possible only when building a small shelter, or a roof.

There is no mods or quick fixes.
Use your compass and save .
Look at the great Steam /Youtube guides first !!!

If you experience any dizziness as  the FOV is very immersive, simply .
Press the tilt key for the frames to displayed.
refer to this guide

EVERYTHING

[h1]Green Hell, AKA Leech Farming Simulator[/h1]
I'm giving this a thumbs up because I spent hundreds of hours in it and I'll most likely spend some more, [b]BUT[/b] I recommend it with caveats. The most important one is: In multiplayer mode, you are going to have a baaaaad time. And I mean [b]bad[/b]. [u]Be mentally prepared to have your game ruined 50 hours into the game[/u] because something glitched and the save became unplayable. This is not just me being finicky, I'm talking about [b]game breaking bugs[/b] that will make progression impossible for at least one of the players and you will have to start a completely new game. 

That being said, let me be thorough on the rest:
 
The tutorial is not really a tutorial, it's more like an interactive prelude where the characters talk and the setting for the story is explained. It will tell you stuff like using WASD to move and pressing E to interact with objects, which is pointless for any game made in the last 15 years, but it won't tell you how to split a coconut in half to boil water to drink, which is something you'll need to do in the first minutes after the tutorial and what gets most players killed in their first run. 
That's just a detail that causes some minutes of annoyance at the start of the game, but it's a sign of how things are going to be from there on.
 
I really liked the approach of having nutrients instead of just "eat and drink whatever" like in many survival games. It's also fun to try and discover the effects of different things when you eat them or use them in different ways. I wish there were more ways of doing this, like combining meats and vegetables in a pot to have a more nutritious food, crushing plants in a bowl to make ointments, etc. 
This is a very needed feature, IMO, because nutrient depletion and energy exhaustion happen at a very fast rate. The realism of needing a balanced diet to stay healthy is met by the absurdity of needing a whole night of sleep two or three times a day. 
This could be offset if eating better foods made nutrient depletion slower or sleeping in a better bed made energy drain slower, for example.

The crafting is also pretty nice. I like that you don't need a "crafting table" of sorts like in so many other games, and discovering the different recipes is actually quite fun. Finding out how to craft different kinds of armour and weapons was game-changing and exciting. 
The bad side is that different tools and weapons are basically just skins for the same thing. The shitty bow you can make the first minute into the game has the same draw strength as the super nice shiny bow you can't even craft yourself. Same with arrows or axes. Having different stats for tools would make crafting a more strategic decision and not just a chore.
Regarding the variety of recipes for crafting, there are things that are trivial for anyone that's left out in the nature (and are even present as decorations in the game), but somehow beyond the character's skills. For example, making a basket weaving leaves. 
I think pretty much anyone has intuitively weaved leaves to make a tiny box while sitting and chatting at a camp or picnic. This concept, however, is foreign to Jake. 
Then again, we're talking about a guy that decided to wear shorts and t-shirt to go to a wild jungle where all sorts of poisonous animals and plants abound.

Which leads me to the next point: Interaction with threats. 
I get that if you step on a snake, it makes sense it will bite you in the leg. But how does it make sense that stepping on a spider wearing thick trekking boots also stings you on the leg? That's exactly how we kill spiders, by stepping on them! 
And how tf does a spider bite you through the armour? What are these spiders made of, that can pierce armour that otherwise stops spears and arrows?? 
Same with leeches. Leeches everywhere. All the time. Non stop. Carry a jar and sell them by the pound when you go back to civilisation because even if you wear armour, the leeches will somehow crawl under it. 
If at least they could be stored and used as bait for fishing, it'd be worth the hassle, but their only effect is making you stop for 10 seconds every three minutes to pull them off and carry on. 

Building is kinda nice, but I think it falls a bit flat. It's nothing innovative, it has a system similar to The Forest, so it's a proven formula that just works. But I think it's a bit weak because of design logic issues. 
For example: you can't snap blueprints together. You have to finish a building completely and then you can snap another blueprint to it, so if you want to plan something ahead and you're not sure if you're positioning the first piece correctly... good luck with that. 
Also the ratio of harvesting, carrying and usage of materials is made to be the most annoying combination possible. 
You need 13 leaves for a shelter? Too bad, the palms drop 10 to 12. And you can carry only 6.
This holds for all buildings. It seems to be made to exasperate the player and make everything as wasteful of time and resources as possible. It's not even a design made on the service of realism, it's only against the enjoyment of the player.
The other reason why building doesn't live up to its potential is that there are lots of buildings and furniture that can be built, which feels very exciting and inviting, but then you find that there's barely any place in the game where someone keen on base building can actually put all these resources to use and build something big, which leaves a bitter taste of disappointment. 
Other than that, the building system works ok if you're doing a more nomadic style and you have dozens of mini bases spread throughout the maps. Which I guess is the spirit of the game, but is not consistent with providing such a rich building catalogue. You feel all dressed up and with nowhere to go.

Regarding the story of the base game, it's ok too. It isn't anything mindblowing or that hasn't been done before. I think that before reaching the second map, we had already guessed the twists and ending of it. 
However, it is quite well carried and it has some mini-maps with novel-like interactive cut scenes that show you parts of it which are very nicely done and quite dramatic. So kudos on a good execution of an otherwise average or slightly above average script. 

The story of the expansion, however... Feels like a different game. There's barely any story at all. It's just grind-grind-grind-grind ad nauseam. And it's not even MMORPG kind of grinding, where you feel determined to grind as long as it takes to get [b]The[/b] weapon you need, no no. Here it's "you are blocked from progressing" until you do this boring task over and over and over again for 10 hours. All while stopping every 2-3 minutes to pull leeches out of your legs. 
Exploring the same maps but with different features in them is nice, though. Gives a feeling of time passing and the dynamism of a jungle ecosystem. The addition of new maps is great too. 
Some of the locations are just beautiful. I have stopped more than once to just look around and appreciate the scenery. The rain, the fog, the parrots flying by, the sunlight piercing in beams through the foliage... just beautiful. 

All in all, it's a game I'd recommend buying if you can get it with a hefty discount. Otherwise you'll feel you paid to get frustrated.
I know this game was created by an initially small team, but Creepy Jar is no indie garage studio anymore and the game is in current development, so there's no excuse for having such big amount of game-breaking bugs that have been reported since day one still unresolved, or not having animations for many interactions, making it look like an alpha release instead of the 5 year old game it is. If at least the modding was more flexible, I'd be happy to sit down and put some hours into coding to fix the many clipping bugs with a mod, but that's not possible.

At first, it looked and seemed like a decent game. But after putting a few hours to learn the game, it's too late to refund now. Steam needs more options when it comes to refunding games that aren't what I expected. 2 hours is not enough to figure out some games if they are worth keeping and playing. 

Aside from that, this game wants to be realistic, but it's not. It's too simple, like the forest only a bit more details.

I put a "killer trap" near my base. I catch 10 pigs a day with this trap. They don't even walk into the trap. They just appear out of nowhere. You turn your back on the trap and 1 second later there is a pig inside it again.

The sanity goes down too fast, you constantly are picking off leeches form yourself, even with armour and such on. So it breaks the fun when every couple minutes you need to peel leeches off your body. It's tedious and putting your stuff back on is a pain in the rear.

You get tired as soon as you leave your camp for a few minutes, even with full food bars. We had to turn Tiredness off, it just was too much when you want to explore and gather things. If you already slept all night and full of food, hydrated, in morning why are you tired before noon breaks? Makes absolutely no sense at all.

Oh and the story mode is cringe. They spent more time yapping and wasting time than actually learning how to play in the tutorial. Had to quit that.

Green Hell is a punishingly difficult survival game. But it rewards your persistence by creating a very effective learning curve. When my husband and I started playing, we were dying left and right, gaining negative conditions stacking on top of each other. Run from a hostile native only to step on a snake. Try to eat a healing mushroom only to get parasites because you were dirty. Start running back to base, but fever makes your fatigue plummet so you fall asleep on the jungle floor and get a worm. Nightmares on top of nightmares.

But as you play the game you slowly learn how to navigate the dense jungle safely. You learn what treatments work on which kind of ailment (I wrote them on cue cards I keep on my desk). You learn what supplies to carry and what you can forage as you travel. You craft armour and tools with better and better durability.

Now after beating the base game, and halfway through the Spirits of the Amazonia expansion we are lean, mean, jungle survival experts. My husband is diligently building a massive multi-story tree house to keep our supplies safe from the natives. He has identified the paths they take to attack us and lined it with traps. I'm off on long trips across the map finishing tasks and searching for iron. Building temporary shelters, landing head-shots with my bow, and surviving off the land. I really, truly feel like I have levelled up my skills despite the levelling aspects of the game being very minor. We've transitioned from victims of this jungle to masters of it.

This is a survival game like no other. Realistic and brutal, but fun and satisfying.

I have, collectively, thousands of hours in survival base-building games. I love them and all the challenges they present. Green Hell is undoubtedly one of the worst ones I have ever played, because its challenge does not stem from gameplay. I usually tolerate the hardships such games present long enough to where I can give them a genuine attempt, but Green Hell made its absolute best effort to make me feel as unmotivated to play as possible. 

You have a crafting notebook. It contains *some* crafting recipes, but not all of them, for some reason. UI navigation is a hell unto itself. There are early access games still in [i]alpha[/i] that have better developed UI and UX than Green Hell. Controlling this game is borderline intolerable. The challenge a game presents should never come from its menus and interfaces.

I don't like saying no on a recommendation for a game that I feel is so well done. I would have liked a different way to review on this one. I want to be clear that the quality of this game is excellent. The sandbox element is enjoyable. It's limited when compared to other games, but I'd still recommend it. The story element is what failed for me.

It's well executed, but it feels like a horror rip-off Medicine Man. It's probably not fair to call it a rip-off though as there are some quite creative elements that make a unique narrative. The story is grim and the ending is hopeless even with the "good ending". I don't mind a bad ending due to bad choices or a bad ending where narrative is humorously absurd or unreal. The MC is a tortured anti-hero and every major choice he makes is irrational for any modern anthropologist. I realized early in the story that [spoiler] the MC was the cause and played on looking for a redemption arc that never came. [/spoiler]

I know this is a personal preference, but I suspect this is shared among players who game to relieve the normal stresses of life. If I could go back, I would choose not to have played the story. Maybe I missed something along the way that would have warned me off. I just read this game as potentially challenging when I started playing.

The game opens strong, in mechanics and narrative, but goes downhill. The game is known for difficulty, but that is mostly centred in a brutal learning curve. It all seems very intricate, but the challenge is in the lack of knowledge. It's interesting having to learn by trial and error what you can eat, but there's remarkably little that's actually dangerous, and once you get past the first couple of days food is no longer an issue. There's not even similar looking items which are either dangerous or not. The pattern is too simple. The game has its maladies, which is interesting, but most are easy to deal with. There's a whole water purification aspect, but parasites are too easy to just deal with. Otherwise the game relies on somewhat cheap difficulty by simply having near lethal hazards dotted around. It's challenging in the same way crossing a minefield is challenging. Also once you figure out how to make armour, random big cat attacks are an inconvenience, not a threat. Also development is, dissapointing. The game doesn't seem to intend player settle down and get comfy, and there's no point. You can make better tools, strive for metal... but there's no point. Even the deadliest threats or sturdiest prey fall to a headshot, and neither is too good at evading them. In short, lots of interesting ideas, which feel shallow in implementation once you get a few hours in.
Also the less said about the story mode the better. It starts strong with intrigue and surprises, but it doesn't last. It does use foreshadowing well, and the twists between the two main characters is good, I'll give them that. The dialogue between them is often quite good, layered with the right amount of... not quite right. I'd avoid spoilers, but the story mode doesn't deserve it. In short, it leans on the trope of tribal medicine being better than the combined knowledge of the globe, to the point of being a literal miracle cure panacea. But for some reason, some part of it is presumably missing, which causes a virus? Or prevents the panacea working on a virus? Neither is clearly put forward, and neither make sense. If it was a side effect of the medicine, it wouldn't be viral, and the supposedly immaculate health of this miracle tribe precludes the latter. The whole story loses touch with reality going into the second region which makes its determined attempt to layer blame on the player character, strange. There's also some slightly amusing... comments on quarantine that aged like milk, but to be fair the story mode was released pre-covid, so it couldn't know people were going to have a frame of reference to compare their narrative holes to.
Still curious to play it? I'd recommend with friends, and survival mode. The early game really is reasonably fun and wild. But the dangers falls off quick, "better" tools aren't worth the time, and your own personal stories will be better than the one they made.

My original review below is intact. Since then, I've been playing on multiplayer, which had a totally different death / respawn mechanic that make the game hit way better. If you can maintain on the front side of the power curve on this game, it's rewarding if a bit laborious (and I keep coming back to that word), but not necessarily in a bad way. The mechanics keep you from just shutting off and hitting trees, if that's what you're looking for, but the exploration combined with building, gathering, hunger and stat management, and hostile threats keeps things pretty lively. It's a good game but definitely won't be everyone's cup of tea. 


I see what they're doing here, but the result is just save scumming over and over again, having natives cheap-shot one hit you without warning, and finally, an infection that didn't appear on my arms or legs at all, with no status icon. Neat idea, but the gameplay loop is particularly laborious, and the amount of random deaths and reloads made the experience just not fun. It's a great concept, and the implementation is kinda there, but it's mostly just a frustrating loop of reloads and saving every few seconds to prevent having to do the same tedious tasks over and over again. after a few dozen hours of gameplay, my character is only a few hours old, and not in an enjoyable way.

I bought this game on a whim after seeing that it was a somewhat intense survival game.

I cannot recommend this game enough if you enjoy survival games, as the gameplay is very fun and rewarding.

I can't believe I haven't come across this game past years till now.
Green Hell is such a special survival game, that deserves all the love it already gets. It beats games like Sons of the Forest in my opinion easily.
Learning the game, even with the Tutorial, including curing all my diseases was a pain the ass. The crafting mechanics are so individual as in no other game.
The graphics are absolutely stunning, the gameplay super realistic. Apparently if you climb up a roof with leaves, it would even collapse. I mean frl, how realistic is this? If I were to make a Game, I would've never thought of such small details. The Story I have yet to continue, but so far I freaking love it. The animations are also something that just has to be called out, they're amazing.

When it comes to Multiplayer, my mate keeps teleporting around, some tribesman in the wall, but nothing really gamebreaking. 

The only negative part I'm missing on this game would be a quick switch in your backpack to the chests and what so ever. Can sometimes really get on your nerve sorting this manually from one to another spot.
Literally a copy paste of the forest... how ingenious and original... way to go, ''Creepy Jar''.

Badly broken game. Can spawn into a new game and have no available materials for building. Character just suddenly falls over dead sometimes. Game just doesn't work.

In an attempt to give an "authentic jungle survival" experience, Green Hell makes you fight with the interface every step of the way. You want to pull the meat off of that fish so that you can cook it? Hope you have extremely high precision with your mouse. You wanna cook that fish meat? No, you're gonna throw it on the ground instead! Wanna build a structure? Open your notebook, guess which sub-category the thing you want is in (which are navigated only with icons across all the various edges of the pages, so you are constantly weaving back and forth to change categories), then flip through page after page after page until you discover that it's not in that entry so now you have to hunt for the next tab to find the thing. Oh it's not there either! Guess you better start over... except you just died of hunger because time is still passing.

Creatures and hazards that range from nuisances to deadly are sometimes invisible, so you can stumble into things that kill you without any warning. You must manage multiple types of nutrition, which of course will sometimes not spawn at all, making it impossible to do anything about debilitating hunger. Some items are crafted by using a recipe from a notebook, others by opening your crafting radial menu and selecting from your pack, still others by picking up something large and then right-clicking and selecting "Craft" from the item, so you never know what you need to do to build something.

Level design includes visual tells to help guide you when you spot an important place, such as the use of color, signage, and shape to direct you—but often only when you get right to the spot; you have to weave aimlessly through the jungle like a drunken anaconda to find anything.

Categories of items that you use are often nonsensical; if you are building something out of sticks, you can't also throw in some bamboo sticks. Those are two different things and the game Will! Not! Allow it! Instead you must make a SPECIAL bamboo thing.

No ability to craft simple items that would be useful to you: You can't use bamboo to make a tube for carrying water, you can't use a stick to make a trail marker to help you navigate and put a marker on your map with charcoal, you can't even use a pair of banana leaves to pick up a poisonous frog safely.

Visually excellent, the gameplay of this is a mess, and the user interface is the biggest part of the challenge.

I have taught survival for BSA Explores and military and this is a fare game to learn conservation and skills.   Positives: causes stress, panic and encourages planning.  Negatives: Unrealistic in thirst.  Went over a dozen days without water in dry season which normally would be fatal.   Game makes it almost impossible to not get parasites which add consumption with little to cure them  although enough to survive.  Frequent saves which means the game is no pushover.  The negatives in this game make it more challenging. Only thing I did not like is passing out in a tree house and getting worms. ?? really if it is safe to sleep in a bunch of leaves why would you get worms from a wooden floor up off the jungle terrain?  Ok, with planning plenty of food but drought makes water limited. Learning curve on killing animals and natives. This would be more enjoyable with others helping but resources are limited.

Honestly the game is fine, i just wish the crafting or whatever im doing wrong was easier to understand.

Feedback for the developers: My friends and I were looking for a co-op survival game (we played Valheim, The Forest and Sons of the Forest before) and based on how the game looks and concept we decided to purchase it, however having played 2h we returned it. There were several reasons we didn't like ist, one of them is the tutorial not being good and its poor instructions. It took us ages to figure out how to make a fire and craft items. Even little things like press C and "inspect your body" there was no such thing on the menu. There was a magnifying glass lol, but this doesn't mean "inspect your body". It just says inspect. Please be more clear and concise with your menu, or better get rid of the wheel and use shortcuts instead. The user interface to access and craft things felt incredibly counter-intuitive and leaves much room for improvement. As for the game play: We went for 'welcome to the jungle' (assuming this is the normal level). Day 1: leeches and parasites, that's fine, but day 2 already a tiger and a cannibal when we're already struggling with the awful user interface and then loosing all the tools and weapons when you do die? You did a fantastic job in making us want to refund the game, well done!

Day 1: After falling off of a cliff my bf and I start our wonderful journey into the jungle, we run into some naked dudes
We Die.
Day 2: We find a cliffside to build a small camp on, we sleep in our cozy new tents.
My bf gets worms and dies.
Day 3: We try to find water. We don't know how to make fresh water. I drink from the river.
I get parasites and die.
Day 4: We begin to build our base. My bf hears a growl in the distance.
We get mauled by a jaguar and die.
Day 6: My bf starts to hallucinate, he begins to laugh uncontrollably even though the game is not making his character laugh. I am scared. This game is terrorizing us irl. He sees a naked man running toward him.
He dies.
Day 7: After a quick glance at the wiki we finally understand how to drink clean water. I pick up an alive poison dart frog.
Immediately dead.
Day 8: We drink ayahuasca. I finally understand what it is like to feel high. After I'm done hallucinating we run into the new open woods.
I run into a jaguar and die.
Day 9: We run into an illegal gold mine and try to understand spanish.
I am dying internally.
Day 15: We run into an illegal drug factory and read sad love letters.
I am crying inside.
Day 20: We find a plane. I realize that the main character is an awful person.
Day 21: We get to the end of the game. We get the wrong ending. I feel like ♥♥♥♥.
I die to the naked man.

Green Hell, an immersive survival game set in the Amazon rainforest, deserves its 6.2/10 rating. The game's lush, detailed environment is its strongest asset, creating a truly captivating atmosphere. Survival mechanics are realistic, requiring players to manage physical and mental health, making every decision crucial. The crafting system is intricate, allowing the creation of tools, weapons, and shelters. Despite these strengths, Green Hell suffers from some flaws. Repetitive tasks and occasional bugs can dampen the experience. Moreover, the learning curve can be steep, deterring newcomers. However, the game excels in delivering a genuine survival challenge, where every resource matters and danger lurks in every corner. With further polish and variety, Green Hell could elevate its appeal, offering a more well-rounded and enjoyable survival experience.

tl;dr - Game is unbalanced. Threats do not equate to time in to deal with them in meaningful or fulfilling way. In addition to not having an efficient or sure way to do so. Which is the majority of the game. 

I know of only a few friends that might play this, at all. Let alone long enough to not get a refund. 
This game has severe balancing issues. You will spend the majority of the game playing doctor to your self. If you save scrub constantly, and never stop gathering resources you might be fine. 

There's a load of people to sing this games praises and that's okay, there's a lot to like.

My issue with the game, put as simply as I can. 

Injury -> Find resource to heal -> Found -> Craft -> Healing -> Healing doesn't work because some dirt got on wound even after applying correct healing method, its now infected -> Find cure for infection -> Starving and need rest -> Search for food -> Find food, about to pass out. If you pass out, that equates to more injuries that might get infected -> Rest -> Nearly dead from infection and hungry again -> Prioritize finding healing as you are near death -> Move slower, lack of stamina from starving, search for healing takes longer -> Find proper healing resources -> Craft/heal -> Wound is no longer infected but you are out of proper healing resources but still have an open wound and still starving -> Look for food -> Verge of passing out and no choice but to use immediate options -> Find floor bird -> Try to make fire -> Not enough stamina -> Sleep -> Health has regenerated slightly, but not enough due to lack of food -> Build fire -> Cook food -> Eat food -> Can move freely now with some stamina for sprinting -> Wound is infected again. 

Does that seem like a lot to you? This is the issue with the game. Its the above, over, and over, and over again. A single injury can cause you to endlessly spiral into the game being completely ruined and needing to start over. The above is a common, but LUCKY scenario where you end up -as bad as you started- because the game has no god damned chill when it comes to being anything resembling balanced. Its like a snake eating its own tail, everything you do with cost you and you're running at full speed to stay in the same place, but the game disallows you to run fast enough and you inevitably end up in a death spiral. 

The only way to prevent this is 
1. Save scrubbing. Save literally every few minutes. 
2. When you're in any kind of bind, basically you better already have a base and lots of resources or you're done for. The actual thing you're supposed to do in this game if injured is nothing. Heal your self and not do anything. If you harvest any food while healing you could be infected. So there's a lot of actual waiting around. Which to the character you're playing is exhausting. 

Its frustrating. Even when you know what you're doing. Not even mentioning the random puma attacks. 

Lastly. Carrying literally anything. You need a ton of resources to survive. 
You can make item boxes, but many items cannot go into the box, for some reason. 

So it makes sense to just, take it with you. 

However. Imagine playing Resident Evil 4, and having one herb take up 1/5 of your item space. That sound good? I know it doesn't. The backpack system is atrocious. You have a limited amount of actual space to use, with makes some sense on its face. But, NOT when some LEAVES take up nearly your entire allotted pockets for things you NEED but cant eat. I cannot do it justice. It might be the worst item system I've ever seen. It does not align with the relative polish of the rest of the game.

That's only the first issue I have. The second is nearly worse. The maximum weight you can carry without being dramatically slowed down, is less then my single arm bicep curl. This dude, this intrepid survivor, killer of crocs and scourge of man killing cats, cannot carry 50lbs without needing to walk like he's on his way to the retirement home. 
Wait. Maybe this all makes sense in some strange way. Like the main character is actually a below average guy with no immune system, though I don't think that's the case. 

All that, and I have little respect for devs that seem to be anti player, but that's a different bag of worms. The game overall is pretty good. Graphics, sound design, voice work, and general game play are all fairly good. But it needs work still, and I feel like the devs aren't reeaallly going to change much at this point.

A lot of reviews say this game is all about survival and is the best. I found that after a few hours of figuring things out surviving is extremely easy and just becomes a nuisance. Once you get a small little base set up and figure out how to get water and food it's all downhill. The larger map outside of the immediate starter area adds almost nothing new.

I completed the story and wanted to like this game but it just felt easy to follow the story line with some tedious "survival." I really enjoyed the first several hours, then there's not much reason to play beyond that.

I did enjoy the story some, but the crafting recipes and map is strange. You can practiaclly ignore the entire left half of the map. There's time where it would have been nice to unlock basic recipes but for some reason you have to find the item in the world to be able to craft it for certain things. For example I never built any water collection or filtration recipes, by time I found it I had already figured out how to survive without.

So It's not meant o be a build a base type survival that almost all survivals are now a days. they have added base building but it's not necessary for the story line. I really really enjoyed my first play through,

I'll admit when I got this one, it was because someone my wife worked with recommended it to me. Now I know that "there is always a bigger fish in the sea" but I'm sitting at over 300 games in my steam library with almost 7,000 hours. I love a good survival game, as good ones are hard come by. This one most definitely has made a turn for the better over time. Does it have bugs? Sure it does, but these days we have triple A grade titles making lazy slip ups too. They have brought in a new element into the survival gaming world. You not only take damage, but you also have to physically check your arms and legs for various types of damage. I've even had to pick leeches off of my character! Which brings me to another point, sanity. If you don't take care of your health, (in the four different aspects along with your physical check ups) you'll start losing your mind. Hearing voices, and eventually fighting people that aren't there. Very few games have I seen actually take up on this old but gold aspect. In short, I really couldn't imagine someone regretting the purchase of this game, especially seeing as the time of writing this, it's on sale for like fifteen bucks american dollar. Just be patient through the learning process of the tutorial and the game, and you'll be cruising along in no time. I'm finally through the basics, and I'm now actually going through the story. Plus you can play co-op with your friends. Enjoy!

Honestly this game is way to hard for my low skill level. If you are good at survival, this is very realistic. The game itself is amazing. Great graphics, great story line (from the little I've seen), and very immersive gaming environment. Every action has a consequence. And I mean EVERY action, and even lack of action, has a consequence. I'm just not cut out for all of the survival scenarios- despite thinking I would be. Even the easiest setting is a bit over my head. I'd recommend this game if you have a lot of patience and think that slower and realistic survival games are therapeutic. With no bias, this game is a 10/10. But because I just can't figure it out, I'll give it a 5/10 for how much rage it's caused me... haha.

The first 15 minutes of this game teaches you one very important thing: Your guy is made of wet tissue paper, and has no place being anywhere outside of a padded cell.

Jokes aside, this survival game is harder than hard. The smallest slip can result in fatal injuries. My guy fell 5ft, got a scratch, which got infected, and died from fever/dehydration/major organ failure. No idea why he even tries to leave the house with how fragile he is, much less venture into the brutal Amazonian jungle where everything with a pulse wants to sign your obituary.

Still, once you get the hang of surviving past your first 15 minutes, things start to get better. There's building, (a bit of) farming, cooking, hunting, fishing, killing tribals, eating them, etc, etc. All of that, while maintaining your macronutrients, something you never did irl... wasn't this praised for being realistic??

If you ever want to feel the stress of metaphorically straightening a crumpled, wet tissue paper without tearing it, try this game.

Green Hell is a remarkable survival game that offers an immersive and challenging experience in the heart of the Amazon rainforest. However, due to its demanding mechanics and scarcity of native attacks, it may not be suitable for players looking for a more relaxed or action-packed gaming experience. If you enjoy realistic survival challenges and don't mind the absence of frequent combat, Green Hell is definitely worth exploring

This game should be a fun multiplayer co-op survival crafting.  The mechanics are interesting (especially dealing with injuries and food balance), the effects of setting are creative, the tutorial is minimal so it's a delightful challenge to progress through the game, etc.

However!  Reloading saves in multiplayer is buggy.  Some of these bugs have been documented for years and are still not fixed.  For example, crafting stations may no longer work correctly, which makes the game unplayable.  Hopefully the devs can work on the backlog of known bugs, because the game has great potential.

This game has some promise, but I'm afraid it won't live up to it.  The summary: it's too buggy to play in multiplayer.

The aesthetic is interesting.  The game has neat mechanics: rather than a simple health/status bar, you have to examine yourself for injuries and treat injuries of different types in different ways.  The inventory management is a bit clunky, but in ways that are quasi-realistic for the stranded-in-a-jungle setting.  You have to eat a balanced diet to remain at full strength, which means you can't just harvest or farm a single food.

But the game is unplayable in multiplayer due to what appear to be synchronization bugs.  I hosted and didn't have problems.  My partner joined and played with few incidents in the first session.  In our second session, however, it seemed that about half of the items that she picked up in the world or moved between inventory containers (backpack, storage box, etc.) would disappear.  In a crafting/survival game, this is brutal: cooked meat, plants that cure ailments, etc. went missing.  It's hard to play a survival game if you can't eat the food you pick up (because it vanishes).  This bug appears to have been reported over the past few years, but with little to no response or resolution, so I don't have hope of it being fixed.

If you're really into single player survival games, this might work out.  But don't buy it for multiplayer.

Green Hell is a survival crafting game about a guy lost in the jungle.  It goes much harder into the survival than the crafting angle, with the primary focus most of the time simply being staying alive.  That means finding food and shelter and keeping your (multiple) health gauges topped off.  But this is hard, as the game has a very minimal tutorial and just throws you into things with the danger level at 100%.

You'll stumble around blindly, get bitten by a snake, stung by wasps, swarmed by leeches, drink water infested by parasites, eat poisoned mushrooms, then mauled by a jaguar.  In the beginning it's not really an enjoyable experience.  You'll have status ailments attached to you and have no idea how to get rid of them.

With knowledge you can mitigate every threat to your person, or better, avoid them instead.  By the end of the game you will demolish the hostile naked stick wielding natives in your metal armor, 360 no scope that jaguar in the head with your bow, gut it for meat, then bring it back to your luxurious base with a bed made of leaves, meat smoker (aka a bunch of sticks tied together), and storage crates made of mud.  Sip from your line of pure rain filled coconut shells and nibble on your cache of dried and cooked meats.

The story of the game is the high point.  It starts off sort of vague but gets a lot better the further you go and as your discover more things.  I'm extremely partial to the bad ending.

There's a slight veneer of jank across a lot of things.  Cutting down trees and such will sometimes have logs flying around, the game sort of tries to predictively put food in your path but can often be missed when it spawns falling fruits/nuts behind foliage you couldn't possibly see, things can spawn clipped into terrain and become unaccessible, and so on.

All in all a fairly good experience.

My first negative review for a game. Very buggy game that should not be released from early access. 

Got to the point where without much spoilers, you had to use the climbing equipment the game soft locked itself after saving on python island. My friend was the host and he saved the game but there was a caiman nearby yet he was able to save ( by right this should not happen when there are enemy combatants around ). In the end he froze there and the caiman attacked him yet he was not dead. He restarted and he respawned out of bounds in the game. A place where you could see half the map was missing. And when i joined back the game i was back to square one. That is 10 hours worth of effort gone. This game is buggy as hell and i don't know how it made it out of early access. 

Another thing to add but unrelated to the bugs is why does the blood effects look like pastel color. It literally looks like pink water and the effect is so bland and minimal it doesn't make it feel realistic, which I assume is what the game is trying to go for. Just for that reason the game should be given a Teen rating if not for the amount of cuss words included.

Exactly what I wanted in survival game play. Story is quite interesting, and really left me feeling a big mixed bag of emotions in the end, which was very thought provoking. I did not expect such a compelling story out of this. I truly am shaken up.

Looking very forward to getting 100% in this game. I haven't completed every single achievement yet, but I already miss it and want more.

Survival in Green Hell is a relentless challenge. Players must manage hunger, hydration, and health while battling hostile wildlife and the environment. The realism can be punishing, but it adds to the game's immersion. It's great game!

Definitely the most "hardcore" survival game I've played. Both stories are amazing and the base building in survival mode is fantastic. 

If you're on the fence and love survival games, go for it. This + Subnautica are the top solo experiences IMO.

This game is terrific. If you have no sense of adventure, get angry at easily at simple mechanics, tend to rush through games and then complain that there's no content, then this game isn't for you. The immersion of this game completely depends on your play style, your sense of adventure, your love for nature/forest environments and everything else that comes along with that. This is one of the greatest survival games I've ever played. Everything just makes sense about this game, and the story is interesting. There's tonnes of stuff you can do, and the amount of content this game has puts Sons of the Forest to complete shame. This game is terribly underrated
These devs can't manage a matching X and Y axis sensitivity? Settings with sliders, no numbers, no fine control, no settings ini? Unacceptable.
Love it great game, story and free roam

I've had a lot of fun playing Green Hell, 
The Good: 
Lots of possibilities when it comes to making your own base and it's easy to get immersed in this Green Hell.
I love the concept of trying to survive in the jungle.

The Bad:
The controls are pretty terrible and took some getting used to. 
The map in survival mode is small and there are currently only two - they both either could be larger, or there should be more open world maps available in survival mode. 
The character swearing is very repetitive, there should be an option to turn this off because this really is a cool game for my kid to watch as well.
More animals - if you're going to put monkey sound effects in the ambient environment of the map, then put monkeys in your game.

Overall:
All in all this game is still being regularly developed and it has a promising and frequently updated system with lots of possibilities. I think this game is worth trying and getting into. I've logged many more hours playing this game on PS5 as well and can say even though there are things that frustrate me about this game, i love it, and I plain and simply just want more from it.
Extremely addicting! very well thought out.

Day 1: After falling off of a cliff my bf and I start our wonderful journey into the jungle, we run into some naked dudes
           We Die.
Day 2: We find a cliffside to build a small camp on, we sleep in our cozy new tents.
           My bf gets worms and dies.
Day 3: We try to find water. We don't know how to make fresh water. I drink from the river.
           I get parasites and die.
Day 4: We begin to build our base. My bf hears a growl in the distance.
           We get mauled by a jaguar and die.
Day 6: My bf starts to hallucinate, he begins to laugh uncontrollably even though the game is not making his character laugh. I am scared. This game is terrorizing us irl. He sees a naked man running toward him.
           He dies.
Day 7: After a quick glance at the wiki we finally understand how to drink clean water. I pick up an alive poison dart frog.
           Immediately dead.
Day 8: We drink ayahuasca. I finally understand what it is like to feel high. After I'm done hallucinating we run into the new open woods.
           I run into a jaguar and die.
Day 9: We run into an illegal gold mine and try to understand spanish.
           I am dying internally.
Day 15: We run into an illegal drug factory and read sad love letters.
           I am crying inside.
Day 20: We find a plane. I realize that the main character is an awful person.
Day 21: We get to the end of the game. We get the wrong ending. I feel like shit.
           I die to the naked man.

Really fun game. It can be very punishing if you  are unprepared or not careful. You’ll learn what it means to be prepared by just playing the game and getting all the diseases. But once you start to learn things about the game it is very rewarding. I used to just find it fun starting new games and trying to get settled with resources and then ending the game because late game was quite boring and tedious. But with the transportation and storage update it really has improved the end game. I can see myself putting in a lot more hours now and staying in one world and building bases throughout the map. The game is in a really good state right now and honestly should have been like this on release or at least a year after release so it is a bit crazy that it’s taken them this long to get the game to the point that it is but I’m still happy about the much needed updates. I’d imagine new players would be faced with an even steeper learning curve now but the wiki is really good and there is a lot of content about the game to help. I also think it’s really good value for money considering what you get.
love it

This game is a challenge! There's a lot of things to deal with such as leeches, parasites, predators, starvation, dehydration, tribal warriors, passing out, etc. This game is the "hardest" survival game, although once you start getting more experienced it's not so hard

This is an amazing game made whole from the beginning, no essential DLC's required, and even free content added after launch.
This game really simulates the struggles of surviving in the jungle. I hope more game developers will learn from Creepy Jar. Simply well done!

Buggy to the point of discouraging me and my friends from playing. Connecting to the host often meant getting a major injury, losing progress or just straight up dying. Often, when the host is not close, food will not cook on the campfire. Having a pen with animals mean you are gonna swim in excrement and your animals are gonna die of an unsanitary environment. After 20 hours into our save, the save file got completely corrupted. The concept of the game is good, but the bugs in multiplayer makes this effectively a singleplayer game only.

At first, I really enjoyed the game. Sadly, there were some issues along the way. First one is some in game mechanics that don't make sense. Example, you can only find cords but technically, we could also make them without needing to find a specific tree and wait that it's ready to be used. There is also issues going on with animal keeping where they die and come back even though we stopped trying to keep them alive along the way.

Those minor issues weren't too bad in my opinion. It was fun, lots of structures to make, storywise, there was something going on. Sadly, my friends and I couldn't continue to know about the story since the save got corrupted for no reasons whatsoever beside being at the research camp in multiplayer.

Unfortunately, the game is riddled with various severity of bugs, full of design flaws and ultimately, after loosing close to 20h or gameplay due to a save file corruption: I won't play that game again.

amazing game packed full of story and mystery play and enjoy

In my opinion this is the best survival game on steam, hands down. 

The crafting system is engaging.

The nutrition system keeps you on your toes along with the many various ailments you may encounter. 

The game punishes players for being unprepared and for not being cautious. 

The player seems well balanced against the hostiles.  

EDIT: disregard all that praise, this game has been abandoned. I can't believe this game is still unfinished in 2023.

Pros:

1: The game is fun
2: The map is huge
3: Base building is fun
4: The story is good
5: Survival is realistic

Cons:

1: Stamina- Jake has the stamina of an asthmatic chain smoker. He can barely run 100m without losing his breath
2: Planks- It is highly unrealistic that one log only gives one plank. You could easily get between 4-6 planks per log.
3: Jake gets stuck on everything- If you walk over a log or rock you will get stuck and cannot move.
4: Jake does not jump properly- If you pres w and jump over something, you will jump backwards
5: Disappearing items- If you chop down a tree there is a high chance your items will fall through the map. Over the years on console and PC I have probably lost more than 200 logs and long sticks due to this.
6: Broken drops- If you carry logs or long sticks or bamboo and drop them, the game will drop the items but you will still be in the carrying animation so you have to open your inventory to fix it.
7: Sled is broken- If you let go of the sled there is a chance the sled will let go but will still be "attached" to your body and you cannot get rid of it. The only way to get rid of it is to either break it or reload the save.
8: There is no console commands- I like to build massive mega bases and it takes way to long to gather all the resources to build it. The debug console was removes for some reason. Whenever I beat games I like to mess around and spawn stuff in. Bring back debug mode
9: No creative mode- It will be extremely fun to have a proper creative mode where you can customise the seasons, enemies that spawn, instant build, no build restrictions and so on
10: Wet season is too short
11: Natives are too annoying- You cant smelt one piece of ore without natives spawning inside your base
12: Jake takes too much fall damage- If you fall off a slight hill you take damage
13: Crashes- Although rare, the game does crash for no reason
14: Building in water- Building in water is the biggest pain in the ass. I have my cursor on the build but it says 'Drink water' and not build.
15: Building- I have my cursor on the build but it refuses to build or one atom of another build is on the build so it "blocks" me from completing the build
16: Picking up stuff- I have my cursor on something I want to pick up but it either wont let me pick it up or it picks up something else I am not looking at
17: Inventory- If you sort or move items then they will disappear. They are still there but become invisible. Reopening the inventory makes them visible again.

I will add more to this list if I find anything else

The game can be enjoyable when there are no bugs. Bugs are so common that it ruins the experience. The game is still worth buying but be prepared for a ton of bugs and glitches. I do love this game but sometimes the bugs are just too annoying.

This is the most accurate survival game I've played to date(to the point that it can be annoying). It took me about 2 hours to understand what all the little icons meant and what fixes them but once you figure that out it becomes much more fun. The story is pretty baffling and you take a ton of drugs to figure it out, so that's neat. Base building isn't that important unfortunately and all you really need is just a ton of little save houses here and there. Its about a 20-30 hour game story wise and pretty unique in a lot ways, so if you enjoy survival games its a must.

P.S. Rattlesnakes are the most annoying enemy (use tobacco to cure the venom)

(9/22/23)
Updating my review a bit now that I've played the SoA part of the game. The original story mode is better but SoA has some new neat mechanics. The problem is that it uses those mechanics over and over and over again to the point you are just checking boxes. The original story feels like a story with survival aspects where SoA feels like a survival with some sprinkles of story. 

Don't get me wrong, the survival aspect of this game is awesome but the story in SoA was a bit too slow paced imo. SoA took me 50+ hours to complete compared to the ~20 of the original story. So yes there is more content there but unfortunately it's a lot of the same. You have to cross the map a decent amount for objectives but at the same time it penalizes you for running. I know it's supposed to be realistic but I wish it was done in a less tedious way.

TL;DR, the original story is awesome and I'd definitely recommend it. As for SoA, I'd only recommend playing it if you really really enjoy the survival part of the game as it can get a bit tedious.

P.S. Rattlesnakes are still annoying but scorpions are are also the worst (eat the white and green lily leaf plant to fix the venom/poison stuff)

early game is more punishing than challenging, suggest using a mod to allow any time save games.  If you don't know how to zurg through and craft a building that allows an in game save point - you could lose all of your game progression REPEATEDLY.  It isn't a learning challenge, its a game wipe if you don't get to this stage before dying.  You've been warned, play without a save game mod at your own risk of punting your computer or begging steam for a refund.

Got through the first day in story mode: 

Day 2: Made a nice camp and a bow and went out hunting. Came back to two tribal dudes having destroyed my whole camp. Killed them, butchered them and started tending to my wounds. Got my base up and running again. Nice fire cozy and went to sleep. 

Day 3: Woke up, ate and drank to go out and look at a trap I had set up 50 meters from the camp. Got mauled by a Leopard but killed it. Couldnt find the plant to make bandages. Died from my wounds next to my campfire.

10/10

First of all, The graphics aren't so bad. Looks good for the most part. Performance is not so great unless, you've dumped $1,000 into a good video card, and the same for a new CPU. I've managed to maintain a 34 fps max in game so, I'm OK with that for now. 

Being in a tropical climate, it rains a lot. When time to sleep, be sure you have a belly full of food and drink a gallon of water, in spite of the parasites it contains or, you'll die. If not, you wake up starving to death anyway and will die if you can't find a bushel basket full of some sort of unknown mushroom to eat. Then there's the parasites, again. Every five minutes, you have to stop and take a breath, eat, find something to drink or, that frkn watch beeps until you do. As for the character, movement is like some whimpy little boy that's always had mommy doing everything for him. Carry me mommy, I'm tired. Chop a tree, 3-5 hits he's wore slap out, needs to take a break and a nap. Come upon a log in your path, try to jump over it, it's like trying to scale the Empire State Building as if, it were some great effort to clear 12 inches of ground. Craft a hatchet with a stick and a stone, when it breaks, the character acts out as if that was supposed to be made out of cold-rolled steel and wasn't supposed to happen. If I could ever stop picking leeches off of me, I might get something done. Be sure to save your game every 5 minutes of progress. Have managed to survive 9 days now, no deaths and this is in Walk in the Park mode. 


On another note, be careful what you post, the developer is ban happy. 
Got a 30 day ban without a warning for telling someone they were ignorant. Steam rules are a warning, x3. Evidently, the developer doesn't like corrective criticism about his game, either. Reminds me of other fly-by-night developers. When they start banning people first off, they can always expect a negative review, especially from me. Take my money but, I can't have my say. However, with all this bullsh!t digital online purchasing, they can get away with it, more-so, by hiding behind the Internet & Steam.

The co-op save system is broken - be prepared to lose hours upon hours of save data - and the devs will do nothing to fix it seeing as they have known about it since 2020 at the very least. Fun game, even better with friends - but if your saves don't work what is the point of even playing?? Due to this game breaking glitch I can just simply not recommend this.

I will start by saying I have been enjoying playing this game co-op with friends. I really enjoy the challenges this game presents. I would give it a positive review except this issue is just to big to ignore. I will change my review if this issue ever gets fixed but considering the game has been out for 4 years and this is still in the game I don't see that happening. 

If you build walls on ground level, animals and tribal guys can walk straight through like they don't even exist making all the effort that went into building them pointless. 
If you build spikes along the wall, they will do one of two things- path to a spot like a shut door where you don't have spikes and just walk through there or destroy any structures you have outside of the walls (like mud brick crafters) and then proceed to walk through the shut door. They are not ghosts. They should not be walking straight through a solid object. 

I actually can't believe how many positive reviews this has with such a major bug like this just being ignored for so long.

Green Hell has the most rational and clever crafting system of any game on the market. Both the survival mode and story mode of the game are exceptional. The story mode uses very entertaining and interactive animation sequences, similar to those in Far Cry games, to advance the story line. The story itself is brilliantly surprising and compelling. I'd love to see this game made into a movie. Survival mode has an intense level of realism that keeps the game compelling. I was very VERY happy with this purchase.
awesome

The game-play is interesting and the air of suspense, gathering, crafting is  good from a theory perspective. The authors tried to incorporate the dangers of living in a jungle with many minor survival options. These are well thought of.

The irritating part of this game is Crafting even minor elements. Though it was supposed to be a fun game crafting, but in turn its the most irritating and painful part of the game.
- The MAP function is real bad with nothing but just an image. I know that you are trying to put the reality into play, but its really a pain in the a**.
- half of the game is just made to gather stuff and to tend to our injuries, as the inventory size is quite small, cant put logs, big-sticks or leafs in the backpack.
- To construct a house with 5 platforms, i be required to run about carrying single items to the location it took almost 2-3 days(in game) to craft a mini house.
- This game seems to of survival, but in the current context, its irritating.
- cant even carry a stone - as it was named big stone but its a size less than a football. Cant even put it in the inventory. I wanted to play it like a game not like me actually going into a Amazon rain forest.
- As of now, the game is not at all in a playable state.

(for those who wish to enjoy crafting in s Single player scenario);
-After getting fedup with the game mechanics, i though of using some cheats/debugs in single player. But the debug mode has been removed. And cheats wont function properly at all.

Overall, i assume that this game will be helpful for those who want to train virtually so that they can plan  trip to any rain forest . 
For any other people who would to just do hours of gathering, improper crafting just to keep saving your character and not able to enjoy the story line, this might be for you.
If anyone who doesn't fall under these categories, I bet this game isn't for you, Try Icarus, Valheim, SCUM, ARK etc, which have betterr mechanics than this one, although most of the fetures could be nearly same, but  not this one.

Green Hell: A Grueling Yet Rewarding Survival Challenge

I wholeheartedly recommend Green Hell if you have a penchant for realistic survival games. In my opinion, it stands as one of the best in its genre to date. Although, I have to admit, those pesky snakes lurking around every corner seem determined to make my life miserable.

If you're into this sort of challenging gameplay, Green Hell is a must-try. It'll test your limits in various situations, and you might even have to endure a few deaths to get things right. However, the sense of accomplishment in the end is truly worth it.

Thankfully, the Developers whom I once upon a time was fortunate enough to speak with, are actively updating the game with new and improved content!

On my rating scale, Green Hell earns a solid 9.5/10. It's the kind of game where you can get killed by a snake, respawn, and get killed by it again – it's an adventure that leaves you with lasting memories.

'edit' The snakes have given me PTSD.
one of the best survival games with genuine threats that might be encountered in the jungle

Moreover, the story is actually pretty good. If you love games with rich in story PLUS can play with friends, this is a good game for you!

It's a very good walking simulator game with great story telling under the disguise of hardcore survival genre,once you get past at the first few day where you fighting for survival, this game becomes easy, dull often tedious. 
The early game difficulty is mainly base around the really fast day/night cycle and you have to maintain your 3 different hungry meters and your health, sure it is "hardcore" but after a few days of playing it, it becomes dull quite easily and these is actually no reason to build a new base besides getting to the main objectives easier even though the building system in this game is indeed serviceable but pretty limited, you can still get creative but in the end of the day you are still building them for just increasing you hunger meters easier and save your game. 
And the AI in this game is really dumb as hell, they often stuck in one spot or wall climbing like it's Skyrim, I really don't like fighting animals or the natives in this game and these's almost no way to avoid that part of the game.
That being said, I really do like the unique story telling, great soundtracks and the voice actor sounds like they belong in the spot, delivers the script well.
If you want a different taste in the modern sandbox survival genre in these days I'd recommend Green Hell for you but if you are looking for a highly replayable hardcore sandbox experience like The Forest series then I think it'd disappointed you once you reach mid or end game.

VERY COOL and awesome fun game with friends! but do keep in mind it is VERY difficult, it's pretty much real life and you have to keep in mind you can die by ANYTHING, this is a very difficult game, but if you like the challenge and story games aswell as survival games this is for you! 9/10 for me.

Genuinely may be the worst game i've ever touched.

Story is cliche and boring.
The voice acting is corny and over acted.
The tutorial is worthless and bloated with story, yeah because I went to survival game tutorial to sit here and listen to two morons who can't even pretend to be human.
The actual gameplay may well be decent but I got utterly bored of wandering around stumbling into deaths. 
The game pretends to be a very realistic survival simulator but as soon as you try to apply any form of common sense to a situation you are immediately stumped and have to go and check the wiki to find out that "Oh the only thing you can make a bottle out of in this entire rainforest is a coconut or a clay bottle which you would die of dehydration long before you can craft or a Bidon that only spawns in the story gamemodes" So an hour of stumbling around unsuccessfully looking for a palm tree with some coconuts in it where you have to constantly walk around staring at the sky, later you will walk onto a snake which will basically just kill you because the cure is some random fucking herb you can't find and you can't treat the wound because bandages are made of one specific kind of yellow leaf apparently. I'll let the NHS know that they're doing THAT wrong then.

SO eventually you give up and drink unsafe water. You get parasites, obviously.
I check my notebook "consume anti-parasitic herbs to cure this"
Yeah thanks notebook, what kind of herbs are those and where do i find them?
"Secret hehe"

So you have to go and consult the wiki because absolutely no effort to apply common sense or a decent tutorial is given to you so after about an hour you're just staring at the wiki going through page after page of random vegetation and where it all spawns.

Then you craft a stone blade and use the inspect feature to try and slit your own wrists with it but your braindead "dehydrate to death in a day, also I will literally just fucking die if I get bit by one snake" is too stupid to do even that right. 

Does our scientist who literally studies animals and plants all day know what a tourniquet is and how it may help in this venom situation? Apparently fucking not, it's like he deliberately elevates his heart rate so the venom kills him faster. Can't say I blame him because I'd want to kill myself if I played anymore of this game TOO.

All that said, I'm sure the game is fine but I don't have time to get a degree in biology just to play your mediocre Forest rip off.

I could literally get the exact same experience from the Forest or the Infected but I wouldn't have to read a wiki for 40 hours or pull a leach off my testicles every 15 steps.

Killed a poison dart frog on day 3 of survival, found out I could harvest the meat and cook it.
Cooked poison dart frog meat at the fire and proceeded to eat it.
Immediately after eating said cooked meat, Started Tripping balls and hallucinating and hearing voices in my head.  Spent the next week huddled in a cave next to my camp fire as the voices & hallucinations got the better of me trying to regain my sanity.
Finally regained my sanity and decided to venture out for food because tripping balls for a week tends to work up an appetite and iv only been drinking rain water for the past 5 days out of coconut shells.
A jaguar found me as I was scavenging for food and immediately killed me.

10/10 Poison dart frog meat was delicious.

At first glance, instant death from "whatever the cause" and loosing appetite, I was going to give up the game but once you delve further and discover more; every action you do becomes worth the effort.  I believe the game wants you to challenge for you to be a survival with every action accountable.  Once you've mastered the survival skill then it becomes so much worth the play.  It's a yes from me.

I do recommend this game. It was quite frustrating for me in the beginning to figure everything out, but once I did, it was much more fun to play (especially after understanding the sanity/ghosts part – which is cool but was confusing). Also, devs release interesting updates from time to time, and it makes me want to keep exploring (otherwise playing this game would get a bit boring over time).

SoA has been a blast to play though and is just as well done. The replay ability is good especially with multiplayer, just survive and challenges. TWO THUMBS UP! It was money very well spent and would highly recommend!

Green Hell is a much better version of (Sons of) The Forest.
It is an actual jungle survival simulator, with fleshed out mechanics and an actual (interesting) plot.
Be advised that this is a tough game: You're supposed to keep track of 4 basic needs of your character, while avoiding constant danger and making your way through the jungle.
If you enjoy hard-earned victories, this is a fun game and it stays fresh, at least for the whole main campaign.
