This game doesn't need a wiki to be played.

If you let yourself get immersed, if you get grabbed by the game and not spoiled you can live a true heart taking story where the reality catchs you as soon as it becomes more of a fact than a dream. Just get ready to deal with it and stay comprehensive, accept the fate :P

*So I came to change my review from "recommended" to "not" and I'll keep my original review.

Beautifully designed environment and awesome atmosphere. But all the sounds are low quality and badly panned (or sourced idk what's the term of it ~ the distance and the animal's sound never matches. You are walking away and it's still like in your head) and I'm using $40-ish headphones only. 

Also the survival system is a bit weird, eating tons of meat but dying because of a banana? (or any fruit). Drinking tons of water from a pot and 10 secs later~ oh, so thirsty. Still fun tho, I'm enjoying with customized settings: food consumption is low and all other hostile things are on. That way feel better-balanced actually, since it's literally hard to find a stone in a forest and takes too much time to gather stuff in that SMALL sized map. While you are getting hungry so quickly in normal consumption speed. Combat - easy because your are fighting with a lords of bugs. But I still keep them (you can remove if you want) it's fun to run away.
---

The map is pretty small for a sandbox and crafting is super easy and limited. You are in a circle of troubles (besides hostile attacks) leeches - worms - parasites etc. Some of them appears with an interaction and some of them randomly. It slows you down often, that way you can think the map is big actually.

+ Beautiful forest to walk around
+ Good atmosphere

- Bad ambiance
- Animal noises
- Environmental sounds
- Combat bugs
- Enemy bugs
- Co-op bugs (like: many times happened that only one of you can see the enemy. it's not the low sanity effect, it's the real enemy)

And again, animal noises are the worst, makes the game really boring when you hear those low quality mp3 sound files. 

Waste of money. 

All the scores you see 8/10 is probably a marketing.

2/10

This game has a steep learning curve, almost like real survival. If you don't die a dozen different ways the first few tries, you aren't playing right. There's danger around every corner and every injury is a potential death sentence. Surviving for a month feels like a major accomplishment. I would definitely recommend starting with the hostile tribes and predators turned off, so you can get a handle on the basics of survival. Even without animals and people hunting you, there's still plenty of challenge to surviving.

Green Hell is a very special game.  It is one of the best of balancing realism with rewarding difficulty while still being a game that is fun to play.  Difficulty and game play is highly customization allowing newer plays to gain experience and learn the mechanics while giving long time players plenty of changeling options.  My wife and I personally do not like horror or spooky games so play with the sanity off.  Without that level of customization to the play experience I don't know if I would even own this game. 
The Developer has been releasing free after free after free update and I love coming back to the game to start a new play through and set new goals or challenges like "This play-through I want to make a tree house base!" 
You get a lot of value out of this game and its immersive design will make you feel like you have just spent a grueling week or two surviving in the Green Hell of the amazon.

This game should be a lesson to other developers on how to make a game challenging without making it unfair. There are dozens of ways you can die or become hindered, but there are also ways in which you can be prepared for each of those challenges. Crafting is delightful and the gameplay loop is solid. You don't just need to eat, you need a balanced diet or your energy and survivability will suffer. You can't avoid danger, it always finds you. But you can be prepared. What other game makes you wash up before you eat or you might get sick?

Ranked:
1. The Forest.

As a huge fan of The Forest, I was really looking forward to Sons of the Forest, but was disappointed with its current unfinished state. So I ended up trying Green Hell and I'm so glad I did. This game offers a more brutal  experience and is focused on wilderness survival, which can be frustrating at times but is also extremely rewarding. Nature is going to be your biggest enemy and establishing a proper encampment feels like a real accomplishment. The world is large and filled with places to explore and things to discover. However, I recommend playing with the easiest combat, nutrient needs, and stamina difficulty settings. Otherwise combat becomes unfair, you can't walk more than a few hundred meters in a day, and you need to eat and drink way more than is realistic.

This game and its devs are awesome. It's ideal for coop since for a single player it would be way to grindy. Once you get to know the flow of the game and its core mechanics it opens up for a great survival experience.

When I saw this game on sale I thought It'd be a good opportunity to give it a go and see what It was like. Boy was I wrong, after seeing so many positive & ''very positive'' reviews I decided to give this game a try and i played a total of 4hrs with a friend of mine. This game does give you the challenging & realistic feel of surviving in the amazon but I found there too be not much explained, the tutorial barely helps you and only shows you how to create a fire, collect dry fibres, sticks & rocks. Other than that you are completely on your on when you decide to either choose story or survival mode, the health or ''hunger'' system in this game is so frustrating as it depletes so rapidly you are consistently either looking for water, bananas, fish or nuts. and by the time you get all your bars full or half-way full your character needs a 8hr sleep every 5-10minutes, after playing this game for even 4 hours I did not like it one bit & wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

I just quit the game to leave this review. First of all the game claims to be open world but an open world typically doesn't make you feel like you're in an endless maze of canyons that force you to follow certain paths. This game does exactly that and it makes navigating so unpleasant because you use your map and gps coordinates to get somewhere only to discover it's blocked by a massive canyon wall that you'll have to walk 2342356234242 miles around to get over which throws you way off course. 

 The spawning of animals, predators and venomous everythings are so predictable due to dated triggers. Example, if you walk into a cave with a scorpion blocking the bath and kill it, you can bet everytime you return the scorpion will be there. If you crawl into a creek bed you can bet you're about to get attacked by a jaguar because well he always spawns when you enter the creek bed. It's so obvious it's tacky. 

 The day night cycle is WAYY too fast. 1 hour is 60 seconds. So about every 10 minutes or so, you're in darkness. This is yet another poor design. Predators like the Jaguar have no sense of self preservation nor do they even flinch when you thrust spears into them, they just keep attacking like robots till you and/or them die.

Snakes are OVERKILL OVERKILL OVERKILL!!!!! You can't take 10 steps without running into a Q#$Q$$#%W#%$@Q$#v SNAKE! It's ridiculous. The game is hard but not in a realistic way. It's hard in an arcade game kind of way. The developers are not good designers and should make mobile PC games instead, maybe something along the lines of candy crush.

Seriously the game could be so great but they decided to half ass it in so many ways.

I got attacked by a jaguar one night and jumped up on top of my shelter because I didn't have any weapons. After it left and I was clear to save, I did only to realize my last save was multiple days ago. My current save was way ahead in terms of progression and base building I couldn't go back. Then began a groundhog-day-like loop. I would load in, in the middle of the night with gaping wounds on both arms and one leg, already infected. I would try to sleep until I had enough health or just rush straight to get food and healing supplies, nearly starved and ducking hallucinations. No matter what I tried I would die. Try it again, get farther, die. I ran this loop probably upwards of twenty times, angry and dying on repeat. By the time I had enough food, healing supplies, and sleep to survive and save, I was way better at the game and even though only one rotation was saved that death loop, spring-boarded me through my progression. 

TLDR: You will die. It will be fun.

Everything else in the game is fantastic, I just would quite enjoy more of a persistent struggle living out in the rainforest, and not thrive so easily.

member how hard the souls series was? 
ok that  was easier... compared to surviving the first day in this game...
once you learn how to identify plants by the shape of their leaves, flowers, etc.
it gets slightly easier...

protips for starters, you can break down stones you find into smaller stones.
you can harvest fiber from plants such as palm leaves and others so you can start your fire.
you can harvest magots from spoiled meat in your backpack, if fruit spoils, save it, you can use it as fertilizer later, you can craft armor right from the start using stick, plantain leaf and rope.
everything has a use, if you need ashes you can harvest it from charcoal, if you get sick, eat the charcoal. 

you will alway want to have bandages, magots, ants and water in your backpack. 
eat the mushroom, they are good for you, except the large brown one. 
food is actually very abundant in the jungle, disease and wounds are terrible...

navigation is kind of easy, your watch has a gps it will show you the coordinates, you match it with the ones from the map and you will known exactly where you are. if you build a base somewhere, write its coordinates down in some paper and you will be fine going out to explore

pay attention to the sounds of nature, if you hear a rattle, jump back, if you hear a small slow roar, stop and look around, and if you see its eyes aim to the head.
This game makes you appreciate the smallest things in life again. A true masterpiece and a celebration to hardcore games.

Would definitely recommend for anyone looking for a jungle survival experience with a great story! There is also a slightly different non-story game mode for 2nd-3rd-4th play-throughs. Come back for more as they keep adding (free!) support and features to enrich the experience :)

Pro-Tip:  The first thing you should make is a bow and arrow. Bow = 1x long stick and 1x rope.  Arrows = x2 bird feathers and x1 stick each. Look for dead birds on then ground and harvest them for feathers. Once you have that the combat is trivial. This game has a "hold breath" mechanic with Left-Shift for keyboard. You can basically beat all combat with the tried and true method of "shoot them in the face."

I played this back in 2020 with friends and we kinda got tired of it quick. I've revisited this in August 2023 because I never played the single player story. People tend to spurn this game because its steep starting learning curve because it does not hold your hand. Gotta google that shit or trial-and-error to figure it out. I found out most things via the latter because I hate myself. But once you figure it out,  combat and survival is trivial, the only challenge is knowing [i]where the fuck you are on the map.[/i]

I will say though,  the story turned out to be something I completely didn't expect, and was actually quite pleased with it. Once you finish it,  you'll soon realize why the game is aptly named "Green Hell."

This is definitely one of the better survival games out there, but it is not for everyone. To describe this game in simple terms, its like The Forest in a rainforest and you have more things to manage besides blood, basic hunger, and water. The most recognizable thing this game has is its hunger system, where the universal "hunger" is split into 3 macro-nutrients you have to manage (fats, protein, and carbs). You will have to balance the core needs with other systems such as sleep, dirtiness, and inspection of your arms and legs for special conditions such as rashes.

For a more detailed description, this game emphasizes the difficulty with surviving in a rain-forest, especially on the harder difficulties. At first, you might be solely focusing on food and hydration but as you get better you start to understand the game loop and get more time to explore and build. It can feel rewarding as your game experience starts to allow you to master the unforgiving jungle. If the above facts may sound daunting, they can be mastered, but it may not be for everyone as you have manage more than other survival games. 

Another note is that the combat is pretty janky. Even if combat is a small part of the game, you will face it and it was probably my largest grievance. It was annoying whenever I had to fight something as hits didn't have good feedback, worsened by some enemies hitting you back right after you hit them, giving you conditions you have to manage post fight. There are also hazards that only YOU can be affected by that enemies can run by scot free which feels cheap as only you are subject to the difficulties with the environment. 

Even if the combat is annoying, there is still a lot to enjoy about this game and survival game enthusiasts should definitely give this game a try

10/10 recommend!

So, I am glad to say that the game creators are keeping things alive, and things are getting better.  They have added more content and another story mode which give you a lot more to do.  In other words, you don't feel like you are just running to the end of the map to get out of the jungle.  

The construction aspect is still temperamental, like most of these games, they just can't seem to get it right.  There is no option, that I know of, to move things once they are built, even small things.  Very weird.  

Items fit oddly into your inventory compared to boxes and depending on how you flip them they will shrink in size, very weird.  Meat weighs 3 pounds in some cases, yet, it won't fill you in one sitting.  Very weird.  All this is just stuff you have to get used to but adds a little lack of realism which cause a learning curve.  I find myself asking, what is making me so heavy--often.  

The new tree house is a massive building project--kind of fun--kind of annoying.  It is very nice once you have it all done and situated.  Eager to see the new things they are developing.  

The fact that you can hold Alt to pick up a whole stack of things is nice, but these little tips not being clear in the game-play is a little frustrating.  Same goes for holding L-Shift to steady your bow, though it is clearly an option in the controls of your settings screen.  

I find the new two two-handed axe-wielding beast of a man a fun mini-boss addition, very nice.  Guy can take more than 10 arrows.  Insane!  

Rocks are still super spastic, there will be four large stones, you pick one up but when you return there are none.  

Carrying the crying child across the entire map solo is the first thing that makes me think it really is a Green Hell.  Better to have two or more people so you can look at your map and kill critters.  

Creature glowing a weird green, buggy.

Drinking from a large bowel will sometimes allow you to drink/eat twice sometimes not.  Harvesting a log will rarely give you two planks, another odd, with no explanation, event I wish I could control.

The text overlapping on item stats has not been corrected.

They force you to use long sticks when building some structures when the sticks are obviously small sticks. 

Overall the game has increased from about 60 hours to more than 200 hours of things to do.  The replay-ability is high, especially with a friend.  The map is extensive.  The discovery of game content has greatly increased.  I recommend a decent computer with a quality display.  The game runs all right on a lesser machine but the graphics suffer extremely.

I remember the first moments in the game. Great graphics, beautiful environment.

As I progressed with the story, I waited with bated breath to see how it would unfold, how I would find out what actually happened in that first preview.

My enthusiasm gradually waned. The story started out great and I couldn't wait and it ended up being a complete bore. Nothing was explained and it felt artificial and unfinished. Spirits of Amazonia (SoA) is much more interesting, interacting with villagers and completing tasks for them. But at the moment I'm at the second village, I don't enjoy the game in general, carrying screaming children on my shoulders already really annoys me, and the only thing I enjoy is shooting some natives in the head when I meet one. For how phenomenal a start it has, the rest of the game is incredibly boring. And you can't help but compare it to the series Lost. Both have an interesting beginning, full of mysteries, the viewer/player waits for how it will be explained, but it is not explained, gradually it loses all fun and after finding out how it ends, the viewer/player asks himself why he wasted his time.

Of course, those looking for a challenge in the game are in the right place. Multiplayer is especially challenging. My experience with multiplayer is as a player who was not hosting, but rather joining a hosting player.

Every time I logged out of the treehouse in multiplayer, I fell to the ground after logging in. The wound I inflicted immediately became infected, and only because I logged out with full HP and we had enough first aid items in the base did I not die because we are playing on a harder difficulty. In the case of logging out at the water base, on the other hand, I fell into the water. The piranhas injured 3 of my 4 limbs and due to the initial disorientation I almost did not find my way out. That's why I always had to log off on the shore or on the ground under a tree.

In SoA multiplayer, it happened to us repeatedly that after placing all the materials on the piles of toxic waste, or when burning dead villagers, the structure was not completed and could not be lit. Fortunately, a lot of reputation among the villagers can be gained through legendaries, but if someone is trying to get achievements, they should do it in singleplayer, where this mechanic works without bugs.

In multiplayer, it repeatedly happened to me that my weapon disappeared from my hand. Even though the other player could see it in my hand, I couldn't, and when I hit the attack button, I was just punching. Since this happened to me repeatedly with the iron ax shortly after we made it, I lost 2 new iron axes.

When the non-hosting player disconnects before the hosting player, they lose all progress: skills, backpack items. As its progress is restored to the last inventory save point. Which can only be done if the hosting player shuts down the game first. Probably the only bug in the game that can be used to the advantage of the player, because if he saves his inventory when he has, for example, 1 piece of iron armor in his backpack, he puts it in the chest and logs out-logs in, he has it in his backpack again and in this chest will also remain. If the player repeats this 3 times, he can turn 1 piece of armor into complete armor within a few seconds. It also works with things that are only in the game 1x. E.g. metal water bottle, metal kettle... Ropes can be duplicated in the same way, for example: put 10 ropes in the rack, rlg and the player has 10 ropes in the backpack again. If the base is being built on the water, where a lot of ropes are needed, this way the construction can progress very quickly. In the same way, it is possible to make a complete armadillo armor for several players from just 1 armadillo. Despite the possibility of making the game much easier, it's still a bug and it would be good if it was fixed.

After finishing the game with the "good ending" the whole game crashed and it was impossible to finish the game even with the "bad ending" for the achievement. It didn't even help to start a new game and run it, neither in singleplayer nor in multiplayer. Whenever the bad ending preview ends, the game crashes instead of the credits. I haven't tried reinstalling the game yet, because with how many bugs there are in this game, I'm worried about losing saved positions in singleplayer and saved inventory in multiplayer.

And unfortunately, I could continue like this for a while, because there are really many bugs in multiplayer. I only mentioned the ones that I personally found most annoying.

Unfortunately, the game also has a number of moments that are at least thought-provoking.

When shooting a bow, arrows are drawn randomly from different stacks. So if he started the combat with 15 arrows and ended with 5, it happens that he has 5 arrows divided into 3 stacks instead of 1.
The story doesn't connect well. In the first story, Jake Higgins confides in a broken voice to Mia that he was attacked by a native, whom he killed in self-defense. Meanwhile, in SoA, which takes place before the events of the story, he kills natives by the dozen and has no problem with it. So I don't understand why it was such a traumatic experience for him in the story when he could have been called the Native Slayer at the time.

And again, I could go on with examples.

Despite all of that, I have to admit that I ended up liking the game. Although the story is worth nothing, and the player who skips it does not lose anything. In the game, I spent tens of hours in survival mode building breathtaking tree houses, forts on water. By growing crops, crafting and hunting.

The beautiful environment is definitely worth exploring at least in tourist mode. I really like the crafting system and find it sophisticated and undemanding. In addition, if the player remembers the recipe, even at skill 1, he can make a bow and go into a real fight. I like the different ways of processing meat and bones, tubers and even fruit. Cooking soups and decoctions, drying and smoking meat. I always thoroughly enjoyed all of this when I returned from a longer adventure.

Some of the funniest moments include when a native broke 1 piece of my armor in a duel. I processed the native and made a spare part from his bones. I admit it's a little morbid, but in my defense - he started it.

Even though I'm planning on taking a longer break now, I'm still looking forward to getting back into SoA and finishing it up. And maybe one day I'll be pleasantly surprised that the story gets a little better.

Green Hell is an excellent survival game characterized by its brutal trial and error difficulty, compelling and truly amazing story, and amazing gameplay mechanics. The game is fairly difficult for new players, you will fail a lot, die a lot, and game shit your pants at the first sight of a spider. 

Pros
1- Amazing gameplay
2- Amazing story
3- Decent difficulty 
4- Good amount of playtime
5- A lot to explore and discover 
6- Game keeps you focused through the need to manage your macro-elements, random big cat attacks, and fucking snakes (fuck them I've died over 20 times because I got bit by a fucking snake and couldn't find a bloody bandage)
Cons
1- Bad performance
2- Short story if you rush through it 
3- Gets too easy after a while
4- A certain weapon breaks the combat by making it pathetically easy.

All in all I wish I could play this game for the first time again

I have played and/or beaten a multitude of survival style games, Minecraft, The Forest, V Rising, Rust, and so on. I went into this game with my wife and did a coop play from start to finish. The punishing survival style of this game I was all for. The concept and general premise are great. The Jungle and graphics/sound design are very well done. So why am I not willing to recommend this game. Because it is abandon wear and truly the pinnacle of requiring you to look stuff up online. Without a wiki, this game is unplayable. 

Tutorial. The tutorial area of the game needs major rework. While it teaches you the basics it fails to mention an important part of the game. Armor. Everything craft able is done by combining things in your backpack similar to The Forest. Now when I say everything is craft able with items from your backpack I mean EVERYTHING (except the bow). So how the hell, without looking it up online, is a player expected to figure out you must use a banana leaf (which can not be placed in your inventory and must be hand carried) be the MAIN component of armor? This is never shown (such as your find an armor piece using the leaf), this is never told (such as a note which there are plenty of), nor is this ever hinted at (such as in the radio conversations). This is figured out by looking on the wiki. While the game can be done without armor it is an unbearable slog to do so. 

The bugs. You leave meat on a drying rack, you travel far away. You come back and it is gone. The gold sack was literally taken out of my inventory by my wife when she picked it up from the table that it spawns at. Water containers and bones never de-spawn, but a multitude of other things important things constantly do. Get poisoned, fix poison, sometimes health continues to drain after full removal. Kill jaguar, die from wounds, 20 second run back to death location from respawn location, jaguar body de-spawned. Character randomly stops being able to look around with mouse movement input, can still do everything but move and look around. The biggest one of them all, The cherry on top, in CO-OP YOU CANT ALWAYS GET THE ALTERNATIVE ENDING DUE TO A GAME BREAKING BUG THAT HAS BE DOCUMENTED SINCE 2020. 

Invisible walls. This game has more invisible walls and barriers than Destiny 1 and 2. 

Death. Death is simple. You die. You respawn at your last rest locations you go back to your body and pick things up. Typically lose anywhere between 1/3 to 3/4 of your inventory items. Not sure if this is some weird glitch tied to de-spawning or intended, so for now I will consider it intended design. However, instead of dropping a backpack with the remaining items, you blow up like a Minecraft character that just fell 40 blocks and hit the ground too hard. You then must manually pick up the items one by one in a god-awful slog of time wasting. Why? You already punished the player with the item loss, why also punish them with the slog of picking back up every item piece by piece. Just drop a backpack since you know, THE GAMES INVETORY IS ONE.

Backpack/inventory. This game has a resident evil 4 inventory system which I love! You can place and space out items however you want while also being able to stack small amounts of items. Good system. Gets ruined by the fact that you also have an over encumbrance system. WHY!? Most games have ether or. Not both. Fallout, Baulders Gate and Skyrim you have unlimited inventory, but you have an encumbrance system. That’s fine. Minecraft, Resident Evil, and Rust. You have limited inventory spaces. That is fine. This game, you have both for no reason. If you wanted the player to carry limited amount of items make the back pack smaller. If you wanted the player to only carry so much make the encumbrance system, but not a mix of the two. The auto sorting of this game when you pick an item up the takes up a new section of your backpack is almost designed to be place in the most efficient placement possible. 

The building. Let’s say you want to build a simple 4x4 block style base. You will be grinding out the resources of the next hour to do so. Let’s say you want to place a “ghost build” of your design before you start placing resources into it. You can’t even place the ghost build until the whole area is cleared out. Can you cut down ANY tree for your materials, no you must only cut trees that don’t have vines on them. Is there snapping so you can build the hut base uniformly? No. and the problem is when you drop items they will sometimes fall in between the cracks of your building never to be retrievable again unless you destroy your floor/frame. Basic features found in a multitude of other games is just flat out missing here. And most annoying, you can only carry a total of 5 tools on you at any given time (which is fine), BUT THE GAME HAS NO BUILDABLE TOOL RACK TO STORE EXTRAS. You also CAN NOT place tools in crafted chest. You just have to drop it on the floor and hope it doesn’t de-spawn when you come back.

The combat. Not bad. Just use the bow and learn to headshot to win. Gets very repetitive after many hours.
If this game was released today in this current state as an early access, I would totally be happy with it and be stoked at the future to come with this games potential. This would be an easy recommendation from me. However, this is considered a completed product and thus has failed to meet an even minimum bar of what other games do far better in the survival craft/builder genre. 

TLDR: 4/10 Below average at best, bad at worst. CO-OP Ending Broken

Remember all those survival shows where the adventurers live in harmony with nature, catching fish barehanded, and building cozy huts? Well, Green Hell is NOT one of those shows! If you want to experience the jungle while being chased by an angry jaguar, eaten alive by mosquitos, and struggling to find food like a lost puppy, then this game is your dream come true!

Let me tell you, it's no walk in the park - it's more like a sprint through the Amazon rainforest chased by a stampede of tapirs. Within the first ten minutes, I was already a buffet for all the insects in the world. I mean, mosquitoes have their own personal GPS just to find me! I don't know what they put in that bug spray, but I'm convinced it's flavored like a five-star gourmet meal for bugs.

Now, building a shelter may sound easy, but in Green Hell, I have the architectural skills of a drunken sloth. My first hut looked like it was designed by a toddler with Lego blocks. If anything, it probably gave the jaguars a good laugh before they pounced on me. But hey, who needs walls when the jungle critters are such fantastic decorators?

I attempted fishing, thinking it'd be as easy as catching Pokémon in a pond. But boy, was I wrong! The piranhas in this game are on a strict diet of survivalists, and they go for my fingers like they're high-end sushi. I'm pretty sure the piranha family has my picture hanging in their living room with the caption: "Don't mess with this guy, he's a walking buffet!"

Then, there are the locals – the indigenous tribe. They probably think I'm the comic relief in their jungle soap opera. I tried communicating with them, but my pantomime skills are on par with a mime in a tornado. We had a staring contest, and let's just say I blinked first, and they weren't impressed!

Despite my endless misadventures, I can't help but love Green Hell. The graphics are so immersive that I can practically smell the damp earth and hear the sounds of the jungle around me. I feel like Bear Grylls on steroids, even though my survival skills are more "Blair Witch Project" than "Survivor Man."

Jokes aside, Green Hell is a challenging and thrilling survival experience that's worth every mosquito bite and comedic death. It's like stepping into the shoes of a true jungle explorer, where even drinking water can be a life-or-death situation. Just make sure you've got a sense of humor, or you'll go crazy faster than a toucan on Red Bull!

So, if you're ready for a game that tests your wits, survival skills, and comedic talents all at once, venture into Green Hell and join the ranks of jungle explorers with stories that'd make Indiana Jones jealous!

I was on the verge of leaving a positive review, but I realized that 90% of the things I had to say about this game are negative. I then looked through the forum for those concerns, and it appears the devs DGAF about player frustrations because the point is for this game to be "hell".

Well, I enjoy challenge as much as the next guy... but there's a fine line between "challenging the player" and "intentionally neglecting basic QOL features to make the player suffer".

[b]The Good:[/b]
The game does indeed present you with a compelling scenario of solo wilderness survival in the trackless depths of the Amazon. Note that I said "compelling", not "realistic" or "fun". The story of the main quest is a psychological horror thriller which is actually really well-written, well-voiced and avoids most of the tired tropes of the genre.

[b]The Meh:[/b]
The difficulty curve is paradoxically difficult to learn but easy to master. At the start of the game, you have zero explanation of what to do or how things work - death is guaranteed. For instance, it took like five IRL hours to figure out that you can get small stones by "harvesting" big stones, which greatly inflated the early grind.

The inverted difficulty curve is largely because schematics for weapons/tools/buildings are locked until you pick one up, craft it by accident or - in the case of buildings - see an example firsthand. Schematics for armor - which is INCREDIBLY important - do not EVER get unlocked until you craft it blindly (or, more likely, read the wiki). 

And when you do craft stuff, expect it to fall apart VERY quickly. I spent IRL hours smelting, then crafting "metal" armor and weapons... the best in the game... only to watch them degrade to nothing in a day or two of light use. Insult to injury: I'm pretty sure the metal spear is inferior to the "tribal spear" you get for free for killing one of an endlessly-spawning horde of howling natives.

But, once you figure out the basics, the game becomes trivial and the only challenge is fighting the annoying game mechanics, not actually surviving. For instance, i just ran into a patrol of 8 hostile natives and proceeded to headshot each one with a handcrafted survival bow without taking a single hit.

Hunting is functional, but completely unrealistic. The best way to hunt is by getting headshots, which any IRL hunter will tell you is breathtakingly stupid. Real hunters try to take down an animal with one hit to the heart, liver or lungs; failing that, they will follow the blood trail. In Green Hell, you either headshot 'em in one hit or kiss that animal goodbye, as it runs away far faster than you to die somewhere you'll likely never find (or just glitch out of the map) with NO blood trail. Hunting is marginally better with a spear than a bow, since even a non-headshot with a spear will kill an animal before they make it 10 yards.

[b]The Bad[/b]
Surviving parasites, disease, hostile natives, hungry jaguars... none of that is difficult once you figure the game out. What's "difficult" is exploring the map (and the game doesn't even GIVE you a map until you randomly stumble across it) in the TWENTY FOUR EFFING MINUTES of daylight you have per day.

The ridiculous speed of the abstracted day/night cycle forces the player to rush through EVERYTHING. But, if you run everywhere, you're liable to get stung by an emperor scorpion... which is extremely difficult to see, but you can (somehow) hear. And, no matter what armor you're wearing, that sting will magically go right through it.

AND that will basically end your day RIGHT THEN AND THERE, because the fever caused by the sting will quickly sap your strength until you pass out... then wake up on the floor in the dark with blowfly larvae implanted in every limb. If you don't use one bone needle (gained by "harvesting" bones) to remove the larva (one needle each), you will quickly go insane. Then, if you don't bandage those four ghetto Amazonian surgery wounds immediately, they're going to get infected.

The first time I had an infected wound, i had no clue what to do with it because I didn't learn until later, checking on the wiki, that the only solution is waiting until meat in your inventory spoils so you can "harvest" maggots to eat the infected flesh. So wherever you go exploring, make sure you take a handful of maggots with you LOL FML I'M NOT KIDDING.

So, by not hearing the "scratchy scratch scratch" scorpion sound and immediately leaping backwards, you lose an entire day of exploring, 4 bone needles, 4 bandages, most of your food and ALL of your clean water. Did I mention that ALL the water in the game is infected with parasites and you can't boil water in a metal canteen? "Fun"!

Then you have to limp back to base... where there's even odds that a patrol of natives will be wantonly destroying all your stuff. Also they will spawn inside your walls, behind your traps. The devs knew this is an issue for years and have finally admitted it, but don't know how to fix it. Also I would have preferred fewer, but more dangerous natives over endless hordes of Amazonian orcs.

Oh yeah, and my mild annoyance with animal behavior turns to EXTREME annoyance when it comes to alligators. Unlike IRL, Green Hell alligators are extremely slow and go down after two arrows to the head. They do not rush out of the water to insta-kill you, which would be fairly reasonable. They see you and then leisurely chase you at turtle-speed across the entire map until you kill it. You'll hear a loud HISS, then five minutes later chilling in your base hear a CHOMP as a chunk of your health bar disappears.

Because there are rarely hints of where to go or what to do, the only way to progress the game is to search miles and miles of trackless jungle one inch at a time, 24 MINUTES at  a stretch. And after about half an iRL hour of exploring, you'll need to trek all the way back to your base to reload on 3 different types of food and 3 different types of bandages.

Once you stumble across everything in the story by process of elimination - which takes about 20 hours if you don't spend much time having fun (i.e. building a barbie dreamhouse in a giant brazil nut tree and getting a pet capybara) - there is a mystery at the end that - if you even know it exists - allows you a path to unlock the good ending.

Oh yeah and in order to find the "good ending" mystery machine, you need to ignore the main path in the final area and swim off randomly into the river for REASONS. This is made more obnoxious by the fact that the MAP for the final area is in the same location as the mystery machine, so the only way to find it is by exploring blindly.

I admit that the solution for the super spoiler good ending mystery machine is kind of clever, but all the clues that hint at the solution are hours away from each other... or you can just look it up on the wiki. I briefly considered solving the mystery with my own very tired, very annoyed brain... and promptly chose the latter.

The expansion, Spirits of Amazonia, doubles down on all the things that were annoying about the main quest. Instead of one needle in a haystack at one time, you have to find like 3 dozen in the FIRST MAP (checking the wiki, the actual number of not-on-your map waypoints is OVER FORTY THREE FUCK ME).

I was dutifully exploring the SOB on the "Hard" difficulty and had discovered about half of the quest points in the starting map of SOA before being inspired to write this review... and I think I'm done for the foreseeable future. Maybe I'll do another run on Medium later. Or maybe I'll never touch this thing again. IDK honestly.

I wish I had played this game sooner. The rumors of how difficult it is kept me away for awhile, but I'm so glad I decided to give it a try. I didn't know anything going into it, and I'm glad I stayed away from reading too much. The learning curve is really something, but if you watch survival shows you'll get the hang of it pretty quickly. Some recipes that you intuitively know you should be able to make will require looking something up, but I didn't feel like that broke immersion. Additionally, while this game can be a little grindy, it somehow manages to make that okay in ways that other games have never been able to before. The way the story unfolds is incredibly clever and I can't recommend this game enough. 

p.s. This game costs half the price of games I usually only get 60 hours of as a near-completionist. The only games I've spent more time playing are in the vein of The Witcher, RDR2, Fallout, etc, so the fact that this was accomplished by an Indy developer is incredible. Easily up there with Frostpunk in terms of must-play Indy games.

So I have had Green Hell since January of 2021. In the beginning it was nearly impossible. You rub against a bush, get ants, get infected, die. You walk by the river, catch a frog, die. You get slightly hungry, die.
It was amazing.
Fast forward and they tweak a few things {like ants are in hills now not random ass bushes}, include new builds, new story lines, PETS!, and new weapons.
STILL AMAZING.
This is by far one of the hardest, most frustrating, realistic survival games I've ever played. 
It is not easy. You will die. You will die again. And you will die a few more times, but you will love it.

My greatest complaint by far is the scripting and overall predictability of the environment. The map is always the same; therefore, once you learn where some of the basic structures are, all sense of discovery goes out the window. Unless you're intent is to master base building, why would I ever learn how to do anything myself when I can use pre-existing infrastructure in my favorite ruined bungalow? If I go to certain locations, scripted predator or native encounters will ALWAYS occur. With this foreknowledge, at just 4 hours in, the incredible sense of immersion breaks down into gamified strategy. This game needs a semi-randomized map, maybe in the form of a deck of tiles that gets shuffled and blindly distributed into a grid instead of proc gen.

I'm going to stick it out and see if Green Hell can capture me now or after a major update. I love the details in this game: the research, the component-oriented base building system, the backpack's organization, the body inspection and macroelements, and even the ability to name unknown plants. There's so much in the nuance of this game that give me hope for its future, but I can't recommend it if I feel like my sense of discovery is threatened this early on.

This game is a must-have for fans of good stories and survival games or for anyone looking to dive into the richness of the South American rainforest.

TLDR: Green Hell is an difficult and amazing survival game with an excellent story

An amazing gritty survival experience. Green Hell is well-named, you are in a rainforest/jungle environment and there are things waiting to kill you at every turn. But everything is appropriately difficult, and as you learn your surroundings you'll find that helpful resources are also all around you. 
The survival gameplay is intuitive and immersive. The macro-nutrient system is great at encouraging a varied or well planned diet. Most dangerous animals will signal their presence in some way (this game needs audio for cues). The crafting (and building) is good, with the ability to experiment out recipes or learning them. The cherry on top of all of what I said is how involved and communicative the dev team has been. I have had this game for a while and it's been great to see all the improvements to the game 
Another key element is the story. I had such a great time playing through the story of this game, and was hooked throughout. After finishing the story I have so many thoughts but I don't want to spoil anything, but I highly recommend that you go through it yourself.

Green Hel is a gripping and intense survival game that thrusts players into the heart of the Amazon rainforest. From the moment you step foot into this lush and treacherous landscape, you are engulfed in a world that tests your will to survive like never before. As you navigate the dense foliage, avoid dangerous predators, and battle the elements, Green Hell provides an immersive and heart-pounding experience that keeps players hooked.

One of the most captivating aspects of Green Hell is its stunning graphics and attention to detail. The environment is beautifully rendered, with the dense vegetation, wildlife, and weather effects adding a sense of realism that is both mesmerizing and intimidating. The dynamic day-night cycle and ever-changing weather conditions add an extra layer of challenge, constantly keeping players on their toes.

Survival in Green Hell is no easy feat, and the game excels at capturing the essence of the struggle for existence in a harsh and unforgiving environment. The need to manage hunger, thirst, body temperature, and injuries provides a deep level of immersion, as players must carefully plan their actions and make difficult decisions to stay alive.

The crafting system in Green Hell is robust and well-designed. It allows players to create tools, weapons, and shelter using resources found in the wild. The emphasis on realism is evident here, as the crafting recipes are logical and make sense in the context of survival. This aspect adds depth to the gameplay and encourages exploration to discover new resources and blueprints.

However, while the survival mechanics are incredibly engaging, they can also be quite punishing. Green Hell doesn't hold your hand, and mistakes often come with severe consequences. Some players might find the difficulty level to be a bit overwhelming, especially for those new to the survival genre.

Furthermore, the storyline, while present, may feel a bit lacking in comparison to other survival games. The focus here is more on the player's personal journey and the challenges they face in the Amazon rather than a grand narrative. For some, this could be a downside, but others might appreciate the freedom to create their own adventure.

Multiplayer mode is a welcome addition to Green Hell, allowing players to tackle the jungle together or face off against each other. This mode adds an extra layer of enjoyment and replayability, as teaming up with friends can make survival a more manageable, yet still thrilling, experience.

In conclusion, Green Hell is an intense and visually stunning survival game that truly puts players to the test. It's a must-play for fans of the genre and those seeking a challenging and immersive adventure in the heart of one of the world's most dangerous and beautiful environments. While the difficulty level and minimal narrative might not appeal to everyone, the sense of accomplishment that comes with surviving the perils of Green Hell is undeniably gratifying. So, grab your machete and embark on this exhilarating journey into nature's fury!

I've never really played any survival style games before playing Green Hell, but I can wholeheartedly say that this game sits at almost number 1 for my favorite game of all time. The level of realism is very impressive, the combat is rather unforgiving, and the sheer difficulty... I can say without a doubt that this is definitely a must play for anyone who likes the survival genre and enjoys a challenge. Even at the "lowest" difficulty, one wrong move or one false step could spell your end... Fighting off predators such as pumas, jaguars, caiman, snakes, scorpions, etc. are but one aspect of the challenge. You have to sleep, forage for food, keep hydrated (might want to boil that water first...), build a shelter, etc. You can get leeches, you can contract food poisoning, just about ANYTHING can end your life. There is most certainly a steep learning curve involved, however, once you figure out what's safe and what's not, this game is truly a unique experience. I would give it a solid 8.5/10. Remember, coconuts and bananas are your friends. Trust me.

Green Hell is a fantastic survival experience with an exemplary sense of place and peril. Creepy Jar have really nailed the feeling of loneliness and despair that true isolation would lead to and married this to some well balanced challenges and a refreshingly user friendly approach. The range of ways to play are really welcome and should ensure that even those players who may be turned off by the rigours of hunger and thirst mechanics can enjoy the immersive jungle experience. This may not be a welcoming jungle, but there’s plenty of fun.

I read a lot about this game before I bought it. After playing through the original campaign (not the additional campaign  "Spirits of Amazonia") and some single / multiplayer survival games, my opinion is simple: a really great game.

positiv:
- the story is long enough to keep you busy but not that long that you think you never get through
- graphics and sound match the area you play in very good
- given some choices of making the game easy, medium or even hard and harder you find the perfect match for everyone
- the complexity to craft tools, bandages and generate food variation from plants and wildlife is great
- you do not know much when you start the game about tools etc. -> try and error gives a lot of fun and, sometimes, you think "how often do I have to fail for one solution?" - a great experience
- single player games can be transferred into a multiplayer coop game -> interesting solution
- there are still additions in gameplay coming (e.g. "transportation update")

negativ:
no negative impressions so far - I still find a lot of fun in wandering through the jungle while experimenting with all materials I find in order to craft or cook new stuff / meals.

While making a survival game, developers have to make sure that they're not crossing the very tiny line and that is making a game frustrating or not. 

First of all i gotta say that the game feels just right about forest, you have to act like how you would if you were to be in a jungle like that in real life. You don't feel comfortable while roaming around trying to find things, you don't know what's lying beneath you and that makes you avoid getting into big bushes, long grasses etc. without getting paranoid (shorts ? really ? in a jungle like that ?). Creatures make you scared as well (like how they would in real life) for example if you were to see a steelseries-rgb-keyboard looking like thing irl your inner voice would tell you to avoid that thing because that thing is poisonous bro telling you. So for the ''nature'' part of the game i can easily say that they've made a good job and to be honest if there was a neutral option i would go for it instead of ''not recommended''.

BUT

For the survival part of it big big nos. HOW ON EARTH CAN SOMEONE GET HUNGRY EVERY FUCKING 5.39×10⁻⁴⁴ SECONDS BRO. YOU BREATHE IN YOU GET HUNGRY, YOU BREATHE OUT YOU GET HUNGRY, YOU REMEMBERED SOMETHING YOU GET HUNGRY, YOU EAT YOU GET HUNGRY WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU MADE OF BRO ???? The game's logic thinks that every time you blink you get hungry but no developers, that's not how a real human body works. ''🤓👆 but by blinking your body consumes 8.234x10⁻⁴ calories''  NO BRO FUCK OFF IT DOESN'T. So imagine if you were an obese who weighs 1890 LBS you eat like what 30 meals a day ? THIS MOTHER FUCKER EATS 10x MORE THAN A PERSON WHO IS AS HEAVY AS A FAMILY TRUCK. I JUST DON'T GET IT BRO WHAT THE FUCK WERE YOU GUYS THINKING WHILE MAKING THIS STUPID ASS MECHANIC. 

I really want to go further in this game like i really wonder what's gonna happen between this couple but i can not bro. I don't feel like i'm surviving it's just feels so frustrating. In addition to everything the optimization is not so good, i'm barely getting 80 FPS with RTX 3060 x i5-12400f i've tried to adjust some settings but they didn't do much. So at the end of the day it's up to you whether giving it a try or not.

As someone who just completed the main story and spirits of the amazonia, I can confidently say that this game is infinitely better with friends when who fuck around, explore, and don't worry about the story. Completing the game is the second rarest achievement, with the rarest achievement being to unlock all the achievements because it involves completing the story and spending more time in the game than I feel like is possible. 
From homing capybaras, killing them because you forgot to clean their poop, to running across the rainforest desperately trying to figure out how tf all the maps connect, this game is the most half-hazard, difficult, yet hilarious survival game I have ever played. 
Surviving the day to day is extremely difficult to learn even on normal mode, but no matter how prepared and comfortable you are in the rain forest you can still get cucked by a random jaguar (unless you headshot them because bows and arrows are busted). 
Would I recommend the game? yes
Would I recommend the story/spirits of amazonia? hell no, (unless you like tripping on acid) I completed it and all it does by the end is have you run for 40 minutes to the other side of the jungle through multiple very specific access points using the most convoluted map I've ever seen in a game.
Why cant you mark the map?? Why doesn't our MC tape them together?? WE HAVE A PENCIL WHY CANT WE EDIT THE MAP TO MARK BASES OR POINTS OF INTEREST?? 
In conclusion, this game sucks you in because you feel like you're nothing if you don't complete the game, I found myself telling myself that I didn't care about finishing the game because I spent hours simply doing fetch quests, but god damn it I needed to see the end just so I could sleep at night.

Green Hell is a wonderful survival game as long as you aren't spoiling yourself. Which I won't for you.

The difficulty, challenge, stress and ultimately joy you experience with this game comes from knowing nothing and learning as you fail to survive. 

Not knowing how to safely consume water. 
Being ignorant of the flora and the effects various plants have on your health and body. 
Not knowing what animals are a threat, where they linger and how they hunt. 
Not knowing how to engage the hostile natives. 
Not knowing how and where to procure sources of food. 
Not knowing where you are and where you need to go to survive and make progress. 
Not knowing how to craft and use things that make your survival possible. 
Not knowing how to balance all these elements together under the constant pressure of keeping yourself hydrated, sated and healthy. 

You are likely to step from one puddle of filth into the next until you are an unstoppable snowball of disease and deficits. 
It made me greatly appreciate the fact that I get to eat and drink safe food and water every day. Because eating that strange mushroom you have never seen before and puking out the last few nutrients and liquids in your body in a desperate attempt to stay alive is about as foolhardy as running through a jungle with a freshly gashing wound.
Inversely this means that once you know the listed things above, the game becomes quite trivial. I played it immediately on the highest difficulty without perma-death to be able to enjoy the humiliation and suffering on my first playthrough. Doing a no death run on my second was extremely easy and I was essentially set after an hour and spent another four on excessive paranoia. The game unfortunately is only balanced for the start. Later on it is almost impossible to die and certain aspects and items you can use and or procure are massively overpowered. I wish they had introduced more threats, gave you less powerful tools and encouraged you to go out into hazardous areas to procure valuable resources.

The building system is something I also found quite punitive. Something it has in common with The Forest but it is a spoiler.
[spoiler] You have a fairly extensive amount of buildings and connections but the combination of it being incredibly time intensive as every piece you build takes a massive amount of manual labor and resource gathering combined with the fact that hostiles can and will destroy everything you build unless you build on trees or water leads to me feeling extremely discouraged from building anything. It is much more satisfying to build bare minimum bases all over the place and hop between them as you are progressing in a somewhat linear fashion for the story than try and settle down anywhere for more than a few days.
I saw absolutely zero reason to play the survival mode after the story mode. [/spoiler]]

Some of the later story locations feel like one and done areas and overall I think the game has problems with balance and direction. It doesn't work as a survival game on its own and it doesn't really have much meat as a story driven game and it takes some survival aspects very seriously while neglecting some completely. Which is fine. It is still a fun game to move about and figure out. I think my biggest disappointment lies with the weak item balancing as most of the stuff you can craft is essentially the same with differences so minor, the higher tiers are just not worth the effort. You can either spent 3 hours making the highest tier gear that won't break for probably your entire playthrough or you can occasionally spend 2 minutes making things out of dirt and sticks that has the same function but will break a few times. The one or two extra chops a low tier axe needs to fell a tree just don't weigh against the scrounging and processing time of quality resources and significant extra weight to carry. I'd choose the extra five kilos of food and water. Unless for some reason you want to spend weeks in multiplayer building excessive mega bases. There aren't enough different items to speak of personal customization but the few in the game barely differentiate between each other and I found ultimately only lighter weight matters so I can keep more crucial resources always at hand.

My conclusion is that is is a wonderful one and done blind playthrough struggle to success with several challenge modes and extra DLC campaign but I don't think I would enjoy it in multiplayer beyond watching a mate die to their own stupidity.
Ahh. the performance is pretty choppy. Lowering settings and resolution didn't do much. But if you're expecting ambitious indie survival games to have good technical performance you probably wouldn't make it in a jungle.

It's like The Forest on steroids, but with more bugs and less cannibals. You'll have to survive in the Amazon rainforest using real-life survival skills, such as making fire, building shelters, hunting animals, and treating wounds. You'll also have to deal with tropical diseases, wild animals, and a mysterious tribe that paints their faces with skulls. Oh, and did I mention that you're alone and have no idea why you're there? Sounds fun, right? Well, not really. Green Hell is a hard and unforgiving game that will test your patience and sanity. It's not for the faint of heart or the casual gamer. It's more complicated and detailed than The Forest, which I still prefer because it's more simple and straightforward. Green Hell is a good game, but it can be stressful and frustrating at times. It's not like SCUM, which is basically a life simulator that makes you wonder why you're playing a game instead of living your life. But it's close. Overall, I like Green Hell and I recommend it to anyone who likes survival games and doesn't mind suffering a bit. (8/10)

Green Hell offers an intense and immersive survival adventure set in the lush Amazon rainforest. With realistic mechanics and stunning visuals, it throws you into a constant battle for survival. From managing your needs to facing wildlife and hostile tribes, the challenges are both thrilling and rewarding. So, i love survival sandbox games with a whole crafting system. I loved Rust, Sons of the Forest, Subnautica, Raft, Valheim. (I know all those dont quite match the *EXACT* cat. but all good nonetheless)

But what stopped me form loving this game, even though I have lived in the Amazon for eight years, was the constant feeling that the character you play as was such a wimp. His dialogue with Mia (his S.O.) is full of him whining almost. Some of it be warranted, but it seems his idea of exploring the jungle was an easy task and every challenge he faces proves him wrong and he made me feel like is a wuss just walking, like walking was too much of a challenge. 

Along with him being a wimp, you (the player) are running out of nutrients/hydration way too quickly in the early stages of game. You are constantly bombarded with rashes and leeches, with can be cured quickly if you got the right tools/healing items, but it happens so often I cant enjoy the beginning of the game.

To me, the beginning stages of any game like Green Hell, Sons of the Forest, Subnautica, are the most fun. The exploring, learning the crafting system, what goes with what and where to find  stuff; all that is the joy i love. But Green Hell just did not do it for me.

AND WHY CANT I FIND ROCKS AS OFTEN AS I SHOULD, the amazon jungle, river beds are bountiful with rocks and sticks, I grew up in Barcelos, Amazonas, Brazil, and often traveling in and out of villages along the Rio Negro and there are rocks everywhere, so whyyyyyyyyyyy are there not as a much for Christ's sake? lol

In conclusion, great game idea. Very harsh as it should be, but the dude whines too much, drains nutrients too fast, and very little rocks. 

Its beautiful, but i just cant get into it. If I were you, id give it a shot, to each their own; just not the same flavor as the above mentioned games.

This game is designed to make your life a hell, pun intended, as you play.  It has multiple delaying and irritating aspects that, until you learn to overcome them, will piss you off over and over.  You think you know how to play a survival, and YOU DO!!  All of those skills transfer here, but you have to learn how the devs want you to survive.  How they want you to get hurt and then how to deal with it.

Once you do so, survival becomes much much easier.  The story is very clever and interesting.  The mechanics are fun and you can lose yourself very pleasantly into just living like a king in the jungle.

Tips:
* Build armor, out of anything, to wear at all times.  Dealing with the wounds is more bothersome than wearing even stupid armor that will prevent them.
* Figure out how to treat fevers quickly (meds, shrooms, etc).
* Carry 4 honey bandages and 2 venom badges and replace them as soon as you use one.
* Carry a bone and a bowl at all times, bone soup FTW.

I enjoyed this game a lot, once my hunting partner convinced me to stop being a wuss about all the infections, venom bites and irritants.

Green Hell is a great game because it delivers on what it promises. It's a survival crafting game. And it does that better than all competitors out there. Basebuilding is amazingly satisfying. Crafting is logical and cool. Survival is an actual challenge and offers soooo much more detail than every other survival game. You can get infections, lacerations, abrasions, fever, poison, vomiting, parasites, worms, rashes.. and you need to avoid and/or treat them all. Hygiene is important, you need to constantly check yourself for leeches, pay attention to scorpions, spiders and snakes.. You need to keep all your macronutrients like proteins, fats and carbohydrates up, make sure you get clean water and you need to explore the jungle and get to know it's plants, mushrooms and all the other things the jungle has to offer..

But don't expect it to be easy. Sometimes you can feel like there is nothing threatening you anymore, you get carless and a snake bites you. No problem.. you got anti-venom dressings to treat the wound. But then the poison gives you fever. Fever makes you thirsty. So you drink all of your water. But you feel okay and keep going. But then that snakebite gets infected. So you put maggots on the wound to eat off the infected flesh. But that raises your fever and all of the sudden you're thirsty again. Water is gone. So you drink some dirty river water. Even more fever. You decide to head home. But you are losing energy super fast now and pass out in the middle of the jungle. You wake up infested with worms. You remove them using Fishbones and treat the open wounds with ash-dressings. But you are so sick now that you keep passing out and you get infested with worms again and again. After half an hour you make it back to base and with the last percent of energy you make it into your hammock. Just to die because the infections killed you in your sleep.

Look i could go on. But if the above sounds like fun, you should buy this game.

This game is INSANE! Basically a survival game so difficult that it makes Dark Souls look like Hello Kitty Island Adventure, and enough detail to make Minecraft look like Pong. A lot of people will tell you to play without looking at guides, but those people are freaking masochists. Watch enough youtube tutorials to get the basics, I guarantee you will still have plenty to learn. The amount of attention to detail in this game is mindblowing. Not eating/sleeping doesn't just kill you outright like in other games, your character will slowly lose his mind and start tripping balls. Bug bites and cuts and scrapes don't just take health, they can become infected and cause you to lose sanity and slowly die. The detail in the survival mechanics is crazy too. Found a coconut? Don't just eat it, turn it into tools and bowls and use it to collect rainwater and carry stuff. Got some bones in your inventory? Well, it's your lucky day because you don't just have a bone: you have needles, fishing hooks, knives, and even soup. Everything in this game has multiple uses. Eat with dirty hands? Get a parasite. Like, dude... Just try it. Unless you're scared of failure. Then just go play Minecraft like the innocent little child you are. :) This game will punish even the most skilled gamers. Welcome to Green Hell (aptly named), where you were born to die!

i love the impressiveness of this survival craft game but that doesn't mean it isn't without it's flaws.

Namely, while the mechanics of saving do make sense from an immersion point of view, the lack of quick-save without the benefit of a shelter is a serious hindrance -  mostly because as beautiful and immersive as this game can be - it crashes A LOT. Like every game session A LOT. A LOT - A LOT. 

Despite being well above the necessary required specs, uninstalling and reinstalling several times, running integrity checks, it just crashes constantly which is really my only complaint about the game itself. It is a beautiful survival game with an intriguing Story Mode, a challenging follow-up Amazonia mode, and basic sandbox survival. 

So until the devs finally fix some of their stability issues, just get used to saving A LOT. Get used to making TONS of day camps that you can save at regularly, and get used to losing your progress A LOT. Did i mention the crashes? *sigh*

Other minor issues are that the Amazon is the most diverse bio-regions on the planet - 1 in every 10 animals species on the planet lives within the this region - but there is nowhere near the range of diversity here or even a modest range. It needs way more birds and way more creepy crawlies - way more snakes, bullets ants, other insect varieties, some giant otters would be great - and the most glaring omission - primates. It is absolutely bizarre that there aren't any primates in this game - no spider monkeys, capuchins, howlers, or tamarins to be found. You can hear them in the audio files, but they never make an appearance which is disappointing when you make a tree house to avoid the threats on the ground (ignoring the fact that real world jaguars are incredibly adept climbers.)

Easily one of the best survival games I have played so far. 

The game can be brutally unforgiving as you would want and expect for a fairly hardcore realistic survival game. But it also is one of the most relaxing games I have played as well, with a setting that just makes me zone out and lose hours very quickly. 

The game has nice immersive tropical jungle sounds and looks great, if not exactly next-gen on the graphics. The mechanics will make sense pretty fast if you have played a few survival games in the past. Of course some mechanics will annoy here and there, the fact you get tired so fast annoyed me, but overall it is all fun and I do recommend to NOT go searching things on YouTube etc and instead find things out for yourself. 

I see comparisons to The Forest and for my two cents, this is far more engaging and enjoyable overall. The setting really helps too and it really does feel like you are at the mercy of the humid tropical environment that in some ways rewards you with easy food but then will ruin you the next minute. 

My only regret is that I got this game when I was trying to get through Diablo IV and I have a pretty awesome base in Rust I need to maintain... as I have lost interest in those games and am addicted to this game. 

Highly recommended!

The ultimate survival-craft game, imo. It is quite daunting when you first start out because the game doesn't really hold your hand and everything is as dangerous at the start as it is at the end of the game. It takes maybe a couple hours to really get comfortable with your controls and the environment. After your first shelter is when things get a tad easier and you gain more confidence in surviving. 

The story is decent and intriguing. The graphics are amazing. The craft system is great. And now that it's in VR, I'm definitely gonna give it another play-through at some point.

If you're into the survival-craft genre, this one is a no-brainer. Just pick it up.

Start with nothing and no idea how to survive. Die a few times, and figure out the basics: you can eat this, you can't drink that. Die a few more times from parasites or disease, and discover which plants have medicinal properties (and pay for that knowledge with poisoning or death a few times). Survive longer, build weapons, defend yourself from enemies and predators.

Eventually, you know every food and water source, can crush every enemy, can build anything you need. You are more than a match for anything this inhospitable world might throw at you. Nature regards you with awe: you are the King of the Jungle.

Then step on a scorpion far from your camp. Your bandages with antivenom herbs are back at camp. Stumble around looking for the herb you need. Your fever rises.

Pass out on the forest floor. Wake up: parasitic worms hiding in the muddy ground have made a home under your skin. Use a bone fragment as a needle and dig them out. Pass out from the pain.

You wake up dangerously dehydrated, and your makeshift coconut canteen already drained. Making it home is your only hope. You start in the right direction, but the combination of the fever, the now infected scorpion sting, and the open sores from your impromptu worm surgery have weakened you so that you can only make it a few hundred yards in between passing out.

Your periodic unconsciousness gives more worms the opportunity to claim a new home. The fever rises. Dehydration worsens. Hunger racks your body. You hope the growl you heard was just a mouse, and not a jaguar hunting you. Irrelevant, as you pass out again.

You can make it, less than a mile to go. Medicine, food, water, fire, and rest all await you. Just a little further.

You stumble one last time, and fall to the ground. This time, you don't rise again. Throat parched, delirious with fever, body covered in wounds and sores. Your vision fades to black.

Scavengers consume your body, and the sun bleaches your bones. Nature looks with indifference over the few scattered, splintered bones that mark your final resting place.

Here lies the King.

It's a brutal survival game. There isn't much progression as far as gear and skills goes. Some minor stamina efficiency and damage increases on the skills. The real progression is in your own competence and knowledge of gathering and crafting to solve problems that arise. You're surrounded by over two dozen types of plants, but which one do you use for snake bites? Which one is for treating stomach parasites? Which mushrooms make you vomit, and which ones give you a helpful energy boost? Why did you build your first base so far away from a water source? Those kinds of things.

The resources are everywhere you turn, but knowing how and when to use them is where your "power" comes from. I recommend going in blind and researching solutions to problems as they come up. Try to discover common sense crafting combinations on your own, because the crafting really makes sense. Spending a few hours on the Wiki before starting would have killed the suspense and helpless panic that Green Hell does well. I enjoyed surrendering myself to that experience, learning, and trying again. If you're looking for ARK or Valheim in the rain forest, you're going to be disappointed. I'm about 20 hrs into survival mode, and it's still a constant struggle. So try to enjoy it for what it is.

The structure building system needs some tweaking, but it's the best building system I've used. Shoulder carry items are innovative, and assembling the raw materials in order gives a wonderful sense of immersion and accomplishment. Having the materials and having to jump around trying to find the perfect angle to be able to place them is annoying, especially when time is so crucial. If the placement system got fixed, Green Hell's building system could change the survival crafting genre.

Wow, what an absolute GEM! 
I wish I had checked this game out back when it was first dropped. 

If you love hardcore, punishing survival, you will love this.
If you love navigating by memory, land formations, and the sun and moon, and have an impeccable sense of direction, you will love this.
If you are on the spectrum (or aren't, even!) and enjoy repetitive tasks with a slower and more gradual progression, you will love this. 
If you loved building (or dreamed of building) multi-layered, massive tree-forts as a kid, you will love this.

Green Hell has a VERY special place in my heart. 
3 ish years ago, I was diagnosed with some lifelong and not-curable medical conditions. We also moved away from the town I'd lived 3/4's of my life. 
Being stuck in hospital beds and being mostly bedridden because of my health, I have YEARNED for the forest in my old town. 

Booting Green Hell is like being back in my childhood woods, except with no physical limitations! I can go ANYWHERE! 
Calling it "Hell" is so far from the truth because to me, Green Hell is a little slice of gaming Heaven. 

From the first time I played Minecraft, I fell in love with the survival genre. Starting from nothing and building your way up. It fit me like Cinderella's glass slipper! Being on the spectrum, I grew to find GREAT stress relief from the repetitive base-building mechanics in games like Minecraft, Eco, and No Man's Sky. 

But Green Hell scratches an itch I never knew I had! It takes that genre and pushes it to the very limit.

It's just man versus cold (or sweltering!), hard nature (with the occasional human attackers, of course). But the appeal of Green Hell, to me, is the realism! You learn how to start a fire with two sticks and some dry material. You fish with a spear. Waypoints? Fast travel? Forget it! You navigate by the sun, moon, and stars or by a real-life grid map (A1, B2, C3, etc.)

Green Hell doesn't throw zombies, ghosts, demons, or magic at you. It doesn't NEED to. You stepped on an anthill and you now need to find plants with antihistamine properties. Got a scratch? Better patch that up with a leaf bandage. Do you remember what plants are safe? And don't forget to wash it! You're thirsty? That river looks appealing, but you never know what parasites you might ingest without the proper treatment or filtration. 

You must balance your nutritional needs to avoid penalties. After all, everyone needs a balanced diet! Sure, you can get by with campfire steaks and boiled water, but you'll perform much better throwing some carbs and fatty nuts into the mix. 

Then, there's the graphics. Everything in the game is so beautifully detailed and varied! With my window open and the spring air blowing in, I can almost forget I'm playing a game! (This is on max settings, just for reference). 

[b]NOTE: [/b] As an aside, I run the game on a custom rig with 32G of RAM. I get an average of 75-100FPS on max settings. However, despite the game claiming a preferred 8G of RAM (4, minimum), I am unable to run it on my 12G laptop (it [u]technically[/u] runs, but at an astonishing -1 to 8 FPS on average) even at the lowest possible settings. This may be due to hardware failure with that machine, though, as it is an older machine. Yet, it did run Rimworld with 700 mods at a stable 75 FPS somehow recently, so...
If you wish to play on the best possible settings, I would highly recommend a dedicated gaming rig and 16G of RAM as a personal recommendation! 
However! If you have a lower-end or older machine, don't despair! The game is very reasonable to look at on even the lowest settings :)
It's certainly a visual treat if you're coming from games like Minecraft, Rimworld, Don't Starve, etc.

The sound is another stellar element in Green Hell! Not only is the track very cinematic and professional, but every sound is a clue to what may be lurking in the foliage. Play for long enough, and you will soon realize that your ears are your most valuable asset!

As an audiophile who composes music between health crises, I find Green Hell experimenting with the mechanics of sound [u]entirely[/u] fascinating! No previous games I have played have relied so heavily on audio as such an integral piece of game-play. Other than specific musically-themed, genres, that is. 
Kudos to the audio developers for Green Hell! 
I would love to see more audio-central survival games in the future!

Finally, Green Hell is a masterful example of storytelling! Not only do you have fun gameplay, lovely visuals, and amazing sound design, but you also get a complex story to boot! I have unfortunately not finished this story, so I can't comment how well it holds up near the end, but... It seems well-crafted this far, and the VA's are on POINT! 
Both Jake (main character) and Mia (wife of Jake) have very expressive voices. I adore their banter in the tutorial!

Personally, I think Green Hell could be selling for $60-$70 and still be worth every penny. But the fact that the developers have charged under $30 AND recently slashed the price? It shows just how much dedication the team has put into this game. Can't wait for more from Creepy Jar!

I admit, this is one of the more difficult survive games, and the learning curve can be steep. Don't give up, run the story and take your time.

Inventory management is a pain; you need to manage weight as well as how much you can carry. Weapon and combat is a little akward; some weapons are far more effective for combat, but less effective for anything else. Crafting can sometimes be frustrating; as most patterns are stored in your book, sometimes learning them or remembering what goes where can be a pain. Or trying to place certain items when building structures is very limiting sometimes.

However, in terms of overall gameplay, story or just having fun with friends this is by far one of the most fun games I've played that's survival, crafting and hunting.

Just watch out for the cats.
