I shouldn't have let recommendations trick me into buying this. It looked frustrating, and it is unbelievably frustrating. It's a huge step backward from the Forest. What were they thinking making three different types of food in the game?! Who cares about nutrition in a survival situation?! Nobody bothers with a balanced diet when you're trying to survive in the wilderness. Just get something in your gut that doesn't make you sick, and you're good.

But no, this game had to complicate every little thing so that you're constantly struggling to not die, to the extent that you can never actually play the game. This is the opposite of fun. It's punishment. I wish I hadn't made the mistake of giving the game 5 hours to try to give it a fair chance, when I clearly should have requested a refund after 2. Even worse, I wasted the full $25 on this, and now it looks like I'll never get it back. Buying this is my worst regret on Steam.

The ultimate survival game that's one part paradise, ten parts nightmare! Playing co-op with a friend? Double the trouble, my friend!

Just when you think you've got it all under control, bam! Something bites, something poisons, and when you least expect it, a wild creature or a native decides to crash the party.

It's like a never-ending episode of "Fear Factor" mixed with "Survivor." Get ready for a rollercoaster ride of unexpected surprises that'll make you question your life choices. Good luck, you're gonna need it!

It's a pretty steep learning curve. With little to guide you on survival, it's quite tough just to stay alive for 1 whole day at the start. I dropped the game when I first started. But with a few tries, and learning from some mistakes, it got a lot better.

One of the big selling points for me, also, is that it isn't crazy dark at nightfall. Yes, it's darker, but the moonlight is often bright enough for you to move around, so you're not totally screwed in the wee hours.

Would not recommend if you don't wanna spend a few hours just getting the hang of the game mechanic. Would recommend for a pretty decent survival game with an actual story that isn't too creepy (like the Forest).

Loved playing through green hell. In my opinion, the food/drink/leech/worm/insanity/venom all being "too frequent and too unforgivable" is right on point. I would expect to have these same issues if I were dropped in the middle of the rain forest. This forces you to think ahead, and be prepared for what can go wrong in the rest of the game. However, while I understand the need in story mode to not let us cut bigger trees to make bases, I would love to see this in survival mode, where we can clear land of bigger trees to just build and survive.

TL;DR Below.

Green Hell is a challenging and addictive open-world survival simulation set in the unforgiving Amazon jungle. With its immersive graphics and realistic survival mechanics, this game delivers a thrilling experience. Whether you're venturing into the wilderness alone or with friends, Green Hell tests your resilience and resourcefulness at every turn. Despite the frustrations and perils, it's a game that captivates and leaves a lasting impression.

My friend and I embarked on an expedition to find the elusive Amazon river, facing constant challenges and threats from predators. The gameplay was intense as we struggled to maintain our health and stay hydrated while navigating through the harsh environment. After an arduous journey, we finally discovered the river, but our depleted resources forced us to return to our base camp. However, tragedy struck when I was attacked by a cougar just as we were about to reach safety. Frustrated and exhausted, I unleashed my frustration on the cougar, relentlessly attacking it. Despite my futile attempts, I succumbed to the my injury, succumbing to the brutal reality of the jungle.

This moment of frustration and desperation perfectly captures the essence of Green Hell. It's a game that pushes you to your limits, constantly testing your survival skills and resilience. The immersive graphics bring the Amazon jungle to life, creating a visually stunning and atmospheric experience. The addictive gameplay keeps you engaged as you strive to overcome challenges and explore the vast and dangerous wilderness.

While Green Hell can be unforgiving and frustrating at times, it's these very aspects that make it such a captivating and memorable experience. The game's commitment to realism and survival mechanics adds depth and authenticity to the gameplay. It's a game that demands your attention and rewards your perseverance.

In conclusion, Green Hell is a must-play for fans of challenging survival simulations. Its nice graphics, addictive gameplay, and immersive experience make it a standout title in the genre. Despite the frustrations and perils that come with surviving in the uncharted Amazon jungle, Green Hell delivers an unforgettable adventure that will keep you coming back for more.

>> TL;DR <<
-Green Hell is a challenging and addictive open-world survival game set in the Amazon jungle.
-Immersive graphics and realistic survival mechanics enhance the gameplay experience.
-Despite frustrations and perils, the game captivates and leaves a lasting impression.
-A must-play for fans of challenging survival simulations.

Rating: 9/10

Absolutely worth every penny. Can’t wait to see where this game goes but definitely the best survival game I’ve played hands down.

For those wondering how different this game is from the forest, here's a perspective from someone who owns both games.

The main difference is that green hell isn't a power fantasy like the forest. In the forest you can blow up mutants and cannibals with molotovs and bombs. Or use fire arrows or flares to light enemies on fire. You can also upgrade you weapons with stuff like human teeth and bird feathers to give them a stat buff. Green hell is less combat focused. You get different tiers of tools and weapons, with stone being basic tier and metal being the best tier. That's about it, you can't blow up jaguars or natives with bombs or light them up with flares.

Green hell does have tribal native people, but they are much less of a nuisance. They don't spawn often and even if they do, they won't send waves of tribals near your location. They spawn, and if they spot you and you kill them all, it won't escalate any further like things do in the forest. There are only two main types of tribal people, archers and spearmen, no Virginia mutants or cave mutants. Again, it's less focused on combat.

Enemies in the forest are all human based. In green hell, there's more variety, you get jaguars, mountain lions, caiman and other hostile animals. And these animals don't fuck around and an unprepared encounter can easily spell death. A leaf bandage will do fine against scratches but it won't do anything against a deep jaguar laceration. It depends on if you have the knowledge to treat the laceration, better yet, kill any animals before they can even harm you. That said, it takes knowledge and skill, since you all you have are spears and bow/arrows, no molotovs or bombs.

Food and water is also much deeper in green hell. You have different nutrients such as proteins, fats and carbohydrates, so eating a piece of meat won't replenish your carbohydrates, it's less like the forest where you can likely survive off a single food source. And this mechanic isn't here just for the sake of variety, failing to satisfy any one of these nutrients can lead to reduced health and stamina, which can further affect your ability to survive.

This is a good segue into stamina. Stamina in green hell is also very important, it doesn't just affect your movement and combat. If your stamina and energy fall too low, you'll pass out on the spot. This will then lead to parasitic worms living underneath your skin, rapidly draining your sanity, which if left untreated can spell another death. So to stop yourself from passing out and getting worms, you need to sleep regularly on a bed. Stamina also dictates if you can light a fire, unlike the forest, you don't have a Bic lighter with infinite fuel, you need to start a fire with a drill firestarter, which uses a substantial amount of stamina and energy. If you don't have a fire, you can't purify and boil water, or cook any raw meat you have. Foods in green hell expire quickly if you don't cook or eat them.

Next is the sound design. Green hell's sound design doesn't just sound good, it is also very very crucial to survival. In the jungle, there's an overgrowth of bushes and trees, so it's very easy to miss any threats that are around you, such as rattlesnakes, giant ass spiders, tribal people and Jaguars. The only reliable way to identify these threats is by the distinct sound in which they make. Hear a snake rattling? Stop moving any closer and go around the source of the sound. Hear the low growl of a jaguar inching closer? Get ready for an encounter. Hear the singing of tribal people? Crouch down and avoid alerting them. Because more times than not, you won't be able to see these threats. In the forest, you can turn off sound completely and still stay alive, but in green hell, turning off sound will get yourself killed by various threats.

Lastly, I want to talk about difficulty. So far I've built up green hell to be this hardcore survival game, whether it is 100% realistic or not is still debatable with sometimes questionable AI patterns, but in its core, green hell is a hardcore survival game. That said, it's actually very customizable in its difficulty. Don't want to get bit by snakes and spiders? You can actually turn it off, don't want to deal with tribal people? You can turn it off as well. Don't want to deal with sanity, there's another option for that as well. It's much more customizable than the forest. You can go in blind and get killed over and over again. But like any hardcore game, it can be very rewarding. If you want to challenge yourself or just want to play like an Amazonian tourist, you can customize the difficulty to your own liking.

Hardcore survival game! If you're into that like I am, you're gonna love this one. Storyline is pretty dark, entertaining. Playing with a friend I'd say is best for story mode. Solo you would challenge yourself to survive in the Amazon for days on end. 

The mechanics are mostly logical, a few strange/new mechanics you'll get the hang of quickly that adds a refreshing feeling to this survival game. There's also the scary factor- Big cats and humans are also out to hunt you, and if your sanity drops low enough you'll surely feel like you're actually going insane. 

I'd say it's definitely worth the current price. The game looks gorgeous, and there's plenty of hours of fun and agony to be had. My PC is 6 years old atm, and my GTX 970 runs 70 FPS at the least at Medium graphics. 
Replayability would probably entice you challenging yourself in different ways/difficulties, but the map itself is not randomly generated so at some point you would've found all mysteries and dangers of the game. 

I'd give this a solid 8/10 in terms of money well spent.

The game does not respect you, your time or common sense. Be prepared for esoteric "real life" crafting recipes and constant tedium to accomplish anything. The developers confused "frustrating" and "realistic".

This is more disappointing than anticipating your paycheck to drop into your bank account, just to find out that you mis-calculated your auto pay date and it wont come until after the weekend and have to cancel going to the bar with your buddies because you're now both sad and poor. 

The crafting system makes about as much sense as stephen hawking trying to communicate through exclusively sign language
The game play itself is about as smooth as a fully grown male gorilla forcefully penetrating you
Combined with the ps2 graphics this game is about as smooth as a freshly sharpened knife

You can only save by gathering all sorts of materials to make some types of shelters and ONLY THEN you can save! I find it very discouraging and I would definitely prefer if it had autosave or even manual save option on the menu. Also something that would be very useful would be to be able to pin the materials you need for something you want to make until you have made it so that you don't go back to the notebook every single time to find what you need. 

In general it's an amazing game but I still feel like there are a few things to be improved like the above.

Interesting take on the survival genre, *very* difficult at the beginning. Honestly, this reminds me almost of early minecraft in the sense of "what do i do" moments. Bookmark the wiki before you even buy the game.

If you can accept that this game will give you few hints at the start, you're going to enjoy this game. I have never seen a game that can entertain me for 8 hours with such a small segment of the map, I've only gone as far as the first abandoned village and even that has been a challenge. The resource management is absolutely brutal, if you don't eat or drink for too long you're pretty much dead. This is a game that offers little compromise as far as base building: there are certain things that are non-negotiable. You need to make a starting hut shelter just to save your game, which is brilliant because it's basically softlocking the game until you figure out how to keep yourself alive for long enough to make a shelter. Can't make a shelter the first day? Make a leaf bed, or you'll wake up with worms under your skin with no way to remove them yet. Pass out on the ground from exhaustion? Same thing. You'll go insane before you can get the resources to fix the worms (ask me how i found that out).

It's a great game, really. Don't let the early difficulty curve scare you away, it's absolutely worth the effort and as you get secure in the resource management and "keeping yourself not dead" thing, the exploration seems to be a great challenge. Oh, and you'll have some of the best jungle atmosphere out there while you're doing all this.

Pretty solid survival game all things considered IMO. If you enjoy the show "Alone", this game is the closest i've played to that. You will probably die quite a bit at first while you learn the ropes. 

What this game does different than other survival games:
- The inventory system in the game limits how much you can carry quite a lot, especially in building items such as logs, mud bricks, large stones, etc. 
- The inventory system means that most bases will be built near a water source for ease of access to bricks and most bases won't be as large as you see in other games similar to this like Rust, Ark, etc. It will take you many in game nights to build what people would call a "2x2" on Rust.
- Food is difficult to stockpile due to lack of inventory "space". Having renewable food sources is tougher to get than most survival games. Fish do that quite well.
- Hydration is way tougher to manage in this game. You can't make a fire if you are tired. You also can't make a fire  if its raining unless its under a shelter you've built (or found). 
- Sleep is interesting. When it hits zero, you pass out, and will wake up with some new "friends" living under your skin. 
- I found myself building many "outpost" or "FOB" type bases which have: Always near water source, a roof so I can make a fire in rain, and a sleeping mat. Spread these among the map and it's really easy to explore.

Cons:
- Sadly all combat boils down to "hit them in the head" be it natives or some animal. As long as you aren't overwhelmed most engagements are very simple if you hit the HEAD. I think hitting the body should do way more damage
- IMO Leeches being impossible to prevent or at least lessen the occurrences gets rather annoying the more you play but maybe it is realistic

I love this game!! I was attracted to it by the claim that you need to use "actual survival methods" to last through it. True, but, impossible for it to recognize every possible method, so, it took a bit for me to find the right combinations for me to survive at first.

These are trivial issues if they are even considered issues at all and don't affect the beautiful graphics and great gameplay. I can't wait for the third installment of "The Spirits Of Amazonia" and hope they keep the dlc's coming! I could play this game forever.

Green Hell is .. meh :-/ . It may seems hard to speak negatively of this game since it is well realised. But, to me, the game is just not fun, so I can't recommend otherwise.
(Note: A of december 2020 - As usual for an EA, Mind the date of this review).

A few examples:
[list]
[*]Crafting: I understand there is a The-Forest-Taste in there, but that's made in a clumsy way, often even tedious. For instance, when you craft something, the game closes your inventory automatically. Fair enough, why not. I mean, that would be ok ... if crafting a single arrow did not require 5 damn clicks spent navigating within 2 different menus. Perhaps that's me, but seriously, 2 minutes stuck in the game UI to craft 10 arrows, that sucks. And the inventory management is generally like that, everything requires more clicks and more time than you'd expect. In Green Hell, you'll have to be ready tp spend a sizable portion of your in-game time starring at your inventory. That might be just me but I don't find it fun.
[*]Base building is, at best, anecdotic, because 1) There is not enough ressource and/or flat space to build a decent base like you would do in 7d2d, Conan or even The Forest 2) Building a base is actually pointless (Since you will have to progress from area to area, you'll rarely get back to your base. And anyways, you will rapidly figure out that moving from a pre-build camp to pre-build camp is the best option to go through the story. 
[*]Dying: You have no chance to survive in this game, that's bundled within the game core. But not because of some gameplay mechanics that you need to learn to get better, no, no, it's nothing about "Git Gud" really. It's just you'll regularly get one-shot by a scorpion, a snake or whatever random Puma. The game will then give you 1 minutes to drop your inventory on the ground (So you avoid the death penalty). And then, once respawn, you'll spend another minute to get your inventory back, one item by one item - Told you, this game is all about fun ...
[*]The "scenario steps": You'll have to go though painfully slow sections of the game, without any way to escape. No spoiler here, but you can guess another super fun time, quite unique to this game I must agree.
[*]Open world : Lol seriously? The map is a succession of cliff-surrounded-small-areas linked by narrow corridors. The player has no freedom whatsoever. Perhaps that's me, but I have a different definition of what is an actual "Open World".
[*]Body inspection mode : You walk 1 minute in the jungle and leeches will stick to you. You'll then have a menu to remove them. The menu is divided in 4 body parts, so you might have to repeat the same your manipulation 4 times. Repeat continuously throughout the game. As deliciously tedious as possible.
[*]You're caracter might become insane and will start to yell in your ears (I mean, literraly, in your real-life headset). Alright ok, unpleasant feature, but ok, why not. Though, you'll quickly figure out that a campfire is enough to recover your mental health, whatever the origin of your illness ... as long as you stand still close by, most likely waiting doing nothing - Another fun moment. Well, you might optimize boring moments though, it's certainly a good time to craft some arrows right?
[/list]

The game's attention to detail and realistic mechanics make it an immersive experience. The crafting system is well thought out, and the game offers a good balance between exploration and survival. However, the game's steep learning curve can be frustrating for some players, and the lack of a proper tutorial may leave some feeling overwhelmed. The game's graphics are impressive, but it requires a high-end computer to run smoothly. Overall, Green Hell is a challenging and immersive survival game that is worth checking out for fans of the genre.

This game has no business being this good!

The story is delivered using mechanics similar to Firewatch, where the main character tries to uncover a mystery, while in radio contact with his S.O., all while struggling to survive. The story itself revolves around indigenous medicine. On a personal note, my life was literally saved by a sacred fungus commonly known as "magic mushrooms"; for me, all other avenues of "modern medicine" failed. 

However, there is a lot of anger from indigenous tribes, at those who share this sacred knowledge, as well as the westerners who exploit it. As Western civilization takes greater interest in the tribes, the tribes are either assimilated or decimated, and their cultural heritage is lost. As the game portrays, the only tribes that have survived are aggressively hostile towards outsiders. There is a lot to learn and a lot to gain from all indigenous people, but simply contacting them, writing about them, sharing with them destroys what we love most about them. 

So what do we do? I don't know. I wouldn't trade my psychedelic experience for anything. I wish I could live like the tribesmen, in touch with nature, away from modern culture. But what has happened to their culture and their heritage is just... so sad. It's worth saving, but how? And what human would forgo saving their life or the lives of their loved-ones, to keep a culture untainted? Even if you make such a moral stand, others won't, so would you be sacrificing your loved ones for nothing?

I picked this one up way back in Early Access when the story wasn't even finished yet, shelved it for a while, and just came back recently. The game has really come a long way and manages to captivate me in a way that other survival games just don't do. The story is great and definitely what sets it apart in the genre but more often than not I find myself just enjoying hanging out in the world, completely forgetting that I'm supposed to actually be doing something. Not only is the environment gorgeous, it's teeming with life instead of feeling like a bunch of empty space in between important areas.

The world is dangerous and frankly pretty frustrating at first, but that same quality also gives you a real sense of accomplishment as you learn how to deal with it. You'll go from dying within 2 days to barely clinging to life for a week before dying, then barely clinging to life for two weeks before dying, then something clicks and you're able to barely cling to life indefinitely as long as you don't do something stupid. Your mastery of the world improves and eventually you find yourself in good enough shape to be able really start exploring, taking risks, and progressing the story...which is when the real game begins and that's something I don't want to spoil.

All that said, nobody's perfect. Dropped items get lost under bushes or just fall through the ground. The UI design often favors immersion over convenience, requiring you to flip through notebook pages one by one to find the building you want or rearrange your entire inventory so you can pick up a rock. It's better than it used to be and it's certainly no worse than many other games, but it does frustrate at times. Of course, one could say it's quite realistic to be frantically flipping through your notes trying to find that one thing you need to not die :)  Haven't tried multiplayer myself but plenty of other reviews detail the issues people have run into, so that's something to be aware of if co-op is your jam.

If you want a survival game that's super streamlined and basically just about making base get bigger and number go up, then this game probably isn't for you. If you're looking for a survival game whose world demands you pay attention to it, where survival is never a trivial task no matter how much you learn or how many resources you gather, that really compels you to explore deeper and figure out what the hell is going on in its weird story...well, this might be right up your alley. Just remember no step on snek.

*UPDATE 4/23/2023* Finished the main story, now working on Spirits of Amazonia and loving it even more. I've even been dipping into multiplayer a bit (still no dedicated servers for better or worse, if that's something you care about) and been having a blast with that as well. This game is honestly worth twice the $25 asking price.

This review is long over due as I cannot recommend this game highly enough. Huge underrated gem that I think everyone should play. I serious consider this among the best games I have ever played. 

In terms of core gameplay, this game is interesting as it's a survival game where the focus is truly on survival. Most other survival games I've played, the survival mechanism is only really a factor for the first few hours, then you build a settlement and focus on upgrades and exploration and the survival mechanisms just become an annoyance. In this game survival is the heart and sole, and you never get past that. There are no upgrades to save you. You're always at risk of things like infection, and food is always limited. It's also impressive the degree to which the survival is simulated. Like with the several types of infections, or how you have to search your body for leeches. 

The real star of this game though is the single player story. Hit me harder than any other game I've played. I think it's because of the way the story is told. It's told through narration over still/freezeframe scenes that you can walk through. I guess this was done as a cost savings measure, because animation is expensive, but it really punches up the emotional impact. It feels more like an experience as you walk around the still scene, picking out small details as you hear the emotional narration. It's unlike anything else. 

You should play this game and play through the full single player campaign(core game). Everyone should.

I am not the best at survival games, but have vastly improved from where I started. Green Hell is my favorite survival game despite my many deaths, because I actually feel like I have to survive. There are a lot of game mechanics involved that make this game enjoyable.

As a lover of Survival Crafter games, Green Hell is the way to go. Immersive storyline completely rocked me emotionally, the game is difficult. Not TOO difficult, but just enough. Getting materials can be Grindy, but as someone who came from vanilla WoW, Ive never been scared of the grind. Beat the game twice, well worth the time and energy put into it. If you enjoy games like Scum, Rust, Valheim, and Raft, youll probably enjoy this.

[h1]Unrealistic hell...[/h1]
The game is marketed as a realistic survival crafting game, but it has invisible walls which stops your movement; climbing ropes that you can't climb until eating a granola bar; 95% of coconut trees don't have even a single coconut on them; trees that cannot be chopped down and logs on the ground that can't be harvested either; ground areas that are completely clear yet can't be build upon; animals that can't be skinned despite having a machete in your hand; and it's possible to carry 6 huge palm leaves but you cannot carry 1 palm leaf together with another type of leaf... I guess the two different types of palm leaves hate eachother? Makes sense...

This game isn't a 'realistic survival crafting game'... it's just a 'survival crafting game'. For every 'realistic' mechanic that the game boasts, there's 2 other unrealistic mechanics at work as well. If you enjoy being punished, then you'll enjoy this game, but don't buy into the fact that the game is realistic or even logical in its game mechanics and design, because it isn't.

Also, the regional pricing for the game is really bad in the 3rd world, which for me on principle alone is reason enough to not support the devs.

For more reviews, visit my curator page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7851637/
For my full recommended list of games: https://steamcommunity.com/id/lfpg/recommended/

This is my favorite survival game I've ever played (I consider Ark a building game, not a survival game). It is way too difficult for me, but there are tons of custom options to make it compatible with my skill level. The setting is lush and beautiful, and the background noises are so nice. Awesome building and crafting system. Dev is engaged with community, recently polled as to what should be added. I can't recommend Green Hell enough. I played singleplayer custom settings.

I don't recommend it for the full cost as it isn't really a finished product. I can't really in good conscience tell people to buy a skeleton framework of a finished game on reconsidering that, the game needs more stuff to do, needs a way to break stones up because they can be depleted pretty fast. Quick harvesting for vine ropes would be a plus because it is really just busywork. The construction options are fairly basic, but that's a survival game for you. I got mine for 30% off, so I would be alright saying yeah for anything less.

You also spend a lot of time hunting things but those jaguars you kill won't let you craft any jaguar skin armours. In fact, leather isn't even part of the game. Bones are available en masse, but can't be burned up for high grades of fertilizer. You also can't seem to make a lot of bone crafts with them, or to extract marrow? What about a bone broth?

First 20 hrs are cool don't get me wrong its a fun game, then its the same stats rinse repeat.

As a sandbox survival game, its fantastic. The story mode, on the other hand, feels unnecessarily shoehorned into the game.

For that magical first play, that is always best in survival games, I configured the game to provide authentic Robinsonade experience. I disabled the natives and big predators, while focusing on battling the elements and treating the occassional snakebite. I had an absolute blast. Crafting, hunting, rationing water, building my own house, transforming an area, slowly becoming more and more comfortable in the game world. This is the strength of Green Hell, it gives you a fantastic playground without the jaded zombie hordes or super-predictable supernatural elements found in other games. That one playthrough I got my money's worth tenfold.

Then I tried the story mode and the world fell apart. I won't spoil anything, but the game couldn't rise above the "obtain X for it is the only way you can reach Y where you can obtain Z for its the only way..." repeating ad nauseam. New areas are walled by artificial-looking cliffs where there is juuuust one narrow path through, magically requiring you to use the latest-acquired thing and only that. You'll never look the same way on the game world again. By the time I write this I reached map 3 and I'm not sure I care enough about the story to actually finish it. It does the otherwise great game a disservice, goes against the very premise that sets it apart from the competition.

Still, I recommend the game. Just stay away from story mode and internet sources, take the time to find recipes and buildings on your own. Logical thinking will get you far and I especially like how more advanced stuff actually makes your in-game life easier. There is tons of content, lots of stuff to do, you'll have a great time.

HARD AS FUCK. dude, this game will rip u a new asshole its so fucking hard. fun with friends tho so i recommend !

Setting aside how weird and gross the native depictions get and the Mighty Whitey-ness of it all, it is functionally a bad game
-Terrible, inconvenient crafting and inventory management systems. Every step of every interaction involves five unnecessary clicks while you open and close different windows. Need to make a bandage for that cut on your arm? Open the inspect window to select your arm, open the crafting window to create a bandage, open the inventory, sort to one of the five screens holding your crafting items, move the leaf from your backpack to your crafting table, craft it, move it back again, move medicine in with it, craft it again, close the window, reopen the inspect window, locate the cut on your arm again, then place the bandage on that exact spot. Moving a stack of items from your inventory to storage? Open storage, open inventory, sort to the correct inventory screen, individually move every item in the stack from one screen to the exact spot you want on the other screen. Every interaction in the game is filled with unnecessary opening, closing, picking up, putting down, holding the correct button to access an unrelated submenu, etc.
-Constant desyncs in co-op where you and your partner have different items, different plants, different rocks, and different aggro enemies on screen in different places. You can only interact with/attack the things that the game decides to render on your side. It's like playing two different games side by side.
-Awful "George, no one speaks like this" writing for both main characters
-The kind of stilted line reads that you can only get from a polish studio doing bilingual english/spanish characters

But if you're like me, you aren't here for an immersive experience. You're here because you want co-op crafting survival and you've already played all the good ones. In that case, sure. Fine. If you need to build survival bases with your partner to get through the day, get it on sale.

Storyline 6.5/10
Gameplay 8/10

Again, avoiding spoilers, I recommend everyone to at least try this game once, I've personally only racked up so many hours by forcing this onto my sister, so a lot of the enjoyment just came from us being together, and not specifically the game itself. That's not a knock on the game itself though, I do seriously enjoy it.

Avoiding spoilers; I find too much of the game itself is limited - especially in regards to the combat, building and just overall replay time. I NEVER find myself (not since I first got it maybe 2 years ago) with the urge to play this game unless my sister is online, but when I do, or when they update stuff, I devote a good 10-20 hours per week. 

It's just frustrating how I want this game to have so much more, like furniture, defensive walls, paddle boats, Mayan armor/colonial Spanish armor and the ability to build anywhere, but we don't have that. At least not yet.

But still, I had 43 hours in this by myself before my sister started, and I did enjoy those moments, so I keep this game installed and continue to play it, just like I encourage other people to play it. Because I really want this game to grow and I've never genuinely had an overall negative experience from it.

Super fun, challenging game play with an incredibly immersive survival system. It challenges not only your abilities to play a game but you memory, practicality and planning abilities. I finally decided to play this game this year. Fucking love it, it has been really fun to play. 

Had a 5 hours long session today where i was listening to a podcast at the same time. Slept multiple times, although did not save manually as i constantly forgot about it. Then as i was in need of a singular bamboo stick for my water purifier i decided to head out to find some bamboo. 
I had apparently forgotten that all my bandages were used except my lily and tobacco ones.

So naturally, a puma jumped me. It scratched me once, i then killed it with a single arrow to the head, saw i was out of bandages, then bled out and died while looking for more. Woke up 5 hours earlier, in my old base. 

This game BADLY needs an autosave feature. It should ALWAYS save when sleeping. Manual saving only, is bad game design in a game like this with so much to keep track of and distract you. 


For the love of all that is Holy, Do not forget to save your game.

"Realistic" does not equal fun, especially in this game.

There needs to be a point when you realize that breaking every single survival element into meticulous little pieces, for the sake of setting the game apart from others in the genre, just makes for a very frustrating experience.

To understand what I mean, as an example, know that this game doesn't just have a hunger meter, it has three: fats, carbohydrates and proteins, plus the thirst. --Now that's just there to make the game feel more deep than it really is. And if you thought hunger and thirst are annoying in survival games, you haven't seen anything yet.

I am an adventure gamer who prefers controller support. On the two sides of the coin you deliver on both ends! the story is captivating, the jungle is vast, and the number of plant species and animals you can harvest is wonderful. Havent gotten much into the building aspect yet because it was prefered I play the story before straight up survival. I am glad I did it because so far I was able to list pro's and con's I have noticed so far. Pro's I have already kind of listed, gripping story, vast exploration, but as far as helping the player understand some of the game mechanics I am at a loss. As far as the map is concerned, you cannot see where it is you are exactly even while using your coordinates, they dont match up. And building aspects it doesnt show you what you need to build items, you merely guess. its frustrating to not have more guidance even in tutorial mode. I am merely lost in the jungle trying to retrace my steps to hopefully get back on track but so far this is the 4th time I have logged on and tried starting from the begining only to still get lost with no guidance. I even chose easy mode. So for the future, give the player more hints on how to craft (what they need for certain items) so they can progress through the game even on easy mode, and no I am not a noob in standards, been playing games for years.

For a game released in 2019, this game has a lot that just makes it overall better.
Here, I'm gonna talk about both green hell VR (bought it on quest 2) and green hell flatscreen. I'll say pros and cons of both.

~~GREEN HELL (FLATSCREEN)~~
PROS:
Green hell's graphics are definitely top notch. It looks stunning for a game from 4 years ago.
EXTREMELY immersive. This game really just throws you in. It's extremely realistic. Playing this game really makes you evolve as a survivalist. Many modern survival games don't immerse you like the way green hell does.
The realism is very high. There's a lot of detail and little tiny things that go a long way in a game like this.
The mechanics are really fun. Spear fishing, crafting, cooking, fishing, everything. Something that i've always thought of while playing survival games is "Why the hell am I not able to do that? Couldn't I just do this?" Green hell sort've fixes this problem pretty well. Like the harvest mechanic. A really simple thing that goes a long way. Many survival games just don't allow you to do something like that. Or atleast the ones I've played.
Weirdly enough? The physics are really good. Yes i agree. cutting down a tree doesn't look right at all. But when logs fall or you drop things onto the floor/on top of things they work the way you'd expect them to. If i drop a stick onto the floor, on top of a few more sticks, they dont clip and bounce around like you'd expect them to. They do what you think they'd do and just stack. or fall over of course. nothing flies out of control or clips through the floor. never.
Base building is fun!
the inventory management system is something i really really enjoy. It's a close cousin to our favorite inventory management system from the early 2000s, RE4!
open world? Oh its great. Beautiful.

CONS
Christ this games entities always clip into leaves and trees a little too often. And their animations are very janky. It's not a complete immersion breaker but this is where I really see it and go "Yeah this game's old..."
Every animation is a bit primitive. But it's really not that big of a deal. I can let this one slide because this game *is* 4 years old.
Its almost completely different from the VR version. Things you could do in VR are usually completely different. like a reinforced ax isn't unlocked until later in the game.
Might be a skill issue, but its hard...

MY OPINION:
Green hell is the best survival game. Just in general. I know the cons make it seem a little bad but you WILL love the intense survival experience if you love games like "the forest". This game is still wonderful after 4 years. And really? If they decide to take a bit of their time to fix nooks and crannies, It'll become the greatest survival game of all time. Its intensity and difficulty just makes it so much more better.

~~GREEN HELL (VIRTUAL REALITY EDITION!)~~

PROS
I love that the hallucination feature was implemented into VR. and very well!
Everything from green hell flatscreen translates very well into green hell VR. The crafting was also very beautifully made. The feeling of wrapping a rope around an axe to make it stronger. physically using objects to nail logs into the ground to make pillars for bases. Just wonderful.
the physics is also still advanced. and the graphics are still beautiful. They made the VR version really well. and everything good from the first game is put into here. 

CONS:
that jankiness wasn't fixed here. bummer.
there is no complex base building in the vr version :(

I really enjoyed playing green hell. It has all these small details that get you more into the game. From having to do a body check because you have to pull off some leeches to having to treat laceration wounds after a not so friendly kitty came to cuddle you. I love how the game has a clear sense of direction yet it still gives you all the freedom you want in an open world survival game. It also recently added a ton of new building features which gives you the opportunity to fully personalize your base. I loved being able to move from a boring house on land onto my lovely little cottage on the water. 
This game was definitely worth my money & time. 10/10 would recommend!

OH BOY, GREEN HELL IS ONE HECK OF A GAME. IT'S A SURVIVAL GAME THAT'S NOT TOO DIFFERENT FROM OTHERS IN THE GENRE, BUT IT STILL MANAGES TO STAND OUT.

THE GAME'S VISUALS ARE PRETTY DARN GOOD, WITH LOTS OF LUSH JUNGLE FOLIAGE AND DETAILED CHARACTER MODELS. YOU'LL FEEL LIKE YOU'RE REALLY IN THE MIDDLE OF THE AMAZONIAN RAINFOREST.

THE GAMEPLAY IS PRETTY SOLID TOO. YOU'LL HAVE TO MANAGE YOUR HUNGER, THIRST, AND HEALTH WHILE ALSO CRAFTING TOOLS AND BUILDING SHELTER. THERE'S A LEARNING CURVE TO IT, BUT IT'S NOT TOO STEEP.

BUT WHAT REALLY MAKES GREEN HELL STAND OUT IS ITS STORY MODE. IT'S NOT YOUR TYPICAL SURVIVAL GAME WHERE YOU'RE JUST TRYING TO SURVIVE FOR AS LONG AS POSSIBLE. INSTEAD, YOU'RE FOLLOWING A STORY OF A MAN WHO'S LOST IN THE JUNGLE AND TRYING TO FIND HIS WAY BACK TO CIVILIZATION.

THE STORY MODE ADDS A NEW LAYER OF INTEREST TO THE GAME, AND IT'S NICE TO HAVE A GOAL TO WORK TOWARDS BESIDES JUST SURVIVING.

THE ONLY ISSUE I HAVE WITH GREEN HELL IS THAT IT CAN GET REPETITIVE AFTER A WHILE. ONCE YOU'VE MASTERED THE BASICS OF SURVIVAL, THERE'S NOT TOO MUCH TO DO BESIDES EXPLORE THE JUNGLE AND CRAFT NEW THINGS.

OVERALL, GREEN HELL IS A SOLID SURVIVAL GAME WITH A UNIQUE STORY MODE. IT'S DEFINITELY WORTH A PLAYTHROUGH IF YOU'RE INTO THIS KIND OF GAME, BUT IT'S NOT GONNA CHANGE THE GAME FOR YA.

-Fe Asper

I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him in the online mode. loaded into the game, made my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and I cant wait to make future memories with my son.

Green Hell is a survival game that takes place in the Amazon rainforest, where you must fend off hunger, disease, and the dangers of the wild to stay alive. It's a game that will test your limits and push you to the brink of madness, but it's also an exhilarating experience. Let's take a closer look at the pros and cons of this intense game:

Pros:
[list]
[*]The game's graphics are stunning, with lush and detailed environments that transport you deep into the heart of the Amazon. It's a visual feast that will leave you in awe.
[*]The game's survival mechanics are challenging and rewarding, with a variety of tasks to keep you engaged. From building shelters to hunting for food, there's always something to do in Green Hell.
[*]The game's realism is impressive, with realistic depictions of hunger, disease, and mental health. It's a game that doesn't shy away from the harsh realities of survival.
[*]The game's sense of tension and dread is palpable, as danger lurks around every corner. Every decision you make could mean the difference between life and death.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*]The game's difficulty level can be overwhelming, especially for those who are new to survival games. You'll need to be strategic and resourceful to survive, and even then, some aspects of the game can feel unfair or unforgiving.
[*]The game can be quite time-consuming, especially if you're trying to progress quickly. Building and surviving take time, so if you're looking for a quick fix, Green Hell might not be the game for you.
[*]The game's combat system can be a bit clunky and unresponsive at times, which can be frustrating in high-pressure situations.
[/list]

Overall, Green Hell is an intense and immersive game that's not for the faint of heart. With its stunning graphics, challenging survival mechanics, and realistic depictions of survival in the wild, it's a game that's worth playing. Just be prepared for a steep learning curve and a constant sense of danger.

Green Hell is no joke! It's probably one of the hardest and most unforgiving games I've ever played, where you'll make a lot of mistakes if you want to survive in the middle of the jungle that will kill you, over and over and over, until you learn how to survive. It might sound stressful, and it is! But this is also where the game shines and what it's all about. When you finally get the hang of it, and you know how to make a shelter, make a campfire, make a weapon, and go out hunting for food in the middle of a tropical rain without getting worms or infections while a jaguar is nearby. That's when you become the true survivalist.

The crafting in this game is genius, where you have a backpack for all your stuff, and you have to make sure everything is there and packed effectively. The game offers many crafting buildings and a few weapons. The combat system might not be the best and it feels a bit sluggish at times. But the main story and atmosphere are brilliant and you really feel like you are living in the wilderness.

The only real criticism of this game is that you can spend hours exploring and getting lost. So, make sure you take your time and explore the jungle in a strategic way.

Score 8/10.

Green Hell is a survival game  that puts players in the heart of the Amazon rain forest. Players must navigate the harsh wilderness, gather resources, build shelter, and fend off wildlife to survive. One of the game's greatest strengths is its attention to detail. The lush and vibrant environment is stunningly beautiful, with dense foliage and wildlife that make the world feel alive. The game's sound design is also excellent, with realistic animal noises and atmospheric music that enhance the immersive experience. The game's survival mechanics are challenging and engaging. Players must monitor their hunger, thirst, and health, as well as deal with environmental hazards such as diseases and infections. The game also offers a crafting system that allows players to create tools and equipment to aid in their survival. The game's story is also well-done, with a well-written and engaging narrative that keeps players invested in the game's world. The game's characters are interesting and well-developed, and the game's twists and turns keep players on the edge of their seat. However, one of the game's few downsides is its lack of variety. While the game's survival mechanics and story are engaging, there is only so much players can do in the limited environment. Once players have built their shelter and gathered their resources, the game can become repetitive.  Green Hell is an excellent survival game that offers a beautiful and immersive experience. Its attention to detail, challenging survival mechanics, and engaging story make it a must-play for fans of the genre. However, its lack of variety may make it less appealing to some players looking for more replay value.

First Review:
I want to like this game, I've followed it for years. I finally caved, bought it on sale and started playing. I understand the game is support to be difficult, but it's just not set up well to ease a player into the experience. On difficult level 2 (1 being the easiest), I spent 4 hours looking for a goddamn coconut. Instead, I found leeches, parasites, jaguars, poisonous snakes and spiders. I watched YT videos and went on reddit; apparently coconuts are supposed to spawn on the ground as well as in trees where the can be knocked down. 4 hours, no goddamn coconuts in sight. Game is just.... so much jank, I can't recommend.

Second Review:
I uninstalled the game out of frustration. Didn't plan to come back to it... went to bed, and the next morning... thought "Surely it's possible to survive beyond 5 hours..surely I can do it". I found that nice ledge on the cliff of the starting area, loaded it with traps. Still cannot find enough goddamn coconuts to save my life. But now I have a mud house with 6 arrow traps for the damn wakandan invaders that keep trying to break my fragile home. Why do they hate me so much? They stole my girlfriend and yet want to ruin my life? I can only imagine the terrible things they're doing to her.. it fuels my rage. I am hunting them now. I considered eating their meat but I don't want to lower myselves to their cannibalistic ways. I'll edit this review once I sandpeople their village. And I haven't forgotten about that jaguar... I'm gonna eat KITTY TONIGHT! If I can find some goddamn coconuts.

If you like a challenge in your survival games and you can manage a bit of frustration (you will die in the Amazon jungles, it is a fact not a theory) then Green Hell is a fantastic game and is thoroughly enjoyable. The Sanity feature is very realistic, perhaps nearly too much so but it adds a whole new dynamic to survival that is both fun and greatly intimidating at times. 

Watch your back for the big cats; they are jerks and will prowl out of nothing on you; if you are good with a bow a well placed shot to the face will net you some good quality meat and bones to help keep you in food and such for awhile (I recommend making soups out of it for the extra hydration value) but they are a dangerous threat in the jungle and can ruin your day and your save if you aren't careful and wary; then again they arguably are not as bad as the natives that sneak up and attempt to wreck your house.

8/10. Wait for a sale at least.

I finished the base game and Spirits of the Amazon but it misses so much potential due to lack of polishing.
It's exciting to survive and every mistake is punishing. You can even spend 80 hours in the game and you'll still miss most of the useful recipes as they have to be figured out with no in-game hints. The game had it's good moments with no hand holding but in the end the journey was way too prolonged.

Frustrating things:
- Spawning of things. Enemies can spawn next to you and you'll be bleeding without a chance of reaction. Items pop in the air and fall to ground and the whole spawning system can just crash without notice and you'll see no enemies unless you reboot the game. Truly breaks the immersion of being in a jungle.
- Base building is not encouraged but only for fun. You constantly need to move around multiple maps. Every map offers the same difficulty level so there's no need to fall back to recover and prepare for "going deeper" in the jungle. Building a house is just a waste of time.
- Leeches stick to your skin through armor. Enjoy taking off every single armor piece into your, oh, full inventory, just to pick the leeches off every single time.
- Reputation grind in the DLC. You can't even grind them as you need to finish 80% of _everything_ there's available. You need to practically do every possible quest you encounter and google out specific positions you have missed as just wandering around all areas three times is not enough. No reputation is given for killing evil villagers. You can't even prepare nice gifts or do repeatable deeds for the villages. Just hard coded quests. I believe most players give up with the game with the reputation grind. I would lower the requirements to 50% of everything there's to do at least.
- Quest markers can be bugged on your map. You can for example see a spot to investigate when there's actually nothing there.
- All cut scene videos are played at maximum volume. Prepare your ears.
- Fishing is tedious and useless compared to gaining normal animal meat.
- Quite a few useless items to be found which have no use for crafting of anything.

Great in-depth survival game with a surprisingly gripping story

I was worried that you played as a white guy in the amazon and most of your interactions with the natives was them attacking you, but the game handles it in the best possible way it could. Minor spoilers for the story, but there is very good reason why you meet few peaceful natives and many violent ones. The people attacking you are justified and the game acknowledges that. It was quite refreshing tbh

Positive: For me it is the first game where I have the permanent feeling of being in the middle of it. Huge game world with a lot of attention to detail. Well-designed game with strong logic. At the beginning very difficult but after some learning time well playable. Beautifully implemented story. Different game modes, well customizable. Soundtrack not perfect but nevertheless cleanly implemented. Negative: Base building is a bit annoying. If the frame partially protrudes into the ground, it cannot be built because the component must be visible. That's why you often have to jump in the air to attach modules. Some logic errors. Some things have to be picked up once before you can make anything with them. It also rains under a roof. Recognition of collectible items is poorly implemented. Sometimes you have to look in a different direction to be able to collect items. A lot of things have to be read up on, since not everything is explained in the game. The collision of the environment does not match the graphical implementation. Rocks are higher than visible with it. You are constantly stuck somewhere. Jumping is poorly implemented and is also annoying. Machete and other found items break, that makes no sense. Although the character has already run 183 kilometers, he doesn't have any more stamina and breathes like my grandfather after only a few meters.

Green Hell is a survival game that offers a unique and immersive experience, set in the Amazon rainforest. The game is challenging, but it's also incredibly rewarding, offering players a chance to test their survival skills and push themselves to their limits.

One of the standout features of Green Hell is its realism. The game's world is richly detailed, with a variety of flora and fauna that feels authentic and believable. The game's visuals are impressive, with detailed character models and environments that make you feel like you're truly in the heart of the Amazon.

The survival mechanics in Green Hell are also top-notch. Players must manage their hunger, thirst, and health while avoiding dangerous wildlife and hostile tribes. The game's crafting system is also well-implemented, allowing players to create tools and weapons from natural materials found in the rainforest.

But perhaps the most impressive aspect of Green Hell is its storytelling. The game's narrative unfolds through the player's interactions with the environment and through the player's own survival story. The game's story is engaging, and it draws you in, making you feel like you're a part of the game's world.

Overall, Green Hell is an excellent game that offers a unique and immersive survival experience. The game's realism, survival mechanics, and storytelling are all top-notch, making it a must-play for fans of the survival genre. Whether you're an experienced survival game player or new to the genre, Green Hell is a game that's sure to challenge and delight you.

:UPDATE 3/20/2023:

I think the best way I can explain what really ruined this game for us is to compare it to reloading guns.

In real life, when you reload a gun, if you pop out the clip and pop in a new one, you lose any remaining ammo in the old clip, it's just gone.  OR, you have to individually finger one bullet at a time into the clip.

In games, this is not a fun experience for a vast majority of players so reloading just automatically handles your ammo and you don't lose any (in most games).

In this game, you have to maintain 4 different meters between different types of nutrients from food, water, sleep, etc.   It's just not fun to eat some meat you recently cooked only to have to go find more food of a different type to fill different meters.

So, most games just have you eat ANY type of food to fill your hunger meter rather than have to ensure you have a balanced diet, because trying to eat a balanced diet in real life isn't terribly enjoyable let along doing it in a VIDEO GAME.

I don't think the game is "broken" I just think it is fundamentally designed in a way that is not enjoyable for us.  On top of that, there was little reason to build a "home" of any scale with all the cool new building options considering you just run around and do story missions and have no real need to build a base.  

And, if you did build a base, running all the way home to refill meters and sleep, just means that by the time you run back out to your mission spot, your meters are going to be drained and you'll just have to run home again.  OR, you forage for food and make a quick fire randomly in the jungle defeating the purpose of building a home!

(To be fair, this issue is exactly the same with the new Sons of the Forest release.... we built a basic base, then ran around doing the story and never once had a reason to go back home until entire game was finished...) 

Original Review:

Nope.  Simple as that.   Unfortunately steam's relatively nice 2-hour refund window doesn't help when you have games like this that typically take a few hours to "figure out" what you're doing and see if you like it or not.

I'll summarize why I would not recommend this game to anyone:

1) You spend a vast majority of your time fighting to fill 5 meters (3 types of food, water, and energy/sleep).  Filling these meters drain them so by time you've in a good place, you need to sleep, which then drains the meters while you sleep.

2) The AI for both the tribe humans and Predator creatures is beyond stupid.  Very quickly you'll figure out how to fight all of these without any trouble (unless you're almost dead already).  Predator is the most annoying as it seems almost random and either scratches you causing more annoyance or you easily kill it and leave it to rot because what are you going to do with food that goes bad right away and you can't cook without putting in a lot of effort?

3) Building at first seems interesting, you have to put each and every individual part of each thing on the blueprint.  Each log, stick, branch, and rope tie.   But this quickly becomes a chore.  You can carry 3 large logs and most things take 4+ easily.  Trees typically give 2-4 per cutting them down. 

4) Initially farming out the 3 food types (Carbs, Protein, Fats) seems interesting but quickly becomes annoying.  Eventually you can build a decent "supply" of each but most of them don't transport so going out to explore you'll basically be fighting all of these bars the entire time.  Very annoying.  By far the worst of this type of system I've experienced.

5) Movement feels pretty bad if I'm being entirely honest.  You get used to it after a while but you'll still find yourself getting stuck constantly on random sticks, rocks, trying to walk on fallen trees and hitting "invisible walls" that can push you off.

I've put off playing this because a lot of reviews and comments suggested it was trying to be a hardcore experience but ultimately ended up being a more frustrating experience.   I think the developers and the hardcore fans will try to force a narrative that the game is "hardcore" and confuse difficulty with annoyance.   

Elden Ring (or Souls style games) are often considered very difficult (which is frustrating to many).  But Soul's style games typically have very complex combat with "perfect" timing needed.   This game has no perfect timing and has stupid AI.  This game has 5 meters you have to constantly fight and they don't offer many tools to improve that over time.  Drying meet extends the life of the food for a few days, but takes several days to dry.   You can grow fruit, to fill one of the bars but can't take it with you since it goes bad so fast.

[h1]The good stuff[/h1]
A good survival game which has a challenging survial depth. You have to:
- manage hunger with 3 different sub-categories
- manage thirst
- manage sanity
- manage tools with durability
- manage health with different sub-categories
- manage food/consumables with different expiration dates

There is a vast flora and fauna (however, not so much in the story mode but in the "Spirits of Amazonia" game mode). The fauna has various predators that are trying to kill you.

There are also natives that are not so happy about your presence in the woods.

It also has a good craft and build system.

The story mode is interesting and has a cool concept.

I would generally suggest playing the "Spirits of Amazonia" game mode, which has the most stuff.
I.e. it further introduces tribes (enemies and friends).

[h1]The bad stuff[/h1]
I bought the game during its early access state. During this phase bugs and some weird behaviour were expected.

However, the game is no longer early access and considered a finished game.

Well... it is maybe finished, but it has a lot of stuff that need to be fixed and addressed. IMO this is not a finished game.

Stuff that needs to be changed:
- [b]Issue 1[/b] At the end of the story mode the game crashes and the achievements for finishing the game will not be distributed
- [b]Issue 2[/b] Saving must be done manually, which is generally fine. However, in a story mode I expect some assistence from the game, espacially before cut scenes.
- [b]Issue 3[/b] A pile of logs and sticks will clip through the ground making weird water noises
- [b]Multiplayer Issue 1[/b] game states of both players are only synced and saved, when saving manually. Meaning if someone crashed (which can happen during a multiplayer session, duh) the player who lost connection will be resetted.
- [b]Multiplayer Issue 2[/b] sometimes when accessing the bow you will get stuck in the "bow state". Changing weapons or opening the inventory is no longer possible. This means the other player must quickly setup a camp to save, due to [i]Multiplayer Issue 1[/i]
- [b]Multiplayer Issue 3[/b] when one player is too far away from the host, he will loose connection. Which sucks due to [i]Multiplayer Issue 1[/i]

[h1] Play This Game Now [/h1]
Green Hell is a thrilling and immersive survival game that puts players in the heart of the Amazon rainforest. The game is designed to test your survival skills in a hostile environment, with a focus on realistic gameplay mechanics and immersive storytelling.

The game's mechanics are comprehensive, with a deep crafting system that allows players to create a wide range of tools and equipment from the resources they gather. The game also includes a robust medical system, where players must tend to their wounds and illnesses using natural remedies found in the forest. The game's hunger, thirst, and sanity systems add to the challenge, as players must manage their basic needs while also dealing with the mental strain of being lost in the jungle.

The game's events are dynamic and unpredictable, with a variety of hazards and challenges that can arise at any moment. From vicious predators to deadly diseases, players must constantly be on the lookout for threats and adapt their strategies to survive. The game also includes a rich story campaign, where players must unravel the mystery of what happened to their missing partner and uncover the secrets of the forest.

The game's graphics are stunning, with detailed environments that are both beautiful and dangerous. The lush rainforest setting is brought to life with stunning visuals and realistic sound design that immerses players in the world. The game's characters are well-written and fully realized, with voice acting that adds depth and emotion to the story.

Overall, Green Hell is a must-play for fans of survival games. It's challenging, immersive, and rewarding, with deep gameplay mechanics and a gripping story that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Whether you're a seasoned survival game veteran or new to the genre, Green Hell is a game that should not be missed.

I can see what they tried to do here. Very similar to The Forest. This is a good game. However, right from the start, I hit a brick wall. After 14 hours of gameplay in story mode on easy, I die constantly. I'm 21 days in, but thats after dying countless time from stupid cheap shots the game throws at you. If it's not an infection, its a random snake bite. If its not that, its low sanity. If it's not that, it's something else. I can't even build a decent shelter without having to check for leeches and worms every 2 minutes. And when I do, 75 percent of the time they are there to disappoint. Now I have to spend the next god knows how much time to find bone needles and make patches so I don't die.....again. This is all in story mode. I've traveled 64 km and have literally gotta nowhere. Long story short. This is why I wait for popular games to be on sale. The game was fun for the first 15 minutes, then I got thrown into jungle with no clue how to get past the dumb shit. Before I pop off here, there's one more thing I'd like to address that I see in literally EVERY survival game. The day and night cycle. You get like 15-20 minutes of day and night. Wtf. Why? What fantasy planet is this? What, the realism of infections and animal attacks and dehydration isn't not enough? You gotta throw in some wacky day light times in too?! Stop! Stop doing that! It's stupid! Or at least let the player change it. We get it, better seek shelter before the sun goes down so I don't walk off the side of a cliff! OK, I'm done. Don't buy this game.

Check this. This dude needs a well balanced meal according to his fitness apps, and if you don't get it just right he comes down with a bad case of Sudden Onset Narcolepsy. This guy will only be able to spend 5 minutes awake unless you get him the choicest of meats and fruits. And if you pass out, well, prepare your arms for worms because YOU GONNA GET SOME WORMS. Apparently the Amazon is infested with trillions of arm biters just waiting below the surface for some dude who missed his afternoon banana.

I spent 30 minutes in a state of aimlessly wondering around the jungle looking for a single solitary bush that grows Bandage Leaves™️ so I could patch up the wounds from taking out my arm worms and realized I hadn't had fun for hours. Sure I could go back to my base and get all that stuff, but after peeling away my 5000th leech and realizing if I did that I would have to:

- spend 20 minutes walking back to base
- peel off 10 more leeches (in a "Self Inspect" mode that loses its appeal <20h in)
- get to base
- fall asleep
- spend 15 minutes getting my nutrition in order (+ travel snacks)
- and finally, another 20 minutes to come back where I was if NOTHING went awry

... or, I could just.... not.

The difficulty is just stupid in the game and the time it takes to do anything is insane. You fall 5 feet scrape your knee and die from infection in 5 hours. You sleep on the ground get 2 worms and day 1 you die from infection. I understand making infection something that can kill you and I am all for it. However infection should take days not hours to kill you. I can barely get up a tent before my character dies from these little scrapes and bruises let alone face off against any predators. How about we make the game playable by not having your character die after you have a scraped knee for 5 hours. Yet if you want to build anything resembling a house it will take you about a week to make a shed with how long it takes to do anything when you are having to micro manage every scrape, bump, and nutrition element. I love that they try to make you need fats, carbs, and protein. However if you cannot find one of the 3 in your first 3 days out there you need to take 2 full sleep cycles to get through the day and lose tons of time. Building any type of base is out of the question you spend 95% of your time just getting your needs met. The graphics and immersive quality of the game is there though, it has potential but they need to give you some time to progress and not just have to micro manage so many things at once. Going 3 days with no nuts to eat and bam you have no energy and cannot get anything done GAME OVER. Give players more time to progress without having to deal with issue after issue 24/7 and maybe we might have an enjoyable game.

The story was interesting and kept me wanting to find the next story location to find out more of what was going on as the mystery unravelled. I am about to start the Spirits of Amazonia story and am looking forward to seeing how it goes.

The building side of things is fun but could use a some work as many times I found myself trying to place the frame blueprints on top of another one and while it visually looked like it should be fine it would not let me place it as if there was an invisible object blocking it. The same goes for trying to place blueprints on the ground, some areas that looked flat enough would not allow placement of even the smallest fire which I found broke immersion.

Very immersive survival, needing patience, sharp ears and eyes etc. Running through the jungle (except for your life) is a bad idea. There's no tech tree to speak of, so more weapon / tool finds with better durability would make it more realistic. After all, having a metal axe which just breaks with no option for repair after a moderate amount of use is just silly if you are aiming for realism. Overall decent game, I have 100 hours on it so far,
Bad Game . Simple As. Purchase the Forest or Stranded Deep , or the Long Dark .

If you like the forest, then you will like this game. This is the Forest as DARKSOULS. VERY difficult game to play, but not hard to grasp.

Example: if you get attacked, your now bleeding and if you dont put on a bandage then you will bleed out. Ontop of all that, you will have to balance carbohydrates, water, carbs, AND fat.

In short, im playing this with my wife to get my survival kick until the new forest game comes out, this is fun and if you can get past the difficulty, then you will enjoy it too.
Good, like the forest but more detail. Also personally love the story line

The story is intriguing, but I really just love a challenging, beautiful game. Please take my advise though, turn up your volume and don't run anywhere. Learn from my mistakes haha.

Awesome.

Edit 2: 200+ hours in. So with the current set of DLCs, all of which are free, I'm a lot happier with the game. Three full games' worth of content, tree houses, animal handling, it's pretty cool. The gameplay loop issue I had is definitely feeling a lot more expanded. They're doing some real cool stuff with it, throwing obstacles in my way that I definitely didn't expect, like a poisoned river and headshot-immune boss type enemies that blast you back 20 feet per swing. I'm having fun with the game all over again. My only criticisms with the game are constructive in nature only, like a minor graphical bug where statblocks of items overlap, and there not really being a way to figure out where legends are without looking up a guide or dumb luck in exploration. I still haven't been able to figure out treehouses or animal handling on my own, but the fun is in experimentation, I guess.

Creepy Jar, if you see this, know that I see your love that you put into this game. I wouldn't have continued playing if I didn't feel the love. You made a banger, and it's only got better since release. That said, here's some improvement suggestions because your survey was very limiting in responses:
1) Please make the "drink the poisoned water," button and the "remove the poison from the water," button a different command. Sneezing should not be the difference between an objective and losing your 100+ hour permadeath save file to food poisoning. Jake has no survival instinct that prevents him from drinking the poison? Come on, guys. That's an easy quality of life improvement. 
2) A way to draw on the map would be great. I can make charcoal sustainably on demand. Let me use it to mark my bases and possible building sites, make a to-do list, things like that. If I have to spend charcoal to do that, then all the better - that's immersion right there.
3) Needing to get a bamboo stick for a mud water filter is understandable, but annoying when I have no idea where the bamboo is. Some indicator, maybe different shades of green on the map or something, to identify where bamboo groves are would be really beneficial.
4) If I start a new survival game where I just want to zen out on easy mode and build a full base like it's Sim City, I should be able to. I don't want to have to explore the entire jungle to get all the recipes just to experiment and build in a sandbox mode. I'm hesitant to experiment on my permadeath save file of course, but that's the only one I have where I have a full notebook.
5) The leech picking minigame is just plain annoying after a while. I've spent many hours in SoA at this point, and it's just annoying when I have to check every limb YET AGAIN. Let me get a recipe for a repellent salve, maybe whatever armor I'm wearing + ayahuasca berries or vines (giving them a use in survival mode since they're pretty useless there) or give me some way to edit the game's settings to turn them off. They don't even do that much to my sanity, they're inconsequential. Why not take this idea a step further and have armor modifications that give at least a small % chance to prevent snakebites, prevent rashes from hornets, prevent leeches? Maybe we do ayahuasca and get a token of some kind that lets us "enchant," our armor?
6) Fires attract predators and native goon squads. I get it. But I sure would love a way to signal to those natives that it's on sight, and I will make armor and soup out of their bones with no sanity penalty. I put rush delivery on arrows straight to the dome, same-day shipping straight to the ancestors. Let me build some kind of totem like they build, something that lets the natives know that I am the sole cause of depopulation in their villages with my confirmed body count.
7) I'm sick of chopping trees. Let me grow trees in the planting boxes or something, and let them feed sticks and logs and whatever into a set of stands automatically. Having to go chop the 9 millionth tree to build my base sucks, I'm ready for jungle automation.

Much love, devs.

---------------------------

Game's dope. But severely lacking an autosave feature. I'm not talking about Skyrim, where like every 5 seconds you get a safety save. I'm talking about major storyline events. When I drink ayahuasca, wake up and run straight into a goddamn gator and get death rolled, I should load back right after my trip. I'll do 1,000 things and bleed out from a jaguar and lose the 6 hours of progress I put into the game. I'm 20 hours in and I've already lost about half my progress. Now I'm all the fuck way back at the first camp and starting to not care anymore.

------------------------------------

Edit 1: Been playing for a while now. Holy shit, I hope you like chopping trees. After you've beaten the story mode, chilled in the DLC, played in the mud, there's not much else left to do. The gameplay loop ends a bit early, and once you've built a giant mud mansion, it gets boring. There's only so many leeches I can pull off and trees I can chop before the game just... becomes boring and repetitive.

A solid survival game with very dedicated developers.  I'm a sucker for a pretty game and GH has that beauty factor that makes it super immersive.  Realistic water is a detail that I judge every outdoor survival game on and this game is a 9/10 in that department.  The Spirits of Amazonia expansion is nuts!  I recently picked it back up after a break and didn't realize how much content I have left to play!  
PROS:
- Beautiful
- Take your time or speed run; either is fun
- Once you get the hang of crafting it's not cumbersome at all - pretty well designed
- Building mechanics are simple but work smoothly - everything goes together easy like lego
CONS:
- The weight system needs to be reviewed ASAP.  If I'm 1 pound overweight I shouldn't immediately start shuffling around at 1/10th the normal speed like I have Parkinsons for crying out loud.  Make it gradual and a large energy drain or something - don't giga-nerf the walk speed.  Frustrating.
- The jungle cats could use some work.  They don't run very realistically and their stalking mechanic is fairly basic, but not totally useless

If you like survival games, I HIGHLY recommend this game! It was definitely difficult at first and I died A LOT but once I got the hang of it, the game was incredibly fun. 

This game has a really great story line, crafting, foraging & collecting, cooking, tons of exploration, fishing, combat, base building (you can even grow plants and have animals at your base). I had a really tough time at first because there are SO MANY things that can kill you and I thought food was hard to come by but once you know what to look for and how to cure ailments, it gets so much better. I'll admit, I was close to quitting when I got bit by a rattlesnake, got worms from passing out 3 times on my way back to my camp, and then got attacked by a jaguar as soon as I got close to home. But again, once I figured out how to fight off everything, I was able to really enjoy the game. I highly recommend giving this one a shot and if you do, save as often as possible lol.
