Purchased this game with great expectations however like so many other people having the same issue the game crashes at random intervals causing loss of all progress. Unfortunately cant save game whenever you want as it requires a shelter to be constructed and you may be far away from it. I have a system that can run almost all other games on ultra graphics yet despite all efforts and assistance from Creepy Jar support there is no known solution or patch to resolve the issue at this time.
I have requested a refund and will re-purchase once crashing problems have been fixed.
The game itself shows good promise. Could do with more creatures / animals to encounter and even on Green Hell mode game is too easy. Tribesmen offer no real threat in combat and everything can be 1 shot killed.

Pros: 
#1:  Good competition for the "Forest games" 

#2: Decent story line and single/multiplayer Co-op player game. IF you don't cheat or use walkthoughs or even if you do "a little" (Like the map uploaded on the wiki or looking for a recipe for heated foods.. ) Still quite an involving story line if you are in specific "generation age group" (not that you have to be at all) You will enjoy the in engrossing story of single player, As well as the challenge. 

#3: Amazing graphics that is honestly not too taxing on your computer / hardware. (Even at low or medium quality settings) This helps with the immersion factor of the game and story line. 

#4: Mirrors the challenge to the user play style. (A rare-ish feature in a modern game) If you want to slow down and get down and gritty with the environment (Building a habitat to live in, farming plants, storing supplies for your next venture into the amazon ((How far this time into the unknown)) OR (no offence meant and maybe censored) "Balls-to-the-wall" aggressive approach to the story and the environment... well there's a place for you here too. 

#5: Decent sound track.  Few but important music ambiance. (I also agree with less music as it does distract from the immersion of you being alone (Kind of) in the middle of the jungle in near current times (2000s+). (Year technically unknown but sometime after 2005)

#6: Realistic sounds of everything. Creatures, Rain or other atmospheric effects, Weapons, the player moving though different environments (Sand, Forest floor, tree tops, bushes, water locations (Rivers and larger locations ((Ponds, Lakes,))  NPC  spoken words of both "Native speaking language (at least English(Story line dialog)) and non-native but ""native"" speaking voice sounds, (Hostiles calls of alert / scouting parties discovering your "Base" in the middle of the night while your nearby not sleeping and hunting a coconut (Yeah, you gotta try to find coconuts all the time. They are very usefull and essential for survival. ) 

#7: Custom difficult available in menus before start of game. This is a big one for me. I normally go for hardest settings when getting into any new game as it helps me learn the mechanics faster.. However, I completely understanding starting on easy or medium. This game takes it a step farther and really allows you to customize your experience down to finite detail. 

#8: Plenty of things to do. Explore, Build, Survive (Hopefully). Then after you master the game a couple of times: You may find yourself still playing doing some things in game you may have skipped your last play though. (Yep it's got some replay factors) 

#9: Multiplayer. Just wow. Well done, I could go into some detail here but its mostly personal and I wont bore you. I'll just leave it at: I can play both the story (Lots of it thanks to the "Spirit update") and endless "Lets see what we can really build and experiment with" modes with my young to old family members. (Serious fun if your into this type of game) 

The ability to see your teammates wounds and hand them a bandage you have one but they don't... amazing! As well as... (Wow just name another game that lets you do this action.....) Pull the leaches off your teammates body. Sheer genius!

#10: The devs are still involved even though its launched! Free and important DLC type materials for free! Patches! Forum and community involvement!  

#11: Real situations and tools that can teach you basic ideas on how to make tools in case you really end up stranded or alone in the wilderness. Game is possibly educational. 

Result: Worth the price especially if on sale if you enjoy this kind of game. 

Cons:

#1: There are still some building bugs. Oversize complex building normally results in failure. (Then again, SHOULD you be trying to build a extremely large or complex structure while in story mode when you are punching a clock so to speak (Of your own making) 

#2: Hostile enemies seem to be over powered when attacking your (Farms, Pens, Living structure, water purifier ect.. ) 

#3: Lack of real sleep due to your game level of involvement, (True to any game but worth mention as a disclaimer)

#4: Rattlesnakes. (They give this reviewer the hebie jebies) (You can turn them off in the custom gate settings mentioned above so this really doesn't count as a con... ) 

#5: Unclear map edges sometimes resulting in death without warning. Minor but annoying when you have a big open lake and you start to swim across it.. suddenly piranha death.  Sure you kinda know your going out of bounds but... they could mark that a bit more in the world or in the map so you can understand whats happening and why you are dying... so fast)

#6: Multiplayer death on any difficulty is bit harsh. Lose all your items (Half of which may randomly spawn at your death point and the selection of items also seems random) (Or so it seems) Loss of unique items (Steel Canteen) forever? Ouch since there is only one in the game it seems. 

Overall:
Great experience. Still playing it. Some annoying non game braking issues.

Conditional recommend: this game is probably not going to be for you if you aren't a patient gamer. 

Quick summary of story mode: a very slow-moving survival game with heavy emphasis on survival. You will get extremely tired of obtaining multiple different lengths of sticks, but the story was engaging enough to carry me through to the end, and it's definitely satisfying to work your way up to being capable of handling anything the game throws at you, after a rough start where absolutely everything is lethally dangerous. I finished the story mode in a leisurely, unhurried 40-ish hours, burning time on building out two different campsites and wasting a good chunk of that time wandering around, either lost or trying to figure out where the hell I was supposed to go next.

Longer thoughts: 

When I saw this game up for sale during Midweek Madness with a very positive review score I had to pick it up out of curiosity, because I remember when it first hit steam. I remember watching someone play it, and it had been basically unplayable. A lot must have changed to swing the reviews so far in the other direction, right?

It does seem like a huge amount of work was done. It's a very pretty game. It sounds good too, which is really important, because sound is crucial to knowing what wildlife is around you -- you certainly won't always be able to see through the dense greenery. The game gives you a good array of tools to survive, but it also hides them behind an experimentation system of combining random elements on a crafting stone in search of correct recipes that will have you eventually checking a wiki, whether you're a die-hard 'I want to figure it out for myself' person or not -- I am that kind of person, but eventually the guessing game wears thin on technicalities (example: you cannot make a bow drill with a stick, rope, and plank -- you have to craft the bow as a bow and then use the bow in the recipe). On top of that, there are some tools or structures you have to unlock by finding them out in the jungle, and there are a bunch that you'll want to use but which won't make sense to bother with, because the game sort of requires you to stay more mobile than that.

The inventory interface is initially pretty unwieldy and takes some getting used to, but after a while it becomes second nature.

I enjoyed the story. It walked the very iffy line of 'being a game where you're a white dude in the jungle murdering locals' very carefully and did a pretty okay job of it, imo, which can't have been easy. I cared about the outcome and the characters, and the story went places I didn't expect. There were some weird plot issues (I had no idea the MC had amnesia until well into the game?), but nothing major.

There are still bugs, like overlapping text, and a few irritating things that aren't exactly bugs but are UX issues. If you pick something up while crouching, you can't uncrouch until you put it down. If you're crouched when you trigger a cutscene, you have to go through the cutscene crouched, moving at a glacial speed. There's an awkwardness to highlighting items on the ground quite often. You are able to carry 6 leaves, max, but the smaller trees you will constantly have to cut down to make beds and roofs have at least 7. Your carry weight is in general a bit absurd -- things weigh questionable amounts, meat in particular.

None of these minor issues were enough to keep me from completing the story mode, though, and I don't think they'll get in the way of my interest in playing the survival mode and the DLC stuff. Actually, if I have any gripes with the game at all, they are two in number, and they are these:

1) Jake Higgins is a VERY unpleasant character to spend time with, especially early on, because every time his tool breaks, and every time he has to light a fire, he throws a FURIOUSLY ANGRY MANBABY TANTRUM about it. The amount of rage involved is so over the top that it was pretty hard to like him, tbh. Like sure, survival situations are stressful, but this man is sitting on the ground in the jungle yelling 'son of a BITCH!!!!!' at sticks at the top of his lungs. This gets less awful as time goes on because he begins to suck less at crafting things so his tools break way less often, but he carries on road-raging about fire lighting through the whole game if he's even the slightest bit tired.

2) The game has a robust construction element, with all sorts of buildings that help you to obtain or store resources efficiently, but the structure of the story mode is such that you'll have to abandon them pretty quickly. Eventually you realize it doesn't make very much sense to construct more than the bare minimum to replenish your supplies before you move on, and you'll find yourself spending a tedious amount of time building a simple square frame, leaf roof, small fire, and leaf bed in many different places as little waystations for you to save your game and sleep. It's really just the collection of the materials for it, and how many times you have to go through doing it, that makes it tedious.

At any rate, I'm looking forward to trying the DLC and then starting a survival game where I can actually make the most of the construction.

This is a very good game in many ways. The radial wheel menu took some getting used to, but once you get used to it it's fine. There are 4 maps, there is a lot to see. Try doing the pacifist achievement on the hardest level, it's fun and challenging. Also, there are "Challenges" which I found to be fun as well. The animals are great, I love the sounds they make, and the birds. Fighting the natives is challenging but not overly hard, it's fun, balanced. The big cats are beautiful. All the plants you can identify, heh, it's slight botanical. The story line games is good although I'm not a big story line player, the graphics were pretty nice...I guess, but I'm more a survival player. It might seem ridiculously hard at first, but it's not at all, even on the hardest level. Yes, it's challenging but not overly so, it's balanced so it's fun. The open world is reasonably big with hidden places requiring scuba gear, climbing gear, a grappling hook and a grappling hook gun. If you think you've seen it all, I bet you have not. There is one cave with six exits. And a gold mine. And some very convoluted underwater caves that I've still not mapped out 100%. One place there is no way up except to build a structure with ladders.

If you like survival type games, PLAY THIS, it's control system can be a little weird to learn at first, but the game has a cohesive story that is super cool, definitely start with the tutorial, as without it it is a little bit hard to figure out the controls.

The insanity meter is a bit hard to deal with as well. Don't eat cooked bugs or poisonous green frogs no matter how hungry you are.

Devs have put significant effort into making this a great jungle survival game. The little touches\the graphics are all top notch, if it wasn't for the epic bowl movement sound effects while jumping it would be a 5/5. i'll have to give it a 4.9/5. 

I hope the devs understand.

I'd recommend this to anyone who thinks they would like to spend some time dying in a jungle. 

despite pooping while I jump, i'll keep playing this masterpiece.
to day i dont fill like dodo in toilet on floor
Fun time waster.
help with bug reports way back; great game, amazing growth, and love from the creatures.... 5stars!
If you dont got friends. Mid. If you have people to get parasites in the jungle with. Pretty good. Leans on your friends pretty heavily though.

The story mode is great! I constantly and eagerly wanted to get to the next important location so that I could progress the story, so well done to the creators there. The sound design is also well done, and helps with building a fantastic atmosphere for the story mode. The ayahuasca sections are beautifully animated and are a real treat for the eyes. Jake gets really upset when he has to start fires or hasn't had a drink in 5 minutes. It's great.

The gameplay loop can get a bit tedious after you learn how to deal with each scenario, and it's also rather easy to avoid the dangers of the jungle if you are careful and listen closely, but it's still fun. I'd love a bit more diversity in the different sections of the jungle, it all starts to blur together after a while, but setting challenges for yourself or continuing the story helps with this. It's a good game to kill about 30 - 40 hours on, and you can play survival mode if you want a sandbox experience. I enjoyed it.

WARNING : this is more a simulation than a game.

I recommend this game, yes, but not for everyone. 
The big advantage is (and I really think it's an advantage), if you don't like your early experience, ask a refund because it will not evolve much.

Don't think it's "The Forest" but in the jungle, some mechanics are similar but the global experience is different (I don't even understand how some players compare this game to Subnautica it's like comparing Cyberpunk and Need for Speed, yes, you drive cars in both of them but that's it).

Is the gameplay good ? 
It is very well designed BUT it's basically you wandering in the jungle watching the ground, depending of the difficulty you choose 90% of the time you'll be walking; running is'nt realy an option or you'll end bit/hurt/scratched/dead/fainted.

There is 2 type of players, the one who will play the game as intended, having to test like a prehistoric man each ressources you'll find and most of the time ending being poisonned/wounded/dead; the other type of player will use the Wiki.
Using the wiki will save you A LOT of time but will cut the difficulty and by extantion the gameplay easily by a half (we can say it cut half the fun).

The craft system and the inventory are a pain in the ass (Jesus we're in 2023, having to manually sort your back pack is really necessary ?) BUT it's very complete; the last building update added a nice touch.

Is the story good ?
No, like most of the simulator, the story is just an excuse to make you travel.
Part of it is a patchwork coming through the early access and being adapted to the final form of the game at the release, it's why sometimes the tone of some vocal lines don't really fit between them or in the situation you are, it was readapted.

Is it difficult ? 
Not really, the whole gameplay is designed around frustration and self control (a little bit like a Dark Souls). 
If you fight your gamer instinct, stay focused on the ground, walking instead of running and beeing disciplined (checking your body, washing yourself etc) it's kinda  easy even in highter difficulties. 
At the very second you'll try to play a little bit faster, not beeing focused, try to shorcuts, ignore the basics mechanics or try a 70/30 chance the game will punish you most of the time.

Notes :
The developpers worked hard on the game since the early access and even uptdate some contents after the official release. For me it's a big plus.
Its a great game for every survial enthuiasts out there

HELL YES!! It has a good crafting system, the world seems real. Good job on the lighting and blending different things/assets on the world to create a beautiful surrounding. Combat is easy to learn, Managing yourself to be healthy is a good touch to the game, because it makes you feel vulnerable, unlike some other games you feel untouchable. All in all it is 10/10 for me :)
I finished the Original Game and also the DLC Amazonia

What can be improve?
- Enemy Champions
I found and killed one massive guy with TWO! Tribal Axes and that fight was amazing. Sadly he was the only one tall guy with a Mask. Would be cool to add more of those, making some fights difficult :)

- The Aztec Sword
It looks like it doesn't blend with the player like the other weapons. Also make it a bit bigger.

- Hand Movement
Maybe make the hands go up and down a bit, while moving and running. It should give the character a more realistic feel? 

- The Cats
The Big Cats are not that aggressive, they walk so slow that one arrow can one tap them. They should hide in tall/big plants or when they spotted you, they would run towards and attack. 

- Upgradeable Backpack? 
Maybe being able to create small pouches for certain things, even a Quiver for Arrows would be a nice addition to it :3

That is all what I can say for my side. Other than that it is a very good survival game.
the hell is green

Green Hell is an outstanding game. I haven't come across anything else that captures the feeling of having leeches suck on you, dealing with infected wounds, suffering broken bones, and fainting repeatedly like it does. The game is so immersive that it can feel like you're actually there, lying in the dirt, starving, desperately trying to stick a tobacco leaf to your open wound with broken fingers while a jaguar growls menacingly from the nearby bushes.
Definitely worth the price
awesome game
mmm capybara

Alright, so far as a survival game goes it's interesting, extreme, and inaccurate. . .
The crafting system is simple but made to seem overly complex by making everything a pain in the back side to do.
The graphics are very nice.

The story line is utter garbage. It basically boils down to this - mc writes a book, mc's girl is dying and runs up medical bills, mc goes with girl to jungle to find imaginary cure, cure some how turns into super virus . . .which apparently can be fixed with a venomous frog. . .oh, but you're too busy doing drugs to remember anything, or even do whatever you actually came to do. . .ending = you suck try again but you're still going to fail, but you're still going to suck as a human being. . .yeah, it's utter trash. 

Honestly it's very underwhelming and the only thing worth the price tag was the half arsed building and crafting, which could have been done better. . .same with inventory management, it's utter garbage. 

Devs need to learn that just because you make something look nice graphically it doesn't make it a good or user friendly system.  Just trying to set up a camp is a night mare of fighting with placement. . .

To be honest I'd place this game story wise on the same level as  blade and soul, meaning that it makes you want to off yourself it's so depressingly bad. The devs should be absolutely ashamed they put together such trash for a game and it's story line.


Honestly, the base building is cumbersome and seems like an asset flip to me. There are placement issues to the extreme, as you have to apparently cut down each individual blade of grass instead of the building clearing under brush when built. You can't put down a foundation for a floor other than five or more feet off the ground. Nearly all placement anywhere is yellow or red, so it won't place. Rocks are always in the way, you know, the ones which you could pick ax in real life but in the game you can only hopelessly stare at and think, 'well they put that in this nice flat area just to f you over for building'. There are no real roofing pieces. The bridge bits will only connect to existing buildings. . .and only in a half arsed manner. 

Honestly, I have no idea what people are praising about with this game when others like conan exiles, sons of the forest (which isn't even finished), 7dtd (which is a decade still in alpha), and so on did 100 times better.  The best part is that some how the devs think if you get a deep laceration that wrapping a leaf around it will prevent infection and heal it like a sterile bandage. It's quite apparent they know nothing about medicine, injuries, infections, herbalism, or even survival. The game was obviously just made to punish the player and nothing else. . . this is done by constantly injuring, infecting, etc. and making any sort of healing resources scarce. . .it's not a challenge, it's annoying.

It can be seen that I've played this nonsense for 55 hours, however, I just did it to make my dear friends happy after their limitless attempts to make me purchase this creature and play it. The producer just wanted to create a difficult game as the name includes "hell" in it but instead the game became some bullshit that only masochists play.

This is a tough game. If you want a challenge then this is the game for you. 

Pros:
- The game keeps you constantly moving and having to survive.
- The graphics are nice and clean. Are there a few things that could be fixed? Yes but that is with all games.
- The sound is decent and not over whelming or under played.
- At the time of this review I have not made it through the story line yet but so far it looks interesting.
- The controls are nice and smooth, but some of the aiming and getting stuck on things can be a pain.

Cons:
- The character you control dies way to easy. 
- The weight limit could be adjusted, and maybe it will be later in the game.
- On the medium level, there are attacks constantly from jaguars and from the tribesmen. Now maybe later on it gets better, but at the start I have fought the tribesmen multiple times and have yet to win a fight. I stabbed one of the tribesmen 4 or 5 times, did he die? Nope. The guy cuts me once and I bleed out right as his buddies jump in and defeat me. On another battle there was two of them. Once again I stabbed the guy with a spear 4 or 5 times and he just keeps coming. Then his companion jumps on me, hits me one time and I lose most of my life. I get it, they are supposed to be a tough group, but it shouldn't be so lopsided. I am pretty sure there is armor but I haven't figured it out yet. Was trying to avoid using the net yet.
- Some creatures show up way to much or they are to aggressive. My buddy and I were playing survival mode and it was like something out of a bad horror flick, the centipedes were attacking so often that we couldn't do anything without having to deal with them. I get that the devs were aiming to make it dangerous but some of the stuff is over done.

Overall at this point I would recommend the game. Some of my frustrations are due to the fact that I haven't learned everything yet and some are just small details like the combat but something tells me that it will get easier after I learn a bit more. After I get through the game and learn some more I will come back and will give an update to this review. Thank you for taking the time to read this.

This game has so many bugs I don't know how it is released. I purchased this game over a year ago, played it a while and put it down because of the bugs. Now I think it has even more bugs that it did before. Bugs where fruit doesn't grow, fire never goes out, mud mixer doesn't accept mud when empty, bow wont pull back, MANY text errors in the book and inventory where multiple texts are over one another and you can't read any of it. Items falling through the floor when placing them on the ground. Multiplayer doesn't update stats for non host. Many items from inventory gone in multiplayer when reloading game. It is very tedious adding wood to a burning fire or sticks to the furnace. Inventory management in your backpack is extremely annoying. You can't see the very bottom of the backpack so items can get lost there like fish bones and ants. At the very first tribal camp there is a bowl under the ground that you can add water into. You can see the icon pop up when you have a bowl of water in a certain spot.

This game is a beta game at the very least. I would not purchase this game for another year. Maybe they will finally get around to working on the bugs then.

I LOVE that you can customize the difficulty with the types of encounters you have, your health & energy decay, etc. I can appreciate the realism that the game was going for and it did make me change my game play style to try to adapt but it got frustrating for me because I just wanted to finish the story! I really like how sound-based this game is and headphones make it even more immersive. I still get freaked out by rustling after 60 hours - is it a dangerous creature or just a dang armadillo!? 

After a little customization I could finally move the story along (still plenty difficult to maintain health even on a low health decay rate if you don't plan ahead and be careful). The story is good. At times I felt an inkling of figuring out what was happening before it did, but it was overall interesting and left me thinking about what I would do in this situation. The main story took me about 30 hours. I'm onto the prequel now which feels more challenging and dangerous with the hostile tribes being more prevalent (there are still notes on what to do but it's not as clear). I found a familiar place from the main story and felt a gut punch of devastation knowing what happens in the future.

There is farming, which is good to try establishing quickly for extra food if you stay in mainly one spot and it's not too challenging to keep up with. I also caught a tapir and a peccary - maintaining one animal was okay, having two seems a little more involved with keeping them fed and watered, and I'm not sure I would get more than two at this point because I still have plenty to do in the story. It is nice to feel some extra companionship though. 

I have only built in the story modes so far. Building is tedious but ends up looking cool. There are only a handful of empty patches on the map that encourage building and expanding out gets iffy - I've had to destroy some frames after finding that roofs wouldn't snap and that sucks because you lose some resources when you destroy items. It would be AMAZING if there was a customization to increase the amount of resources you harvest so you could build faster. I have not tried a tree house or a floating structure yet but I'm looking to messing with those in survival after I finish the prequel.

Not a game for those with common sense. Very linear survival path, frustratingly so. Interface is incredibly cumbersome. Tutorial teaches nothing applicable to actual game outside of interface navigation as you lose all the supplies you were "taught" with in the tutorial.

Excellent, hardcore survival! As it would be in real life, sustaining even a minor injury in Green Hell's jungle is a life threatening experience. The game forces you to learn how to deal with infections, rest and healing very nicely, and working toward getting a little camp going and building a sense of safety for yourself is very satisfying.

Green Hell eschews the standard hand-holding of modern games in favour of emphasis on player knowledge itself, which I love. You don't get to hover your mouse over a plant to see what it is and what it can do; it has no name and if you want to see if it's helpful or harmful, you will need to experiment. Then, you can name it yourself. This philosophy underlies a lot of the game's mechanics which can, admittedly, at times be a little too obscure for my taste (trying to work out what you can craft by randomly combining things) but in general is a breath of fresh air.

The game's main story is quite good and definitely worth playing through, even though it does unfortunately sit quite at odds with the actual gameplay since it really discourages you from building a permanent base. At the end of the day, you can learn what you need to survive and basically always be on the move, foraging as you go and setting up temporary shelters when necessary.

The Spirits of Amazonia mode, afterward, lets you satisfy your base building desires at last, and has a number of other goals that encourage exploration.

Unfortunately, there are some things that don't work perfectly. Pretty much every resource can be found pretty much everywhere -- they're not always easy to find right away, but they're around. This means that aside from SoA's small quest/grinding system which encourages you to explore, there's not much reason to go far from your base in terms of raw gameplay mechanics. There was nothing I ever really found myself "needing" other than one freak 3 hour period where the plants you make bandages from just... weren't spawning anywhere for me.

Furthermore, the crafting does leave a little to be desired. There's a variety of tiers of tools and weapons, but the tiers are ultimately quite meaningless and aside from personal satisfaction there's very little functional reason to strive for anything better. You can make the essential things pretty early in the game, and then you're pretty much set. Even advanced crafting like forging with metal doesn't feel like it gives you much benefit, which is a pity because the detail in the crafting process itself is quite cool.

The same goes for the skill system, which feels a little bit tacked on. Most skills aren't really impactful in a significant way, so I honestly tended to forget there were even skill levels.

This kind of thing eats at the core experience. I had a grand base building project in mind, and began by making a very rudimentary encampment with one roof for shelter over a fire and no walls. It was all really fun to get going but once I finally had the resources to begin building my real base, I quickly realised it wouldn't actually offer me much functional advantage; I already had everything I needed and there wasn't really any way to progress further, aside from simply enjoying the aesthetics of a nice base with more room for storage. The raids of enemies on my base never seemed to involve more than 2 or 3 enemies that were easy to deal with quite quickly, so that sense of danger that should have wanted me to hide behind walls started to fade away too.

I guess in the end it would have been nice to have some more difficult enemies requiring some more advanced preparation which would in turn require a more sophisticated base of operations. But that's just me -- I'm not big on building for the sake of building, preferring a very functional meta-game, and if you love the creative side of base building games you'll still have a blast!

I still highly recommend the game because it's a really cool experience! I'm looking forward to playing again once I've forgotten everything!

Well then... Now played 17 hours all co-op, and up until very last hours I really enjoyed and liked the game, but now all the problems are just too many to ignore. 

First it seems like really well made survival simulation, and everything you do seems realistic. 
Inventory management you have to do somewhat manually, dragging and dropping, which I liked a lot. No pausing there either, so better be clear of those jaguars or what not. 
Crafting is fun and requires decent effort, and it is rewarding to see things getting easier with those tools you just crafted. 
Buildings require you to put needed materials in place, which I liked a lot, seemed like actually building.
It's dangerous out there! You'd better watch your step and listen your surroundings, it'll save your life, and that's always rewarding to see that your supreme survivalism just saved you!

BUT:
First issue we had with was somewhat related to rain. When it rains nonstop for days on end and your first thought (albeit it being a rainforest) is that its a bug, should tell you something about the game. It seems to be game mechanic, but all those little issues and oddities before made us think that it just broke. 
Then the crafting hit our faces: you get recipies AFTER you crafted something, and when you know you need this certain thing but lack the moonlogic... 
Next, after killed by that big cat, tooltip tells you to back away slowly and it will flee after few hits... well thats just BS. We NEVER encountered whatever feline without casualities. Also, first time we were able to kill it rather easily, last time it took MANY hits to kill, no any sign of wounded animal retreating. If you manage to kill the feline, most certainly it has scratched you bad, so you need to bandage up, and during you wound dressing, your loot just disappears in front of your eyes, so either skin the cat and bleed out, or survive getting nothing. Also, what are spears used for if anything you fight can get to hit you?

Then, when the wilderness seems to level up with your struggling efforts, is the final blow to survivalism for me: metal armor. What you do when you are in a jungle for few days? Well, basic survival 101, build a forge and make your self a metal armor. Really? Then, that pesky rattlesnake bites you despite you being clad to metal, and as nobody told you how to make antivenom, you try to frantically find some shroom or flower before dying in poisoning within 30 seconds AND losing that metal armor you spent hours crafting as the game mechanic dictates. And it was I who stood next to my dying friend and looked as most of the inventory just vanished in front of my eyes being upset. There's a ragequit for you. 

UPDATE
Finished the game now (sort of). Issues got bigger until the end, connection issues probably aren't the games fault, but syncing got really weird at times. When my friend lost connection and I kept playing, when she got back, all of the food in her backpack was spoiled (it really didn't take even 1 ingame day). Also stats were totally random, and places where she spawned back, at times in places where we hadn't explored yet. Also gear disappeared at times. 
Crafting and building wise there aren't much to discover after the very first beach. Metal armor carried me to the very ending so that most threats weren't but mere annoyances. Also, the bigger the base you want to build, the more problems it spawns, at times not accepting required items so that you need to find very peculiar angle to be able to install current bit. It's a shame, as building our settlement was the most enjoyable thing to both of us in this game. It is also a shame, that we spent many hours building, and at the end game you cannot return to them. 
Endgame also feels rather unfinished, being rather empty and without dangers and lore bits missing half of sentences. 
Final cherry on top of everything, game crashed on me at the end credits, so I didn't got the achievement my friend got...

I hope they will hone these things, as I can see the potential diamond.

UPDATE 2:
Updates and new stuff keep coming. Even after it's shortcomings, this is by far the best survival game there is.

Green Hell is a brutal survival game only because it is so punishing early game. Once you get past the tediousness of the early game it's just another open world survival game.  Three bars just for food alone, hydration, sleep, injuries, numerous ailments leeches, worms, venom and poison. While they have put together a in depth survival game, it has a rough execution. The harder difficulties are "harder" by making your character weaker and making dying more punishing. 

Beware of the surprise cheetah that will spawn behind a random tree and just come eat you. I understand the cheetah jumping me near the boars and capy locations but the random spawn in the middle of nowhere that happens more than it does near animals is absurd.

As for MULTIPLAYER, the survival system is a joke online. Food is already difficult to manage early game on singleplayer. The game just about forces you to die to reset your meters. Otherwise you'll be zombies fighting imaginary enemies until much later.

This rant being said, you can tweak a few survival settings to your liking. Six hours might not seem like a lot of time for a review but if you just ignore the early game issues you can push to late game real fast by just dying to reset your meters.

A great example of a survival game is one that takes into consideration the effects of eating raw bugs or human meat, leading to episodes of disorientation and confusion in the jungle.

This game explores clans and jungles, with many components of constructing and upgrading huts, hunting for food and avoiding poisonous plants and animals, and searching for and creating sources of freshwater.

I believe this game surpasses many other survival games in terms of realism and accuracy to what would be found in a real-life survival situation.

I haven't played much of the story yet, but from what I gather from the tutorial, the voice acting is very well done and the story about exploring the local tribes and their structures takes a nice creative direction amidst the survival aspect of the game.

The game has a multiplayer mode which is very enjoyable and can make survival more engaging and easier if you don't want to go through it alone.

I highly recommend this game, as I have experienced very few bugs and have enjoyed the time I have spent playing it.

I know this sounds confusing but the game is trying too hard to be 2 games at the same time.

Part 1:
It has hardcore survival aspects which are neat. Such as needing to check your specific limbs to see what is wrong to apply the appropriate remedy. You learn everything from trial and error. Such as, you do not know if things are edible unless you try it, what things work for rashes, etc. You have to up keep, proteins, thirst, fats, and carbs. Certain foods apply to certain areas. All of this would be fine if that was the main focus of the game was to survive while running through the story but you kind of have to do the second part as well in order to survive.

Part 2:
The game attempts to be a crafting game but it feels shoehorned in due to how overbearing the survival parts are. Shoehorned might be the wrong word here since the crafting behaves well but can become incredibly repetitive compared to other games in this genre. I thoroughly enjoyed and liked how the devs made the crafting parts a little more realistic in the sense of how one would build a structure in the middle of the Amazon. Many of the crafting things have to be "attempted" to learn them. There are no quests that may teach you new techniques. You can literally go through the whole game without ever knowing or learning how to make armor or other items.

Most games in this genre kind of encourage the player to make a base with all of the things they need. Adventure out for the next quest or unique materials, and then return with the bounty. Green hell is opposite in that you are often better off scavenging what you need while you move along to the next objective. Essentially the two mechanics end up fighting each other in the end.

I purchased and played the Forest before I bought Green Hell.  I not regret not choosing Green Hell first.  It is much more enjoyable.  It feel more polished, the building system is more used friendly, the "enemies" are more realistic and the graphics are better.  If you are trying to decide between the two games, I would choose Green Hell, hands down.
This game is a hell of a challenge, and is incredibly fun to play with friends. It's fairly complicated and has a rather steep learning curve, but it's a great time!

This is probably my second or third favorite survival series (the other two being Subnautica (the original only) and Raft). While Raft is much more casual / forgiving, Green Hell is not. It will definitely take you a few tries before you get the hang of this game and understand how to establish a foothold in the unforgiving jungle. The game literally throws you in all but naked and you have to figure out how to balance your needs (typical hunger, thirst) while avoiding or dealing with the inherent dangers that lurk in the jungle - everything from animals or dangerous natives to food poisoning because that thing you just crammed in your mouth looked a lot safer than it was. The graphics are great, the attention to detail is impressive, the mechanics and fundamentals are sound, and the game keeps getting awesome updates. Overall a strong recommend.

I greatly regret this purchase. There's much more entertaining survival games out there that doesn't have as many "Gotcha" mechanics. Running into 3 rattlesnakes in a span of 50 feet and then getting attacked by a Cougar doesn't make for compelling gameplay. All happened within an almost fresh spawn too. Tarantulas are also not deadly by any means, but this game sure does like to make them seem like it. The type of scorpions they have modeled in the game are also the kind with less potent venom and also not deadly. In any case, I'm sure the Amazon is quite deadly in general, but that doesn't mean it makes for good gameplay having literal landmines everywhere at any given point. There are audio queues for the danger, but you're usually already bit before you hear them. 

Everything in this game just feels cumbersome and time consuming with no payoff. The story mode is about the only thing that feels rewarding, but survival is just bland and boring. The plot is a bit all over the place, but the survival is well balanced in a brutal way, there are things more realistic than you expect (yes, you picking up a thing in your hands will add to your carryweight!) and you start to constantly weight certain risks against their rewards. The world is super fun to explore with distinct biomes, and somehow youll never find animals when youre looking, but when youre just trying to make it back to your nice leaf bed, they will find you, they will bite you and you will be putting maggots on your infected wound because you couldnt clean yourself because you passed out on your way to water from said animal attack. In short: good fun experience, finishing up the plot cost me about 30hours, but do not exclusively buy it for the plot, but its a decent add to the whole survival aspect.

The game has good gameplay and story. You can look at other reviews for information on that. I'm going to give you a list of things you should know [u]exclusively if you are planning to play co-op[/u] while avoiding spoilers. [b]TL/DR at bottom[/b]
[hr][/hr]
[b] Save System [/b]
The biggest issue we noticed was saving the game. There is next to [u]no autosave[/u] but you get opportunities to save at most structures you make, and using calendars at some world structures. Here's how it works and some things to note:

When the host of the session saves, their playerstate (health,hunger etc) and inventory, the world, and the story progression saves to the hosts computer, as it would in singleplayer. 

When clients save, their playerstate and inventory saves ALSO [u]to the host's computer. [/u]

Because all saving is done to the host's computer, to avoid any sort of save corrupting it's good to:
- Have the player with the most stable internet connection be the host, loss of host's connection will result in disconnecting clients and therefore their inventories will likely be reverted to when they last manually saved. (Having a high latency didn't seem to be an issue)
- Avoid players saving at the same time and allow each save attempt to complete before the next player attempts. (In the bottom right of the screen, there is a save icon that will disappear when it is safe for someone to save.)
- Avoid playing green hell when steam planned maintenance will occur during your play session. This occurs every week on Tuesday 11pm GMT. If the maintenance begins during your play session of most steam games, varying results may occur. In the case of Green Hell, the host will play fine. The clients, however, will receive an error message every time any type of save is attempted. This means that none of the client's save attempts will register during the entirety of the session, and the session should be closed to resume playing after steam services have returned.
[hr][/hr]
[b] Other [/b]
If a client's save is behind in the story for whatever reason, the client should be able to access any area the host can even if the tools required are not visible in the inventory.

I recommend that every player saves before attempting the finale. The game will warn you when it is about to occur and give you the option to postpone the finale. There is currently (and has been for years) a bug in which if clients disconnect immediately after beginning the finale, the clients will not be able to experience the finale (and receive the ending achievement) until the host has re-launched the session and attempted the finale with everyone present again. I recommend saving immediately before attempting the finale in the case that this bug occurs, which will allow all players to try again without losing progress.
[hr][/hr]
This is based off my experience with playing through the main story of Green Hell with one other player. Your experience may differ. Don't let these small caveats deter you from experiencing the game, we found it to be a positive experience regardless of losing some progress to these issues.

TL/DR: save often, but each player saves one at a time and don't play during steam maintenance.

way too difficult at normal difficulty. game mechanics are designed to keep punishing you when you're already struggling. find a different survival sim.

EDIT:

Upon further review I have to say on the whole, this is a good game and I would recommend it. 

However, the player condition system needs to be revamped. There are certain scenarios where getting injured or poisoned is essentially a death sentence with no way out of it. Great example is the jaguar/worm mechanism. If you get torn up by a jaguar, you need at minimum 2 anti-infection bandages (usually 4, I've never been attacked by a jaguar and had less than 3 lacerations as a result). If you use regular bandages, you're almost 100% guaranteed to get infected. If you get infected and develop a fever, you have a very small amount of time to gather the additional resources needed to craft more bandages to heal your wounds and stop the fever.

If you don't get the resources needed, you'll pass out and wake up with worms and a very small amount of energy until you pass out again. Depending on your macros, your health may have already started draining at this point or will begin to soon. Now you have a very small window of time to continue to find the resources needed to craft bandages to start to heal and the additional resources now needed to remove the worms.

Can't find the resources you need in about 60 seconds? Guess you'll just have to pass out again and lose more macros and health. And god forbid you leave the worms in because your sanity will be gone in about an hour of game time. At that point, hallucinated warriors will attack you and somehow cause real damage (???).

At this point, having 60 seconds of play time between passing out, you're fighting off hallucinated warriors, trying to keep your macros up (possibly getting parasites in the process, a whole other system I didn't even mention), trying to find materials to craft bandages and trying to find materials to craft worm picks. 

It literally becomes impossible and the devs would be well served to consider revamping the condition system so the different systems don't stack and it becomes impossible to survive.

TLDR: Good game, but player condition system is broken af.

[h1] Okay, what is this game? [/h1]
[b] Surely, it's a gem, which needs polishing a bit. [/b] The game is great - you play as Jake Higgins, who is a doctor who tries to find a cure for his wife, while going adventures and exploring the jungle. That's all about story, because [b] story - in my opinion - isn't good or bad, it's in between these. [/b]
Okay, so what made me to give positive review to this game? I'll explain: [b] the game is kinda hard - but it's what it's when you're a man who is just thrown into the jungle, who tries to survive and to find his beloved wife. [/b] Game does it well. It has a steep learning curve, but when you understand the basics, the game is just pretty simple. You need to fill 3 macronutrients indicators, take care of your health and sanity. The game punishes or rewards you for every choice you make. Every plant/animal (as food) is unknown and gives other effects while eating. Some may lower your hunger, some may lower your sanity, and some will make you dead/vomit.
Okay, so I pointed (in short) eating and surviving above. [b] Let's go to survival aspects - combat, building, crafting. [/b]

[b] [u] Combat [/u] [/b]

So as I stated above - the game is hard (everything tries to kill you, even your wrong choices can make yourself as enemy).
But there are other dangers you need to fight: tribals (not hard, but they always attack in groups so it may be hard, when your only weapon is spear); big cats (jaguars and pumas); caymans and piranhas; snakes, spiders and scorpions. Combat is pretty simple - every headshot ends in a kill. And if you hit (by hitting/throwing) any other part of the body - enemy will bleed out soon. [b] So combat is pretty simple, you only need to maintain your stamina, block and hit. [/b]

[b] [u] Crafting [/u] [/b]

[b] Crafting is pretty simple - it's intuitive [/b] - you want a spear? [spoiler] Okay, so you need to put 1 stone blade, 1 long stick and 1 rope. [/spoiler] That's all, every item you make is saved in your notebook. All you need is to find new blueprints (found when exploring the jungle and finding new items/constructions) and you need to collect new materials (for example, to unlock bamboo things, besides those made of wood).

[b] [u] Building [/u] [/b]

[b] Building might be a chore, depends on how big things you build. [/b] Almost every construction needs long sticks or logs (so you need to cut down many trees to make a big building for example). [b] The way you build is great, [/b] you just put your plans, and fullfill them - step by step - with the items needed. The only bad things (besides the one said above) are that constructions don't stop rain animation inside the building and animals just "penetrate" them. And to add to the end, you need a lot of flat surface to build - the game is just lacking flat surfaces; you need to clear the surface from almost all plants and trees before you can build on it. [strike] I need to add that they forgot to add the option to just chop down the fallen logs (I mean the short ones, not "footbridges"). [/strike]

[b] [u] Performance and graphics [/u] [/b]

[b] The game is made by small a studio, using Unity Engine, so optimization isn't good, but it's not that bad. But the graphics are stunning - seriously, everything looks just beautiful. [/b]

[h1] Overall rating: 7/10 [/h1]
As stated before, [b] the game is great, but isn't perfect, [/b] the optimization could be better and there should be more mechanics and items (but [b] the studio is still working on adding new content so it looks promising [/b]).
[b] Pros: [/b]
- graphics,
- mechanics,
- great survival,
- crafting system.
[b] Meh: [/b]
- story,
- survival mode (I didn't know where to put it, but [b] survival is just great, BUT [/b] if you played story first, then you'll wander around the same map, searching for the same items and blueprints (just in other places) and after achieving all your goals (for example building a big base), the game just feels kinda boring.
[b] Cons: [/b]
- optimization,
- building,
- slow development,
- it's grindy a bit and monotonous.

[h1] DON'T WORRY ABOUT THE MOTION BLUR! YOU CAN TURN IT OFF IN GAME OPTIONS, IT'S NAMED AS HEAD BLOB OR SMTH LIKE THIS! [/h1]

If you like survival craft building games get this. I was unsure of this game for a while because I didn't want a frustratingly impossible experience while I built. In my experience it is challenging but not nearly as frustrating as I thought it might be. You just need to fail for a few hours, then it all becomes pretty natural and satisfying.

They still need to add a lot more for builders to enjoy, but it is a lot of fun to me as is.

One of the most realistic (as far as games can be) survival games which includes many dangers or tropical survival (from ants to poison plants to just dirt) that most other games ignore. Graphics are very good but not AAA level, but realism is cranked to 11. 20-30 hour story line and then hundreds of hours of exploration and building.
If you like The Long Dark and Subnautica, this will also be your jam.

I'm a bit shocked this game has such high reviews. I found the majority of this game to be hugely annoying but I suffered through it with a group of 3 others. I started on hard difficulty and then we switched to normal because managing your "macros" along with the various health issues is beyond frustrating.
First off I had the impression this game was similar to The Forest where there's enough content that its worth building a base and exploring from there, but there's honestly not. There's no cave systems or anything interesting to the map and while the map is "open world" its really VERY linear in how you progress the story (literally just follow the paths through the jungle.) 
Base building is a waste of time and incredibly annoying as there's no real way to efficiently transport the resources needed to build anything beyond a simple hut. And Tribesmen destroy most structures in a few hits, wasting any of the time you spent gathering and building. There's no real need because you can just progress the story, which refills all your different health bars at certain points. If you do only the story stuff there's probably like 5 hours worth of game play tops. Combat in this game is completely meh, playing on normal AND hard we barely ran into any Tribes or predators. 
The way you interact with the world from things like fireplaces for cooking to building and crafting, to checking yourself for cuts or leeches is just straight up annoying. 
I also found the characters in the story to be incredibly grating, especially when you start losing sanity and your consciousness starts yelling at you with no breaks until you get your sanity back up. The story is just bad and any of the twists were so obvious.
This game sucks. Again, I'm shocked the reviews were so high. It's way too similar to The Forest and it's worse in literally every single conceivable way. I wouldn't even consider the "macro" mechanics or various health ailments to add any level of difficulty or interesting mechanics because it becomes easy once you learn where different food items are, and all the differently ailments are 100% avoidable once you learn what causes them (except leeches or cuts.) All this stuff just serves to make the game incredibly annoying.

I wrote this long ass review but if I had to sum it up in one word, I would say it's ANNOYING.

8.5/10 Great.

The game can seem quite difficult when you start. But once you know what you're doing and learn all the basic treatments and food you need it's great fun. Exploration is a 10/10. Although I recommend just stay put at your first camp for atleast a week before you start to explore widely. That way you will have resources and better understanding of what you are dealing with. 

Remember, the more time you spend in the jungle the less of a prey you become.

Story, Exploration, Survival Mechanics, Environment design are all pretty much on point here.
I would've liked to see more and better combat with the tribals or predators. Currently it's meh but since this isn't a combat focused game it isnt too bad.

I love this game! It's so immersive and realistic, difficult but doable. There is a lot you have to learn by experience and I like that... I did end up watching a few videos online for a few tips/tricks but by then I knew most of them except the most difficult (or bizarre) ones! Play with others, it makes it 100 times better!

This has been a roller coaster experience so far! Playing with a friend has been fun, but still challenging. The startup is very difficult. You have no knowledge of how plants or foods will affect you. You ate something with dirty hands? Parasites... All of this going into the survival aspect has been pretty cool. You also aren't eating food in general for your survival. Players need to eat various foods to have appropriate nutrients. Basically everything is out to kill you...
We have progressed some of the story which seems to be pretty interesting so far. All-in-all I do recommend playing if you enjoy a dynamic survival experience. Especially with friends! 

**Heads up** 
The game still has some bugs, but so far nothing we couldn't play around. It seems the devs are actively working to make this a better experience all around so hopefully those are resolved soon!

Played the game, beat it, got both endings. 

I feel like this game could have a *lot* more building aspects. They just now added a door, you know? There's not a lot going on, for a survival building game. And you're discouraged from building where ever, instead having these little clearings all over the map where you are encouraged to build. 
Tribes people will come and wreck your stuff at random, where in you'll have to rebuild, so that's kinda nice. They also attack you at random or jungle cats will. So it's not a boring game, there are challenges and thought behind it. The map isn't massive, but it's pretty darn big. It is absolutely beautiful though, lots of plants and trees and brush, tons of things to keep an eye out for, like critters in and out of the water. Running through the jungle haphazardly isn't a good idea, you can trip over any manner of things, like rattlesnakes. 

Story is pretty good. The voice acting is on point, and the pacing for said story is very spread out but not so much you're ripping your hair out. It obviously has an underlying message for the masses, but all in all, it's a very good game. If they add more things to build of substance, I would say this is a game I would buy off sale. For now, though, on sale would be my recommendation.

TLDR: Boring game, with beautiful terrain, and what feels like a stick figure character (looks and feels like ****)

Bought the game 2 years ago... did something I NEVER do, and waited to give it a review, to give them time to build the game up more...

Came back yesterday... played all day yesterday, and all day today (couldn't have been more excited for the build update)... and both days had the same thing in common... I was forcing myself to play... to justify having (once again) wasted money on a EA title, simply because my thirst for the genre (which remains unquenched)

The game is extremely slow, the progression feels horrible, the game itself feels empty (in terms of things to do)... I spend 20 minutes working to make/craft/build X item, and when I'm done crafting it feel almost 0 satisfaction... and it's like ugh, well that was a letdown now what... do it again, same result (for 2 RL days worth of gaming)... 

The game is very beautiful... but somehow at the same time feels extremely outdated visually... It feels just so... clunky... trees, mountains, terrain... while very simple, LOOK GREAT... the player, it's movement, it's resource management (watch, build, "Inspect") all look horrible, and feel SO weighted, like they're just weighing you down with ugly boringness.... 
I said in my TLDR, and it's the only way I know how to describe it... the character FEELS like you're playing a stick figure... everything feels so... idk rigid? the moments, the visual of it all just... idk heavy? clunky?.... Picture in your head you're in a very realistic survival game... but your character is a gingerbread man... you know how they would walk, if you watched them in a cartoon or w/e? that's what playing this character (game) feels like to me (which is clearly my biggest gripe, based purely on how long this description is XD)
Even the way the character moves... it's SO robotic... he holds his arm up to inspect a scratch like he's a robot, or calling for his drop pod to beam him up

I ALWAYS base my reviews (good or bad) with... If I could get my time & money back.... would I do it... I absolutely would, which means I cannot recommend this game

I've given this game a 6 hour shake so far with a buddy, and I honestly just don't really get the point. I do typically have this happen with most survival games, but only after 100+ hours.  Maybe it's just 1 too many meters to keep filled or a lack of resource availability, but after about an hour of playtime, we just started letting ourselves die to get rid of the worms and infections because, for some reason, birds and small animals don't have bones you can use to make bone needles?  
I also had a problem where the texture of the forest floor has sticks and stones and leaves, but you can't interact with them.  It's weirdly hard to find very basic "forest stuff" in this rainforest.  Why am I not flush with sticks and stones when I can clearly see them in the textures all around me?  Also, why does a basic, small fire take so many resources to make if those resources are going to be that hard to find? 
We bought this game hoping it would be our next survival game we stuck with for a while, but I'm just not feeling this one.

Green Hell is a survival game set in the Amazon rainforest. Players take on the role of a researcher who has crash-landed in the jungle and must survive against the elements, wildlife, and his own sanity. The game features realistic and detailed graphics, as well as an immersive sound design that creates a sense of isolation and danger. The gameplay is challenging and requires players to manage their hunger, thirst, and health while also gathering resources and building shelter.

One of the strengths of Green Hell is the game's attention to detail, with realistic and accurate depictions of the Amazon rainforest and the creatures that inhabit it. The game also features a unique "mental health" system where the player's mental state will affect their gameplay, such as hallucinations and paranoia. The game also features a story-driven campaign and various survival modes, such as a "permadeath" mode that adds to the game's replayability.

Another strength of the game is the crafting system, where players must gather resources and craft tools, weapons, and shelter to survive. The game also features a day and night cycle, and weather effects, which adds to the realism and immersion.

Overall, Green Hell is a challenging and immersive survival game that offers a unique and exciting experience for players. The game's attention to detail and realistic depiction of the Amazon rainforest make it stand out among other survival games. The game offers a unique gameplay experience, with the added feature of mental health system and a story-driven campaign. It's a game that is not for the faint-hearted, but for those who want a truly challenging and realistic survival experience.

Green Hell is unforgiving. Even though I love playing this game! It's a thrilling challenge to stay healthy while racing against the clock. At first it can be overwhelming, but with practice, you'll quickly become familiar with the plants and animals, and learn what to listen for and what to avoid. Once you have a base established, you have more time to focus on other goals. It's a great feeling to have a secure base, but you need to be prepared to defend or abandon it if necessary. It's a fascinating balancing act!

Creepy Jar have crafted a truly remarkable survival experience with Green Hell, which wonderfully captures the sense of loneliness and peril that comes from true isolation. Players are presented with a range of ways to enjoy the immersive jungle environment, and the game's well balanced challenges and user friendly approach make it accessible to everyone regardless of their familiarity with hunger and thirst mechanics. There's plenty of fun and excitement to be found in this forbidding jungle, and it's sure to provide an unforgettable experience.

The difficulty of Green Hell is touted as a selling point, but in some situations without logical application of  the games mechanics, it can sometimes feel more like a tedious chore than a creative sandbox survival game. Still: Would buy again!

Green Hell is a really hard game, for all the right reasons, and in a way I've been wanting more survival games to follow. You start out with nothing and level 0 stats. Axes break after a few swings, your bow aim will sway tremendously, and you'll be lacking many late game blueprints. The game has a backwards learning curve.. I think the first seven days are the hardest and make or break a playthrough. After some time I wasn't dying nearly as much and was hitting headshots with the bow super quick, even got kitted out with some nice armor. The deeper you go and the better tools you get, building and managing food supplies gets easier. Not that you're ever overpowered, the worst thing you can do in this game is think that. You'll start runnin around, let your guard down for second and bam. Get bit by a rattlesnake, too tired to build a bed to sleep the fever off and too far from home. You pass out on the ground, wake up with worms, barely any energy, dehydrating and you're already about to pass out again. Good going, hero. 10/10 experience, making it to the end was an achievement. Free dlc is only a bonus. (finished the story at 45 in game days)

The title doesn’t lie. It’s a hell playing this game. But with time you’ll learn how to heal and avoid dangers. The story is not bad at all if you make it through the first 2-3 in-game days. You have to learn how to create a stone spear, axe or other tools/weapons, while you have to learn blueprints to construct a log bed or any other base constructions. There’s not much to explore. The search for unknown orange fatty nuts made me progress in the game. 

You have to drink, eat meat, eat fats, and eat carbs, while you get tired and actions require a certain amount of stamina, which is also reduced by exhaustion. You can’t ignite a small bonfire or hunt if you’re too low on stamina. Then, you have to find mushrooms to avoid death or eat anything with «energy». You can’t just sleep anywhere without concequences, but you’ll likely fade and get parasites under your skin, which leads to infection. Even an untreated wound would likely lead to a deadly infection. Therefore, you need to prepare dressings and sleep off the ground or near a fire. One preparation is the ash dressing, another is a dressing that treats poison bites. Poisoning will make you thirsty and make you loose energy rapidly. You’ll get fever. You need to prepare something over a bonfire, but you won’t make it if you haven’t already lit a fire and there is water nearby. And you’re likely to meet both somewhat aggressive tribes if you stay near them and stalking predators (throw stones or learn to use the bow gradually). With three ash dressings you can survive a Leopard attack, but the problem is getting the Molineria leaves in the first place and the ash isn’t readily available before the bonfire burns out. If not, it’s perhaps better to get covered by rashes creates by ants or bees and slowly turn insane instead, perhaps combined with leaches? After a few days more things will spawn like the coconuts. But you won’t necessarily find ecactly what you need, so look for orange, red or blue mushrooms. 

The main game isn’t a big challenge compared to the extra content. There’s a lot to do in the three parts of Spirits of Amazonia. The first part is a grind, the next one is getting better, and the third is actually the background for the main story. But very few will make that far. It’s a hard extra game. You won’t make it if you get bitten by snakes, spiders, scorpions, and stingrays. So you have to construct bases where you can sleep, so you can retreat quickly. Or else, you can’t make it. You won’t go very far before you’re bitten. It’s unavoidable to prevent poisonous bites because you lose your concentration after 30 mins. So how do you go through the game?

You won’t. And that’s exactly what the insanity is about.

I died again and again and again, but every time I revived, I learned more about the jungle, and eventually I memorised every mushroom, herb, etc. that could give me nutrients or kill me. This game is brutal, but I'm glad I bought it.

If you say you like survival games but don't play this then no you don't. This is the trail blazing standard all new generations of the survival genre need to follow closely behind or get lost in the dust. Concepts, some of which may not be new on their own, brought together into this immersive world blow any similar lost in the wilds game out of its respective safe to drink leech free baby bottle water. Imagine for a second if Farcry Primal was actually good, if Don't Starve was hard, if Rust PVE was a thing.  Checking and treating your limbs alone for damage in the way done here throws away decades of "health items" and super player wolverine crouch to heal gobbledlygook. Mini map, or map with player indicator, hah you mean learn cartogrophy and spatial memory skills. Best of all unlike so many even newer released games ITS STILL BEING UPDATED. Good, this is a world and framework worth expanding on and experiencing and if you don't then you'll have missed out on what I have to believe is the new gold level standard for survival games. Feels like freakin schiffbruch 2002 in here. Thank you for existing.

So far I've been highly impressed! Absolutely cant wait for more. Between the stunning scenery and level of detail that has gone into the functionality of this game is incredibly fun. I can see myself getting lost in this with extreme highs and lows as things progress and life in the jungle seems to take over. The sense of a strong learning curve is there, but that's a huge part of survival. You have to learn and adapt to your surroundings and try new things. Green Hell is a survival game set in the Amazon rainforest. In the game, players must gather resources, craft items, and build shelters in order to survive against the various dangers that roam the land. One of the things I enjoyed the most about Green Hell was playing with friends and watching each other die in hilarious ways.

One of the standout features of Green Hell is its immersive gameplay. The game is set in a beautiful, procedurally generated rainforest that players can explore and discover hidden secrets in. The crafting system is also robust, allowing players to create a wide variety of items and structures in order to survive against the dangers of the forest.

Playing Green Hell with friends added an extra layer of enjoyment to the game. We had a lot of fun watching each other die in silly ways, whether it was from falling off a cliff or getting attacked by a venomous snake. The game's multiplayer mode also allows players to help each other out by sharing resources and building structures together.

In terms of presentation, Green Hell is solid. The graphics are good, with detailed character models and environments. The sound design is also well-done, with realistic sound effects and atmospheric music.

Overall, Green Hell is a great survival game that offers an immersive gameplay experience. Its beautiful rainforest setting, robust crafting system, and enjoyable multiplayer mode make it a must-play for fans of the genre. The game's challenging gameplay and hidden secrets also add to the replay value. I had a lot of fun playing Green Hell with friends, and I can't wait to jump back in and cause more hilarious deaths.

easier than it looks

Green Hell is challenging and fun. The challenge comes from needing to keep track of many things at the same time. The jungle is full of danger and you need to look and listen for spiders, anthills, beehives, snakes, hostile natives, jaguars, caimans and pumas. At the same time you need to forage for nuts, fruits, coconuts, and medicinal plants. On top of that you are constantly managing your carbs, proteins, fats and water nutrition meters and your energy, health and sanity meter.

I like that Green Hell is not grindy. Building a base can be done in 10 minutes if you're experienced, it is not necessary to spend hours collecting materials. The only thing that requires time is the mud brick buildings and iron tools. But they're not necessary to complete the game.

Green Hell really doesn't hold your hand. A lot of times you have no idea how to progress without looking online. You need to be observant and clever to get the "good" ending. And you will die a lot when starting. I recommend Green Hell to anyone who likes challenging survival games. 

NB There is a permadeath "Green Hell" difficulty in this game. Do not skip the cutscene at the end because that will crash the game. Thankfully I can resume at a save point but I still lost half an hour of progress

I had little expectations going into this game. I started with the tutorial (highly recommend to learn the basics how to survive in this game), went into the story mode on normal difficulty, and was instantly drawn to knowing what happens next. It felt like I was part of a great Netflix show that I couldn't stop watching, but instead I was playing a role in it; I was hooked. The story line does great at introducing certain aspects of survival and key things to look out for. Every time I pushed out of my boundaries to try to race to finish the story I was harshly reminded that survival was the #1 priority and I had to constantly make sure I was taken care of first before venturing out into the dangerous jungle. I learned very fast, that there are a lot of things out to kill me, even my own body. The story is amazing, I loved the ayahuasca trips, and quickly fell in love with the characters. I can't wait to finish the story and try different ways to play the game. So far I've only played singleplayer, but I'm already recommending friends to pick up this game so we can play together!

I was really excited to try out Green Hell, with my boyfriend, but unfortunately, my experience with the game was pretty disappointing :/

The graphics are decent, but the gameplay is frustrating and repetitive. The survival aspects are unrealistic and the controls are clunky. The crafting system is also confusing and not very user-friendly.

But the biggest issue I had with Green Hell is the bugs and technical issues. The game is riddled with bugs that can range from minor annoyances to game-breaking issues. And even when the game is working properly, the frame rate can be choppy and the loading times are unbearably long.

I am not reccomending this. There are way better survival games out there that are far more enjoyable.

good game 9/10

[b]The good[/b] 
- Beautiful jungle and pretty graphics
- Love the exploration as you have many things to find and you really feel lost in the jungle
- The survival elements are fun and expansive
- Decent basebuilding, do not expect The Forest level of basebuilding, but that is to be expected as this game goes for a more realistic vibe
- Game is a bit Trial and Error in the beginning. When you know what each mushroom, plant and animal does. The game generally is pretty easy going with tons of food everywhere

[b] The not so good/bad[/b] 
- The inventory, checking your body and crafting can feel kind of clunky from time to time
- The kids you have to carry with the Spirits of Amazonia expansion... Who came up with the idea to let them scream constantly?!  
- No auto-save or save option when I want to save (only at your base)... Too many times I had to replay 30 min of gameplay due to dying to something stupid. Hidden snakes and spiders giving you poison and with no anti-venom plant in the area = death. The fever is too heavy, draining stamina/hydration way too fast. For example: when you step on snake number 249 you can get rid of the poison rather quickly if you have the right plant leaves to eat, but to get rid of the fever you need more advanced things to get rid off, stuff you usually will not have. Also fever kicks in insanely fast and makes your hydration and stamina drop to nothing in mere minutes. Being in the middle of the map, the fever gives you almost no chance to get to your base that is in the south of the map. And believe me, the map aint that big. Add a jaguar that in 9/10 cases comes out of nowhere and you can reload the last save before you head out on your exploration trip 30 min ago.

All in all a fine game but with some frustrating elements

Edit: Guess I should give a real review. I really do enjoy this game. It encourages you to go slowly, but you're in a constant race against the clock to keep yourself healthy, at least in the beginning. It can be crazy difficult at first, but once you've learned the plants and animals, what to listen for, what to avoid, and established a bit of a base, you start having time to focus on other goals. You really feel the benefits of having an established base; but at the same time, you have to be ready to defend or flee it. 

Head shots are satisfying. Tool and weapon use feels solid. Crafting is pretty intuitive. The map is interesting and beautiful. I like that you have skill gain as you use items. The seriousness of even a minor scrape is appropriate to the environment. Seasons have an impact on game play.The story is also interesting, though I admit I haven't followed it all the way as I get sidetracked by base building.

Building is occasionally frustratingly buggy; I do hope that the upcoming building patch addresses some of the issues. But the structures feel realistic to build and they've got a decent balance of resources needed for each structure, though I could do with less reliance on long sticks. And I wish we could reinforce our structures to last longer against attack.

Fantastic game; I highly recommend it.
