llevo jugando unas 9 horas en modo superviviente repartidas entre varios dias.
por ahora el juego tiene buenas ideas pero esta repleto de errores tanto anti realistas como absurdos.

primero la performance que tiene el juego es muy exigente, no tengo una pc mala necesariamente. puedo jugar practicamente lo que sea en un rango de fps pasable. juegos de muy alta gama me corren perfecto si no pongo todo en alto.
en este juego los fps maximos que llegue fueron 30. lo que seria jugable y de hecho por gran parte del juego lo es, si no fuera porque todo tipo de cascada o fuego que se carga me parte en dos la computadora. por sacar una antorcha prendida y ponerla en la mano me quedo en 15 fps. esta horriblemente optimizado. las fogatas me bajan un poco menos pero siguen siendo una zona de lag. las cascadas se las aguanta un poco mas y puedo pasar sin mucho problema.
si tenes una computadora de la nasa, el juego seria mas disfrutable.

El mayor problema viene cuando tenes que ir de tu base a un lugar y no volver.
obviamente tenes que tener la salud y los macros altos, cosa de no morir de inanicion en mitad del camino.
pero me genera mucha irritacion lo falso que es la expectativa de vida de un humano saludable armado con lanza y machete. a los pocos metros ya tenes que estar esquivando serpientes, bicho que si te pica tenes que reiniciar el juego o vas a jugar en una ENORME desventaja la cual no vale la pena. y si no lograste guardar una benda estas condenado a muerte. 
bueno ponele que eso tiene sentido, que no te pique una serpiente, que por sierto se ven mas pequeñas de lo que son, al menos las que te matan de una. pero mas alla de eso, el personaje tiene unos problemas para caminar graves. si baja de una piedra de no mas de 4 metros de alto, se rompe todo sin ningun sentido. si hay algo que un hominido hace es trepar, que un decendiente de primate no pueda bajar 4 metros sin lastimarse me parece un chiste.
despues tenes el problema de que no podes correr. a los 3 trotes el señor no puede mas y quemaste todos los macros. no me parece ni cercano a la realidad. tiene sentido que correr con el peso de una mochila te canse, pero si yo que soy un sedentario asqueroso tengo mas aguante que un tipo que se fue al amazonas solo. es claro que no tiene mucho sentido.
la cosa que mas bronca me da es cazar animales vivos. primero no puedo acercarme sin que salgan corriendo a 1000, claramente logico hasta cierto punto. es un poco exagerado que todos corran como si supieran que los vas a degollar al minimo contacto pero por motivos de balanceo ponele que esta bien.
ahora la unica forma de cazar es o con arco y flecha o arrojandoles un arma. 
aca es donde el juego pierde toda logica y realismo, me frustro y cierro el juego para escribir un tomo de la biblia en steam.

Positives:

● Immersive and realistic gameplay: Green Hell puts players in a challenging and realistic jungle environment, where they must gather resources and craft tools in order to survive. The gameplay is intense and immersive, and the various survival elements add a lot of depth to the game.

● Beautiful graphics: The jungle environments in Green Hell are beautifully detailed and realistic. The character models are also well-designed and the various creatures and animals in the game are all very well-animated.

● Interesting story: Green Hell has an interesting and well-written story that adds a lot to the game's overall atmosphere and immersion. The game does a great job of introducing new elements and twists as you progress through the story.

Negatives:

● Difficult gameplay: Some players may find the survival elements of Green Hell to be too challenging, as you'll need to carefully manage your resources and make sure you're always prepared for the various dangers of the jungle.

● Repetitive gameplay: Some players may find that the gameplay becomes repetitive over time, as you'll be doing a lot of the same tasks (such as gathering resources and crafting tools) over and over again.

● Glitchy: Some players have reported experiencing various bugs and glitches while playing Green Hell, which can be frustrating.

A generally pretty solid survival game with some mild, non-supernatural horror (or at least very dark) elements, though these are more in the context of the plot than the scene-to-scene gameplay. The difficulty curve interestingly hinges to a large extent on your familiarity. If you were to start without reading any guides or walkthroughs and just plunge in, a huge number of deaths are to be expected. But once you know what types of medicine treat what injuries (or how to avoid them in the first place) and what's safe to eat and under what circumstances, it becomes quite easy. I'm honestly unsure whether to recommend reading any guides in advance or just enjoying the grisly process of discovery!

There are two main campaign modes that use the same map, namely the main game and the "Spirits of Amazonia" prequel. There's some missing context in the main game that you uncover as you go which I might say is worth experiencing first before trying Spirits of Amazonia. Generally, I found it to be pretty satisfying. The base building is very rigid and inflexible unfortunately. Placing pieces is relatively easy but they're hypersensitive to positioning and obstacles. However, because the game necessitates quite a bit of travel, you'll most likely end up with a lot of vacation homes across the Amazon rather than doing everything from a single main base. The survival mechanics around maintaining different kinds of nutrition are a cute novelty that does keep you from just relying on excessively abundant meat the entire game, but it's fairly trivial once you have an animal trap set up as long as you can meet your hydration and carbohydrate needs. Combat is generally functional enough. Inventory management is limited both by available space and by weight - which is realistic, but sometimes frustratingly at odds with how much the game seems to expect you to carry around to survive.

I'd say the main appeal probably is the sense of atmosphere. Being surrounded by authentic native flora and fauna gives the game a really strong sense of place that helps to set it apart and establishes that you're in a particular, real, detailed geographic region. It can be surprisingly serene between the parasitic infections and leopard attacks too, and the graphics are generally quite nicely done and cohesive (although the ragdoll physics are hilariously wonky in a way I don't count against it). I think anyone particularly interested in really getting to know an environment and building familiarity with it will especially enjoy this one.

The game did at one time have a rather egregious number of bugs (and can still be a little quirky with handling fluids in containers - if you get "liquids conflict" on an empty container, try filling it from the source you previously filled it from), but the worst of it is ironed out now, depending on to what extent you consider the building to be buggy vs. just very feature-limited.

TL;DR:
This is a great game for everyone who likes survival games.
It has a great flaw though: constant spawning of enemy warrior tribesmen, especially on higher difficulty. This can turn into a genocide game which is sad and ruins the experience.

If played on easier modes though it has an intense atmosphere.
Sometimes, when the ambient noises were changed or I haven't played in a while, I get a mild heart attack because. 
The constant lookout for dangers and that listening to the surroundings is the best way to avoid them, is creating a constant on edge feeling. Even if nothing happens. Gets me everytime.

The game is beautiful, I just love how the light reflects on the leaves and how rainwater drips to the ground. I like details like that. There might be prettier games nowadays, but I don't care. I grew up with pixels, this is art.

I like the more realistic approach, that the player has to check body parts for injuries, different wounds and illnesses need different healing methods, the character needs not just food but different nutritions. There might be other games like this now, but this one was one the first, if I'm not mistaken. After I saw this mechanic in a Let's Play on Youtube, when it was still in Early Access, this is what got me.

The biggest unrealistic issues are the attacks.
Jaguars, as most wild animals, don't tend to attack humans. Unless they are threatened and really have no other choice. I'm always sad when I have to kill one of these beautiful creatures, even virtually.
Caimans are a different story, they really are dangerous and since crocodiles in general have no specific prey (except for few kinds and youngens), the might attack humans. Mostly crocodiles hunt animals smaller then themselves and rarely attack something bigger.
In this regard though it's nice that these animals make noises when they are about to attack. This would not happen in nature, no predator would willingly make noises when they lurk and close in on their prey.
(Same counts for spiders, I've never heard a spider beeing that noisy, but it's a game after all. So by listening, the player can avoid getting surprised by a sudden attack. The constant listening for dangers is part of the atmosphere, it brings certain on edge feeling.)

The warriors make sense, as humans are always one of the most dangerous creatures on the planet. If in any culture they are ought to attack strangers, they will do.
But they most likely will not attack in such waves. It seems like there are endless warriors in the jungle and as other players stated and sceenshots show, these also don't stop attacking. Not even if the corpses of their kind pile up. They appear out of thin air and spawn in the strangest locations. The player often has no chance against them, can't really prepare for the encounters and the only way to survive really is genocide.
This gameplay appears to go against the moral of the story, which is the sad part.

Changing the game's difficulty also changes the behavior or more the number of warrior encounters. Mostly, at least.
But if one wants hard survival, they can't have this experience without going on a killing spree.

I am a 45 yo mother, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single mom to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since we separated with my ex-husband. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I thoroughly enjoy survival games, usually those with a bit of light heartedness or sci-fi themes, so I was a little unsure if I'd enjoy this. At first it was VERY hard, but as with most survival games once I got the hang of what to look out for, what's useful and what's not, it's pretty straight forward. I was initially frustrated by a few UI glitches - made it difficult to work out whether there was a bug or whether I just hadn't figured something out yet. I found the story pretty banal - it didn't hit the right note for what it was aiming for, took itself a bit too seriously to actually make the point about society that it tried to. But despite those things an enjoyable game with enough bits and pieces to add replayability.

Not possible to give a "meh" rating but the game is not good enough for a thumbs up. 

tldr:
The graphic, sound and story is great. But the game is way to easy. If you like to build a base and gather resources, this is for you. If you want to be forced to build a base and gather resources, it's not. Even on survival mode.

Long version:
I only played the story and a few hours survival mode. Didn't try "Story of Amazonas". I think I will not continue to play the game.

I started with the story on the 2nd hardest difficulty. The hardest one without permadeath. I did a few mistakes, died, started over, did a few mistakes less, died started over, did even less mistakes and survived. I think I had to restart three times until I beat the game after 28 hours. And 28h is a lot. I bet I could do it now
in maybe 8 hours or even less.

If you get the hang of the basics and listen to your surroundings, there is no threat anymore. The tribe or predators are a joke. Predators constantly gnarl while they stalk and the tribe warriors yell around so one can easily hear them. The predators have to be killed (except the caiman). Never tried to flee from the cats but I think this is not possible. If you have no bow or spear, you can prepare yourself to die now or later from the wounds. Oh you got a few bandages? Then its not a problem. With bow and/or spear, they are just a pain in the ass, because you have to stop and wait until you can see them. Headshot and thats it. The tribe warriors are a bit tougher, because they are three or more (except some who are sitting alone on the ground and sing). I only decided to attack them, if my spear, knife and bow were damaged enough. Then I got new ones of them.

The only "threat" later are the scoprions, snakes and spiders, which tend to spawn right behind you or attack from the inside of trees. I got bit two times by a snake which spawned inside a big tree. More often I got bit by scorpions which spawned 10m behind me in a cave which I left 5 seconds before. I was to careless to check the floor AGAIN. But even this costs you just 12h. You have to put a bandage on it and sleep the fever away. With enough water there is no problem.

Base building:
If you have a cave, you only need a fire and a bed. No point in building any buildings. Without a cave, you need a roof for the fire. No need for planting, breeding or defensive structures.

Why?
The only thing you need is a knife, bow, spear and an axe. Build it with obsidian stone. You can hunt, gather fruits and water. Water can be easily boiled [spoiler]inside a turtle shell[/spoiler] and stored [spoiler]inside coconut bidons[/spoiler]. And there is a lot of them around. You can eat nearly everything. There are just a few things you shouldn't eat without cooking them. You even don't need to find nuts, because the tapir (iirc) has a lot of fats in his flesh. If you still go low on fats, search for a [spoiler]yellow nut falling from palms[/spoiler].

Herbivores are way to many around. They constantly respawn every day. On the other hand, there are to few predators even with that amount of possible prey. With so much plant eating animals around it's a wonder you can find any fruits or plants.

Armour?
It's possible to craft armour. But I see no sense in it. Afaik it protects against attacks from predetaors and tribe warriors. As I said before, I never had any probles with them. I still crafted for pieces of [spoiler]Armadillo[/spoiler] armour hoping to get rid of the leeches and the bites from scorpions, spiders and snakes. But they don't protect you from this. Sarcasm: If they would, there would be no threat anymore. One could run through the forest without looking on the ground or listening to the rattle of a snake. 

Leeches!
The leeches are a pain in the ass. You get them. You get them often. Don't understand how but I even got them while I walked on a plain ground without any leafes or water around. And there is no protection against them. You even get them while wearing armour. And because you can still get them, there is no need in wearing armour. I threw them away and played the rest of the story (20+ ingame days) without. Yeah I know it protects against ant bites. But I don't needed ants and avoided them. To be honest, I still don't know for what ants are good though.

Surprise attacks:
Yes they can happen. In my 42 ingame days story playtrough I had them ONLY ONE TIME in a cave I slept. I came back late with 20% max stamina and still managed to kill all 3 of them. Just because they focused on destroying my leaf bed. I was able to take them down with a spear throw and two arrows. I had to wait after each attack, because my stamina was drained. Stupid AI. They could have killed me really easily.

I never had any problems with sleeping in the wilderness any time. If you play this game, you could think the djungle is a nice place for a backpack trip.

What the game is missing or needs improvement (IMO):
1. Mosquitos or other pain in the ass insects which drains the sanity of the player as it would in real live. One could use mud for cover which leads to other problems like parasites or other things.
2. Dehydration. Yes of course you need to drink in this game. But its just a minor thing. If you read the notes from the camp you will find in the story, then it must be real hot there. But I had only to drink once per day no matter if I walked or ran all the day. Take 120 units of water with you and you can go on 2 ingame days until it becomes a problem. If you find some fruit on the way. And you will.
3. Clothes which can be damaged/destroyed.
4. More threat from fauna. No one can tell me, a pile of leafes on the ground protects me from insects which crawl over me while I sleep. Even if I put a few logs beneath them. Stalking cats shouln't make a sound when they prowl. And make them attack while I sleep. Then I am forced to build a shelter!
5. Decrease spawn time of just everything. Fruits and animals shouldn't respawn in a few days. Yes this is a djungle and resources are found everywhere. But not if I am on the same spot for days. If I kill 3 tapirs per day, then they must can get depleted. Same with fruits, sticks, stones, trees...
6. More dangerous plants. As I said, one can eat nearly everything without negative side effects. There could be for example diarrhea, dizziness, ...

Challenging and exciting, with a unique story.

I enjoy learning craft blueprints from trial and error or periodically via exploration, it makes the survival aspect of the game a lot more fun. Early on I suffered many deaths while trying to learn the mechanics and objectives, but it helped me prioritize what needs to be crafted and in what order. Once you master the basics of crafting tools and minimally viable staging areas, exploration and survival become a lot easier.

A few obvious tips (without spoilers):
- learn to use the environment and mechanics to your advantage
- while fire isn't essential, it does make your life both easier and harder (heed the in-game warning)
- bring extra water for longer trips
- be mindful of gear durability

I played this multiplayer.
1. The bugs.... THE BUGS. I had to redo checkpoints because the save went missing or the checkpoint just didn't work or the cut scene crashed. This was the largest cause of frustration and I was about to abandon the game entirely.
2. The design is somewhat mediocre, you really only need to build like 3 structures out of the entire manual to get through the game. It's really not that hard to survive once you travel around. In fact there's essentially no point in having a base.
3. The story is.... ok. Nothing fancy, just ok.
4. The 3d motion sickness hits hard in this one. You can adjust the settings to reduce it, but it's still quite noticeable.

My thoughts; Great graphics, immersive gameplay which can be tailored to custom difficulty settings, you can even choose tourist mode if you don't want to manage things like thirst, hunger, tiredness, sanity.  Though having those settings enabled will help drive you into some fun situations.  Green hell has nasty spiders, rashes, leaches, venomous snakes, caiman, and jaguars just to mention a few of the things you will come across.  You can even cannibalize the locals if you don't mind risking going insane and hearing voices.  I prefer it over The Forest which isn't a bad game either but this one feels much more immersive to me.  You can also find some cool stuff in the jungle that you may have not expected to find but no spoilers here from me.  If your a fan of survival games you wont regret picking this one up.  It is also priced very well for what you get, and when on sale that's even better.

[h1]Overview[/h1]
One of the most punishing Survival game. If you think the forest a;ready hard, try play this game and you'll die after 3-5 hours in lol. Because the similar nature to The Forest by Endnight games, I will mostly compared Green Hell to The Forest.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ The graphics Is Definitely the prettiest, the lush, dense forest is really good and telling you in a tropical biomes the best.
+ The story is pretty straightforward but nice and worth to explore (Don't forget the real ending)
+ The Mechanics is much harder than the forest, There's injury that need bandage otherwise it will rot or basically making your characters weaker and crazy, there's illness, poison, rash, worms crawling on your body if you sleep on ground, and making fire needs plow and tinder with 50% chance, etc. It's much denser survival games than The Forest
+ The body needs not only food or water, but fat, protein, carbs. Filling them all is really hard early in game but once you get it, the game is fun
+ Animal variety is so many, not only the tribes is the no 1 threat, but leopard, angry hogs, rattlesnakes, parasites, etc. So many things to prepare with
+ Crafting also bit variable than the forest, There's mud crafting, coconut bidon, Nut bowl, etc. So much to craft.
+ Unforgiving but bearable, way more fun with friends too

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- The tutorial almost tell you nothing than basic button of the game, plus there's no way to know what to make and credible recipes if you not tinker hard enough or looking at youtube guides. You'll guaranteed died over and over until you understand the basics.
- Harvesting items harder than the forest bcs limited carry capacity and slots using mechanics from RE4 and limited weapons slot. Carry more than you can will slow you down so much and you cant even jump. Playing alone almost make the game harder 5x than with just one friend. Almost everything progress much faster with friends.
- The carry problems got worse if you also injured, fever, rash, etc that draining your health and stamina tremendously. So if you need to make so many bases to stock your items or you doomed to death.
- Items disappears when you died except the backpack slots. You got machete, bows, etc that only spawn once, you lost it forever. Need to reload save and have much better plans to avoid this.
- Maps sometimes not 100% accurate, you found a places there's drawing/markings on map but someplace it wasn't accurate, plus we cant add our own markings like bases or explore-able places. Easy to get lost if you don't have good memories of places you walk into.
- The forest sometimes more fun and enjoyable bcs they allow you to make giant structures and things to play with. Plus the jankiness of the AI and glitches is truly one of the charms. But in Green Hell, you can't build things like that. Plus everything is tedious to build alone.
- The harvesting of Liara - The Rope of this game sometimes ridiculous bcs you just cut down the tree but you still have to hold E to harvest it, sometimes it fallen to bad places you can't reach.
- Not every big tree is able to cut down, unlike the forest you can actually create complex or city if you want.
- Some items serve no purpose in main game, until you reach the spirit of amazonia. Then why the devs placing the item in main game is ridiculous. Making us wasting backpack spaces and hoping there's something to craft with it but it can't
- Multiplayer sometimes unstable, so many disconnect and desync that we noticed after playing sometimes. Sometimes making other players other than host lost the long progress they made except it saved on backpacks.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Is it a punishing survival game. HELL YEAH. Is it fun? With friends yes if they all know what they doing and the basics of the game. Alone? NO. Recommended and play with friends or random players...

I love this game!

I haven't played the story mode yet but I've spent nearly 30 hours in survival mode.  There's a lot of stuff in this game that you can discover through intuition or just standing survival knowledge.  If you spent time as a scout you'll have an easier stroll up the learning curve.

A lot of the techniques used in this game are applicable in the real world, though notably more difficult to use than the gameplay implies.  Some things I'm not so sure of as inspite of my attempts to research them I couldn't find anything definitive.  But it's a game, a great game at that.  

Looking forward to eventually playing this with some friends.  Also thinking about doing a permadeath run to see how long I can make it.

Noooope. Can't recommend. I really wanted to like this, but if you like a good survival game with strong narrative you should buy Subnautica or Grounded or even Forest (and, sorry fanboys, nope, not Raft... Raft sucks).

Green Hell is all fun and games while you get used to the mechanics (which foods do what, what animals do what, what afflictions do what... this was even during a bug the devs took months fixing after an (worthless) update that kept you from recording what plants did what), but then you are left with... very little. GH is known for how hard it is... but it isn't difficult after you get the core mechanics down. After that? Same enemies, same environment, same tools, same threats.... same, same, same. And that's after 1/5 of the game. 

I read a review that said: [spoiler] All you need to do is wall-crawl... [/spoiler] and I thought at the time, "they can't possibly be right", but, after playing, yup... they were totally right.

Successful survivals allow the player to push forward through increasing levels of difficulty by way of skill but ultimately require them to acquire new different materials to craft new different things that will help them in the new biome they explore. GH? Nope. You learn everything you need to learn in the first 1/5 of the game, then it's all about finding a MacGuffin that will get you to the next place (and a whole lot of nothing).

And, much like Raft, the narrative/end-game/pay-off just isn't worth it (Raft is, frankly, godawful, while GH is just... meh). There is wild miss-direction on how to get to the end, and, even the "good" ending is disappointing. [spoiler] The tone of Mia, whom you are set on saving, is wildly divergent... at once loving and thankful for what you did... and then disgusted, insulting, and accusatory.  [/spoiler]

Okay, so normally I like to finish a game before I put in a review, but this game is going to take up so much of my life that by the time I'm actually finished I'll have a novel-sized review, so I'll get ahead of myself this time lol.

I really enjoy survival crafting games that have storylines. The Forest was one that captivated me and I didn't like that I couldn't spend an unlimited amount of time just hunting and surviving, but otherwise loved the game altogether. Green Hell gives me that satisfaction of taking my time and really enjoying the survival of the game (not to mention there are a lot of difficult components that consistently keep things interesting and challenging). I like that it leaves EVERYTHING to me -- all the exploration, building, finding new survival tips and recipes along the way.. it's a constant battle for survival and the only one who can muck it up is yours truly.

Words simply can't describe how much I love this game, and I'm stoked to finish the story but I also can't wait to play the other game modes and just test my mettle along the way. I'm positive that multiplayer will be a blast as well. I've only spent about 7h in this game so far and the giddiness and high from that time alone is worth the money. If you enjoy survival games at all, grab this one and see for yourself! I'm not usually one to rate over the top number on a scale since it's statistically impossible to be better than 100%, but this game is a 1,000,000/10 for me!

Edit/Update:

Bugs are still being fixed! In my original post I thought that support for the game had essentially ended. I won't lie, it's super nice being able to name all the unknown plants, but so far I haven't seen anything that changes my initial conclusions. The big game-breaking problems don't seem to have changed at all.

Original Review:

I do not recommend this game.

The storytelling is great. Early gameplay will most likely kill new players a dozen or more times before they get into the swing of things, but after that it becomes challenging without being overwhelming thanks to customization options.

If that was all, I would be ecstatic. Unfortunately the entire thing is buggier than a Bethesda buffet. Core aspects of the game seem to have been changed at the last minute without any thought to what might break. Several key events required to advance the story simply do not work without a dozen restarts and a crap-ton of cursing.

It's maddening, it kills any enjoyment I might have had while playing that session, and is so consistently broken that any kind of testing at all couldn't help but catch it. Given that the game's been out on Steam for three years, I cannot bring myself to endorse it despite all of the great stuff it brings to the table.

This is possibly the most unforgiving survival game ever made. I hated it for the first three hours but couldn't stop playing because although I was dying over and over, I was also learning from those mistakes, and gradually I became better. Now that I understand what is going on, I love it. The game provides everything you need if you know where or how to find it, but if you make any mistakes, even the smallest ones, the repercussions can be swift and deadly. Every action you take nees to be deliberate and measured. Rush ahead, and you will be dead in minutes.

I'm not great at survival games, especially ones with multiple ways to kill you. Getting a hang of the mechanics, the meta, starting over again and again, I rage quit. Took me months of abandoning it and coming back before finally getting the hang out things. When I did, not too tricky ("Normal/Welcome to the Jungle difficulty, I know my limits) and I think I love it.

The scenery is great. I didn't notice the beaten paths really guiding you around because they're subtle, and unnecessary, but even guiding you to the first abandoned village was some pretty great level design. I don't feel like my hand is being held, I can explore to my heart's content, it feels like I'm wandering through a strange jungle I haven't seen before.

Threats are easy to manage and avoid or take care of when you learn the tricks. Like every game if you can aim the bow is OP even with basic arrows (I never actually did anything with metal). The notebook is detailed enough to identify cures and plants as well, though much of it requires trial and error. E.g. find a strange plant? Effects unknown till you eat it or try combining it with other things. It may cause or cure food poisoning, you'll just have to cross your fingers, adding to the "realism" of surviving an unfamiliar jungle.

The story is... I'm torn. I can poke holes in it, but I'm a sucker for the romance types. I suppose my biggest annoyance is the ineptitude of an anthropologist who has been to this exact jungle before. It'd change the whole story if he was new to the jungle, and it wouldn't be nearly as fun gameplay if they let you know everything an experienced anthropologist should wandering the jungle. It's kind of explained in the story later, but it's not exactly perfect. Also the chance of missing the "bad ending" is a shame. I wasn't smart enough my first go to find the good ending, but someone who pays more attention than I do won't have a problem, and the bad ending is what ties everything together.

Overall fun game, and that's what's important. If you enjoy suffering through survival games worth the price tag, if you're a noob like me that may give it up a few times maybe wait for a sale.

EDIT: Now with all the updates they've been doing for farming, beekeeping, just general quality of life improvements I'd say this game touches even more audiences without losing its soul. Wonderfully done keeping me hooked.

This game is simply outstanding. As a survival game it exceeds expectations and raises the bar in comparison to similar games. Games such as the Forest, that hold a dear place in my heart, seem incomplete when shown next to Green Hell. The development team continues to nurture the game long after its initial release and are constantly adding new content to the game. It warms my heart as a player to know that even if I stop playing, a year from now when I come back, there will be enough content to make it feel just as new as the day I bought it. Unlike huge studios *cough* EA *cough* they have released updates big enough to be entire DLC for FREE. Which is reason enough to buy this game. Simple as. It's incredibly refreshing to see a game that is as dedicated to its playerbase as Green Hell. In a world of Microtransactions and lists of a dozen+ dlc, Green Hell has delivered a COMPLETE experience that contiunes to grow for less than half the price of one that you have to buy fragments of for a year. If this game was a full $59.99 USD I'd still be beyond proud of my purchase.

Green Hell, is a HARDCORE survival game with some clear cut base building. All things are designed to help your survival experience and after "completing" the game, I feel as though both my patience and survival skills have improved IRL.

[u] So let speak on the games strong points. [/u]

Fun in CO-OP/ Multiplayer. Where you quirky problems can be shared and experienced so its not just you going mad.

Visually stunning. This game is like eye candy in a voxel based gaming world. 

GRINDY. Lets just say every building piece or crafting item requires "JUST ONE MORE" of something. Poisoned? You'll probably need one more Lily than you have. Building a smoker, better go get one more bamboo stick. You will not be bored trying to survive, that's for sure.

[u] And lo and behold, the negatives below: [/u]

[b] The bugs are infuriating. [/b] Mice and toads will launch you neatly organized stacks of materials into the goddamn stratosphere. Forget stocking things on your house, they fall right through to the ground. Best waste materials and build storage. Wanna try husbandry? Well, only 1.4% of gamers tried, because its buggy as hell. Invisible shit piles will kill off your animals before they even breed.

[b] Rain mechanic? [/b ] The old saying, "when it rains it pours" applies here, in metric tons. My buddy and I went a week without rain, then a week with it. Right after we found ourselves complaining about hauling water, we then complained about the constant white noise for days on end.

[b] Dont wasted time building. [/b] I understand the Story mode is not for building elaborate homes or multistory mansions, but boy thinking back you shouldn't do anything past a lean-to and campfire. Hours spent trying to build both "just useful" to "awesome" things when a coconut bowl and biden is all you really need.

[b] Story. Is this even a story? [/b] If your playing for a story, you're going to be very disappointed by the end of it all. (Hopefully your game doesn't crash during the last cut-scene in multiplayer, like mine did. DEMOTIVATING ASF) It was easy to see where it was leading the story fairly early in the game, but the way it was slapped together by the time you reached the 3rd "area", Anaconda Island, left so many holes and yet gave so much unnecessary information.

I will say, having only played story mode, maybe it shines in sandbox. And maybe one day I will try it. But only addressing key mechanics of the game itself I doubt anything addressed above fails to hit the mark with most players. That being said, this game is a real good direction most survival games should go. The grind is absolutely real and that is what kept me coming back for more. But the bugs in the game itself countered most of the joy i felt playing it. Dropping back in saves and losing hours of my life to stupid bugs became a real dilemma. 

All in all I rate a 6/10. Due to an horrendous story, Beta level play-ability, but beautifully designed with Multiplayer. This is not your NEXT GAME experience.

Fascinating game, stands out among the many games in the "open world survival craft" genre I've played by being incredibly unforgiving but in an immersive good way. While the difficulty does present me with an apprehension to sit down for a while and simply struggle struggle. 

The basic act of building a structure feels much more rewarding than the mindless tree chopping I do in similar games. That being said It does suffers from the same excessive resource requirements for simply things like walls.. and the green hell difficulties does make you feel you need an IV bag surgically attached at all times to cover the dehydration level of your character.

 If you can deal with some of these inconveniences, which exist in many other games of the same vein, the experience is worth it imo. I actually worry about taking a long stroll in this game, a fear I rarely have in the other games, looking out for snakes, bugs, big cats, etc. makes the moments I do explore much more engaging.

Previous review

"There are some good things about this game but honestly the amount of game breaking bugs that I've been finding in my recent game has been pretty painful.  For example I was attacked by a piranha while spear fishing, and then couldn't remove the spear from my hand, save the game, sleep, eat, or do anything at all other than alt f4 and that isn't the only bug that I've found.  The fact that this game has been out for years now, and still has game breaking bugs like that and they are already onto expansions and other games is just overall disappointing.  It is a pretty decent survival game but the bugs just take the fun out of it.  I've played a lot of early access games that are in a far better state than this."

I really didn't expect the dev's to reach out the same day as I posted this review and then fix the bug.  That never happens.

Bought this expecting a "The Forest" clone. It was so much more than The Forest in terms of story and gameplay mechanics. Making a wrong move early in the game is very punishing and can usually result in death if you don't know what your doing. I didn't feel like the immersion was broken by having a co-op partner but it did make the game much easier. Although, my partner was always reset to the last "brew" stand when we logged in on the same save and would have to find their way back to the story progression or temporary camp we set up. It was my biggest annoyance, besides my dreadful directional awareness that was most of the time my fault. It's been a while since I felt connected to a storyline and I wasn't at first until the last quarter of the storyline and then it really hits home. For a game that came out a year or two ago it was strangely relevant with today's society even if it was mere coincidence.

On the surface, there are similarities to The Forest, so it's not unusual for people to compare them. Under the surface, however, they're quite different. Green Hell is more survival and "realism" and The Forest leans more toward horror and supernatural. I greatly prefer Green Hell.

The developers have continued to add content after the game's release, which I always appreciate and consider a sign they care about their creation.

Good combination of base building, living off the land, and running for your life. Still a work in progress, so some things (like building large structures) are a bit buggy, but devs are committed to improvements.

I enjoyed much of this game, however, it did end up getting rather repetitive, as there's only so many hours you can slog back and forth through the jungle without it getting dull. The prequel was the worst at this, as it dragged you back and forth endlessly and nothing seemed to be in any kind of order. The story on the main game was engrossing but the aimless wandering of the prequel was a turn off.

Take it from someone who does bush craft/survival as a hobby: this game is amazing. It's unrelenting and unforgivable just like the real world. All the survival points are there.

A few additions I would like to see ingame:
More containers: Some place to put bones in would be nice and maybe add the ability to search for clay and use the campfire to make cups, bowls or even big jars.
Garden/Nursery: It would be cool to have some place where you could cultivate either mushrooms, plants or even small animals (E.I. Frogs, rats, larva, maggots, etc.)
Clothes making: Some plants can be used to make rope and even clothes (Hemp, Flax, Nettle) it would be cool to be able to gather that as well as animal skins and work with it.
Survival mode: I would love to have a mode where we have predators and sanity but without the mean men trying to kill us. 

TD;DR: Game's great, go try it and have fun dying every 10 minutes.

Edit:

Loved to see some of the things I mentioned added to the game later on. These new updates are great. Keep up the good work!

Second Edit:

Wooo! No more unkown plants!

Fun game, similar to Stranded Deep, but this game is very poorly made. They set you up with a very realistic feeling game, between the food and different environmental threats keep you on your toes. But even on the easiest setting the game will pile on debuffs until you're low on health and one tapped by a imaginary tribesmen. 

Overall between the graphics and the gameplay mechanics I would recommend against getting this game unless you plan on spending hundreds of hours trying to master the most basic parts of survival only to get screwed. 

Now if you're a masochist and you love this suffering, then go for it.

I loved The Long Dark game and I thought this would be similar. Big mistake. This game is difficult without being satisfying enough to challenge yourself to beat it. It will be realistic enough when it serves the purpose of killing you, and unrealistic enough to serve the same purpose. The tutorial is not truly very informative, which i would have excused if your character didn't need to rush like a maniac in Overcooked . The exploration could have been so much fun if the game could let us some time to breath and observe the beautiful landscape and its' inhabitants. Sometimes the lack of options is annoying and makes no sense. Your character has to sleep on a bed and nothing but a bed. You cannot sleep by choice on the ground so enjoy waiting until you pass out when your bed won't be ready in time. The passage of time goes unreasonably fast, and your bars drain equally as fast. Your bed takes a whole day and night in game to make (gather materials, bring them to the location, and assemble it) which is a ridiculous amount of time. And only in 3 days or so in game you can die to insanity, yeah makes sense, doesn't it? Passing out also is not fun and it will be something you will experience very often in the beginning. You have to wait and cannot wake up straight away or skip the black screen persisting after you pass out so you are left looking at it for quite a few seconds doing nothing. All in all you will have to fight against food poisoning, leeches, parasites, wild animals, hostile tribe people, famine, insanity, thirst. You will need a specific diet and clean water which again if you don't have makes you have a shorter life than a female mayfly.

2 tbsp canola oil
6 cloves garlic crushed
1 pc onion, sliced
1 kilogram chicken cut ups
2 tbsp vinegar
1/4 cup soy sauce
1 cup water
2 pcs bay leaves
1 tsp whole black peppercorns, slightly crushed
2 pc Knorr chicken cubes
1 tsp brown sugar packed
Option: 1 cup kale or spinach

1
Heat oil in pan and sauté garlic and onions. Then add chicken to the pan and sear on all sides, until you have a little browning in the chicken skin.
2
Pour in vinegar, soy sauce and water. Add bay leaves, pepper and Knorr Chicken Cubes. Bring to a boil over high heat then reduce heat to simmer, but do not cover the pan. Continue to simmer for 10 mins.
3
Remove chicken pieces from sauce and fry in another pan until nicely browned.
4
Put back fried chicken pieces into sauce. Add sugar and let simmer again for another 10 minutes or until sauce has thickened. Serve warm.

The game does not allow you to create a dedicated server! If you start a co-op game, the one that hosted it has to always be online and launch it (or you have to swap saves manually). This is crap. They already have a server that is launched when you host a game from your PC. Why can't we have that as a separate fileset to put on our own dedicated servers?

You also only join a server through an invite. The server finder doesn't work. This is really bad if you crash in a fight and your friend just can't send an invite, cause they're also fighting. And it does crash, freeze, or get you stuck in some animation/context pretty often.

There are 4 types of "elements" (3 nutrient types + water). These drain out super fast. This isn't fun. You spend so much time running from one food station to the next until you can finally head out to do stuff and play the game.

Controls (especially crafting) are silly. So many things attached to separate menus and buttons, when they could've been combined (e.g.: crafting and inventory are two buttons - minecraft had that figured out ages ago).

Plenty of bugs, like desynching of world objects or losing everything in your inventory during a crash.

if you want to hang around the base, building and cooking, but your friends want to do quests. Well... you can't. Or they can't. Everyone has to go there to get the quest working.

Still, it's the lack of a dedicated server that's the dealbreaker for me. Such an easy thing to implement, and it ain't there. But hey - you can name your capybara now!

Tips based on my own experience playing the game:
1. Find a place to build shelter and do it asap. Food source can come in second since you'll be seeing fruits around.
2. Obviously, get food.
3. Listen carefully to your surroundings. 
4. Always have bandages. 
5. Pay attention to your health and always attend to your wounds. "You will take care of your health in this game more than you do irl" - a quote from a review of someone
6. I built bases on every area. So whenever I try to explore, instead of going all the way back, I could just go to the base I made on that area to store my stuff, eat, and rest. Made my life so much easier. It's a lot of work but better than dying or getting injured every time you wander around. 

This has no particular order (except no.1) and there's a lot to mention. But pretty sure other's have their own tips and tricks to share.

This review is in English and Slovak language:
Táto recenzia je v Anglickom a Slovenskom jazyku:

The game has a very good and long enough story. Performance is very well tuned and works without problems at full details even on older PCs. So for the price of the game you get enough quality content and I definitely recommend buying it. In terms of gameplay, it's definitely a harder survival game, which I'm very happy about, but this game also has a few flaws (similar to other survival games). Some quests are very hard to understand without reading tutorials on the internet (especially in SoA). The AI ​​(fighters) are quite intelligent, but the combat system is not finished. Basically just hurt them and run away because they don't heal and will die from the injury after a while. There is a large amount of fauna and flora on the map, so finding food and materials is no problem, as you will stumble upon something at every turn. However, on hard difficulty, water and food dwindle at such a rate that you're basically just a cook lost in the jungle doing nothing but food and collecting water non-stop. However, the biggest shortcoming is the imperfect movement of the character on the terrain. The character often gets stuck even on small terrain irregularities (especially rocks) and jumping to high places is sometimes a pain. Overall, however, the quality outweighs the flaws.

Hra má veľmi dobrý a dostatočne dlhý príbeh. Výkonovo je veľmi dobre vyladená a funguje bez problémov na plné detaily aj na starších PC. Za cenu hry teda dostanete dostatočne kvalitný obsah a jej kúpu rozhodne odporúčam. V rámci hrateľnosti ide rozhodne o ťažšiu hru na prežitie, čo ma veľmi teší, ale aj táto hra má niekoľko nedostatkov (podobných s inými hrami na prežitie). Niektoré úlohy je veľmi ťažké pochopiť bez čítania návodov na internete (najmä v SoA). AI (bojovníci) sú síce pomerne inteligentní, ale systém boja nie je dotiahnutý do konca. V podstate ich stačí zraniť a utiecť, pretože sa neošetrujú a po istom čase na zranenie umrú. Na mape je veľké množstvo fauny aj flóry, takže so zháňaním potravy a materiálu nie je žiadny problém, pretože na každom kroku o niečo zakopnete. Na ťažkej obtiažnosti však voda a jedlo ubúda takou rýchlosťou, že ste v podstate len kuchár stratený v ďžungli, ktorý non-stop nerobí nič iné, len jedlo a zber vody. Najvačším nedostatkom je však nedokonalý pohyb postavy po teréne. Postava sa často zasekne aj o malé terénne nerovnosti (najmä skaly) a skákanie na vyvýšené miesta je niekedy utrpenie. Celkovo však kvalita prevyšuje chyby.

I'm a casual gamer, usually play in bed in evenings. Thus it needs to be controller compatible. Everything works well until I need to use the Notepad or Craft. It then brings up a mouse cursor and there's no way to use the controller. Even when using the mouse to hover over, it goes in a seizure and I can't even confirm the craft with the controller. I've read of other people not having problems with a controller, but it refuses to work for me. Refunding and getting Subnautica instead.

Very good survival game.  One of the most challenging ive done that is in this first person format. You must forage food, water, everything you need to survive.  You can play a single player story or just do survival mode. I bought it just for the story and had a good time doing that. It took me 14 hours to complete. In the beginning you dont even have a map but you find 3 along the way. The map is just something you look at, and there is no marker on it tell you your location.

Your wife has givern you a watch that has directional coordinates that you can use to navigate using the map. There is no minimap. I was able to find my way around without too much trouble. Navigation is good via movement with the keyboard and so is combat.

You must fight natives and some animals as well. The settings are very nice because you can turn certain challenges off and on, and adjust how hard each one is. I put the nutrient depletion to low so that water and food lasts longer. You can adjust a lot of things, and its very nice that way. Something that a lot of games are lacking! So I only played the story mode. Im not majorly into survival games, so that was enough for me.

The survival mode looks great for those that like that. You can also have up to 3 other people playing with you in your scenario, It looks like you can save and continue ad infinitum. One session I saw that I could have joined was 120 days, game days not real days, old. There is of course a day and night cycle and you must sleep to replenish your energy.

Other survival things. You can heal wounds by making bandages. You can craft armor. There are things you can make that I didnt even do. As you build things and use tools, your skill increases too.

You could build a big building if you desire. I just made little shelters to sleep and save the game. Thats how you save the game. If youre into building things, like in Skyrim, then youll like that aspect. I did not explore that option.

Everything I loved about The Long Dark, this game ups it.  There are only a few small nitpicks, like the fact fish don't provide the fats necessary for survival and brain function, which in RL they're the best source.  But the graphics, animation, and challenge make up for whatever little complaints I have.   The difficulty is nowhere near as punishing as The Long Dark, where wind and cold are major factors, and even canned food spoils.  But Green Hell offers an entirely new set of things trying to kill you, especially microorganisms!  Diseases, infections, parasites, you better learn quickly how to counter these things, or you WILL die!

The Law of the Jungle is savage and merciless, and it couldn't be more fun.

TL;DR: underappreciated fantastic game that's as hard as you decide to make it. Controls and interface take some getting use to, but just dont worry about dying for your first few hours of play while you figure out all the interfaces. then restart a fresh game and take advantage of the custom difficulty options to enjoy it how you wish. It can be a bit much with default settings at first. Absolute blast with a friend or two. I used maggots from a piece of meat that rotted in my backpack to clean out an infected laceration on my leg, and then 'stitched' it closed with big bitey ants. 10/10. It takes patience to get into... took me a few play sessions to really start to get it and enjoy it, but once i did, it's become an addiction. 

Great survival game, but can be super punishing and confusing at first. Once you get a handle on what's required to survive, good practices for survival, and adjusting your mindset to always have a plan and adapt to changing conditions, it's a blast. I like that the wilderness, GENERALLY speaking, is not 'evil' or out to get you. it's simply alive, and there are dangers that you must learn to exist with. you WILL DIE a lot at the start until you learn to live off of/with the land. you learn to love the rain, rather than fear it, and you learn the importance of placing bowls and coconut shells to capture that life-giving rain water every chance you get. 

If you liked 'The Forest' then you'll probably enjoy this game. It has a much different pace and vibe though, and you definitely feel like you're free to take your time more and settle in, whereas 'The Forest' obviously kind of put a deadline on everything due to passage of days meaning more hostile locals... 

I love the progression from the feeling at the beginning of being scared and useless, and everything seemed so hard... but after a while, you start to become one with the rain forest. you begin to learn all the plants and recognize signs from the environment around you, and you learn to sustain yourself by foraging and taking only what you need. you learn which plants made you sick, and which ones are a tasty treat... you find signs of animals that you can hunt, and learn to spot food sources like good fishing holes, or areas where crabs or birds might hang out for an easy lunch... It's a great feeling to suddenly feel much more competent and like you've grown to be part of the landscape, rather than fighting against it, even though your level of tech doesn't ever really advance much... you simply become practiced at surviving and thriving off little more than the sticks and rocks around you- you learn what to look for as far as viable shelter locations, and you can set up a quick camp anywhere you need to (and hopefully find a meal and drinkable water if you're smart). you still have to adapt though... not all areas are the same, and fighting against the nature of one place or another will almost always lead to your death. you have to work with the nature, or find a more suitable location. there's no right or wrong way... there's only dead and alive. This is something that few wilderness survival style games have really managed to reproduce in my experience. But even as you feel like you're thriving, you're always only one or two missteps or bits of bad luck away from disaster... the jungle is unforgiving, and a fever from an infection or especially bad food poisoning could very well be your demise. The jungle is dense, and you can also easily become lost if you're not careful... panic and frantic movement can lead you to starvation and dehydration if you stray too far from places you know well.

This is a survival game in which you play as Jake, a seemingly mentally handicapped man who is searching for his missing girlfriend. Jake is apparently also an un-diagnosed diabetic as he requires gallons of water a day to survive. He also eats more protein in a 12 hour period than Schwarzenegger in his prime. Sometimes Jake dies of thirst despite being in a tropical rain shower. If Jake can't drink clean coconut water, Jake dies. Jake will get his limbs scratched, cut, poisoned, infected and stung every time he walks 3 steps but his damaged brain means he can't figure out which limb is wounded without  inspecting each one individually. All the leeches in the forest are also in love with Jake. Jake spends half his life removing leeches. Jake has many problems, but he does his best.  Oh, and Jake cleans infected wounds by letting maggots crawl all over his skin. Jake simulator is a unique experience.

Have you ever wondered what an amazing survival game would be like with the ABSOLUTE WORST navigation mechanic would be like?  This is the game for you then.  I sincerely wish I could get a refund.  There are great survival and base building aspects to the game.  Environment is unforgiving, but not insurmountable.  Combat takes some practice, but is fun.

100% the entirely game ruining experience is getting even slightly lost and pretty much stuck in a death spiral.  The only help you have for finding your way around the jungle, is a longitude/latitude measurement.  No way placing markers.  No maps showing your position. Nothing.  Essentially, the game encourages you to build a base camp, gather nearby resources, and NEVER, EVER, loose sight of that camp.  If you try to wonder out to one of the PoI's in the game, you can either start a whole new camp, or die trying to find your way back.  You can try to build some structures as a trail marker, but not really because you have very limited carrying space.  You have to constantly be eating different nutritional value providing foods, you have to carry a lot of water, and bandages, which takes up most of your inventory space.  The longer the trip, the more you have to take.  So stopping to build is pointless.  Not only that, if you want to remember way points, you have to write them down somewhere.  The Long/Lat is unhelpful, it may as well not exist at all.  If you try to find (for example) 25s, you can get a heading, but that's it.  You'll eventually run into a rock face, or a canyon.  Just go around?  Good luck.  Even if you manage to avoid all the hazards, you are going to spend hours walking around and slowing dying to attrition.  Once your energy gets low enough, you'll only be conscience for a few minutes at a time, your body will fill with parasites, and you die, all because you happened to walk away from your base for more than a few minutes.

All of this could be easily solved with some kind of map overlay, or a way to mark your trail, or anything other that the least helpful way imaginable to try to find your way through the environment.

Much more difficult than you expect! The story is engaging, and the graphics are beautiful. Inventory and building is quite finicky, so would NOT recommend playing with a controller. A massive downside in my opinion is the survival aspect. whenever you attempt to walk through the jungle, you get a HUGE variety of infections and wounds, and even though the mechanics to cure them are well thought out, you accumulate illnesses by FAR faster than you can cure them. Basically whenever you even get a light scratch, it's worth it to just revert to last save, since it's almost guaranteed that by the time you find the plant that helps, you'll have 6 more problems to take care of. It's extremely frustrating when you're on low stamina and away from shelter, since you begin to pass out every 30s, and accumulate 4 illnesses every time you do. I believe that making helpful resources much more common could help, or maybe make illnesses a probability thing, so it's not GUARANTEED that every time you go into the water you get leeches, or every time you pass out you get worms. Great game overall though, and with some balancing, and expansion to base building, this can truly turn into an S+ tier survival game

They're not bad, but doing some things is slightly clunky. The first person view camera is fine. The world itself is full of interesting things to discover and catalog and combine into new things, as well as unique places to explore and some variation in terrain. The game has enough going on to keep one engaged for a long time. The tedious stuff feels satisfying and the random stuff feels well balanced. I certainly have recommended this game to friends and would recommend it to strangers who enjoy open world exploring with an emphasis on the crafting/building system. The difficulty can be turned up well beyond what I can handle so far, but also has settings that remain challenging, but are also quite enjoyable.

I've played a lot of different types of games over the years - MMO's, FPS's, survival games, strategy games, etc, and I don't post reviews often but I had to for this. Green Hell was probably one of the least fun games I've ever played. The ending was extremely unsatisfying and made me angry. Even the "good ending" we went for sucked. 

The gameplay was very un-intuitive, we were struggling just to figure out how to light a fire, and any time it went out it was frustrating to figure out how to re-light it. There were many points when there was no way to know where you were supposed to go next without using a guide, there was no idea what you're supposed to do next to progress the story. At one point you're just supposed to wander around a big jungle away from the safety of your hut while you're constantly struggling to survive until you get lucky enough to stumble upon some tire tracks that are extremely difficult to see and follow. We could barely find the tracks even with the coordinates from a guide, and then we still had trouble staying on the track because it was so hard to see. My vision is not bad and I really struggled so if you have problems with your vision please don't bother with this game. At night it was far too dark and we constantly felt like we couldn't see what we were doing. Even using torches/fires, it just was to hard to see.

One evening I spent a couple hours running around looking for a poison frog so I could progress the story but they were nowhere to be found and we eventually gave up and logged out for the night. (BTW I only knew to look for a frog at all because of the guide we were using.) When we tried again the next day the frogs were in the exact same spot we had both searched many times over. 

I thought it would be fun to get some capybaras and build a hut and farm, but we never even got around to building more than a basic shelter because we were spending all our time just trying to treat wounds and sickness and trying to figure out how to do basic things in the game. You really spend most of your time treating wounds and sickness, making bandages and looking for something to treat illness. You're picking leeches off yourself literally every few minutes, even in the safety of your hut - why??? 

Even using mods and playing with a friend we found the game to be difficult and just NOT fun. I dont mind when a game is difficult as long as it's also fun, but Green Hell was not fun at all. Halfway through my friend and I were both fed up so we decided to just barrel through to the end because we paid good money for it and we're stubborn like that. We both regret buying it. I honestly can't believe there are so many good reviews, there must be a lot of masochists out there.

Fun, immersive game. I liked the story as well. Native AI is not very good, but I would say that is not the main point of the game. There is plenty in the game to learn and understand. 

Some of the bugs around building are a bit frustrating (mud walls extending downward and overlapping for no reason, being unable to build without an obvious reason why), especially if you are trying to make a nice looking base and you are suddenly unable to place a frame halfway through the build.

It would be nice to be able to "shift" some elements around that have already been built, like maybe the farm plots and the mud mixer. Maybe the storage box too, if it is empty. 

Overall I think this is a really good survival game.

Looking forward to updates!

and i've been wishing a game would go as hard as having several different and fairly accurate friction fire methods/items...but this game just, HARD.  

it's a gorgeous game, and it's an addicting bit of gameplay for those of us that refuse to give up; though, if you can't stomach dying repeatedly and after forgetting to build a save location, or wished it had a good building system, you'll want to steer clear.

I don't understand how anyone could find this punishing and unforgiving game to be fun. After being denied a refund, I gave the game an extra 90+ hours, trying to find something redeemable in it. There are so many positive reviews, I thought I had to be missing something. Why won't my brain produce the happy chemicals? Am I missing something?

Your difficulty options are:
* Boring, uninspired story mode
* Everything wants to kill you
* Everything wants to kill you, and death must come immediately
Also, all of your tools break easily, your scarce food goes bad fast, and you have the metabolism of a hummingbird on cocaine.

Technology advancements make things slightly easier, but the more advanced tools require a level of infrastructure that takes a ridiculous amount of time to build. Then, you have to start over, building a new camp from scratch to advance the story. As if that weren't bad enough, the game doesn't give you sufficient space to build a nice camp anywhere that you'll also be in close proximity to all required resources.

Speaking of the story, why do I care? The two main characters lack personality and chemistry. They're supposed to be married?! Their tragic backstory attempts to evoke sympathy while providing a justification for the situation in which they find themselves, but it's too shallow and generic to be engaging.

Maybe I just dislike survival games as a category. I need my games to be an escape from reality, so "work hard to get nowhere, and face the constant looming threat of your own horrific demise" seems more like a description of being a Millennial or Gen Z'er in the USA than a fun game.

I still want my refund.

Not a bad game, but definitely needs more tweaking.
Not only it glitches and crashes randomly, but also in-game mechanics are not exactly the best.

For example I don't understand why game has an urge to rearrange things in the backpack every time I load a save.

Another annoying thing is placing or collecting things: sometimes you have to run around for minutes looking for the right angle to place or pick an item. Not once I dropped a bigger fish back into a trap because there was no space in the backpack and could not retrieve it back later, or dropped an empty mold back into the mixer and had to leave it because it was just not possible to pick it up. Or running around a tree with blue mushrooms trying to find a certain angle from which the game will finally allow me to pick the mushroom...

Spawning and despawning seems to be quite random: sometimes a knife I dropped and forgot for a bit despawns after some short time, but garbage I left behind stays there forever.

And it is not just game mechanics. Also both endings left me quite disappointed. I had to find and read the whole story, because I had more questions than answers about the whole story after finishing both parts.

It's still nice to play if you are into survival games, just don't expect much from it and save as often as possible.

THIS IS SO GOOD I JUST CAN’T. Seriously, I got a friend who's also a big survival game freak like me, and for so long have we searched far and wide in the abyss of the Internets for a game that really suited our expectations, which can be summed up as simply as; immersiveness, and beautiful scenery. That’s literally it. And Green Hell serves it all. 

So in a random order I just made up because why not; 

Skill development. I want it to be there, but I’m not the type to ask for a really complex tree where you have to strategize with your attribute points and all that fuss. Green Hell has a beautifully simple and effective way and I absolutely love it. You just get better at what you do. That’s it. It goes slow, but that’s good for me. It’s useful, realistic, and easy, and the development speed is at a good pace for my taste, which is on the slowish side.

Hunting. First of all, that music that starts playing when you throw a spear and land it on an animal but it doesn’t kill it and it starts running away and you run after it and it’s just going right and left in the busy undergrowth OH THE THRILL OF IT. Sometimes I can’t find them and I lose a spear as well as precious meat but hey that’s all a part of the hunt. Thanks to the skill system you can’t just pull up a bow and some arrows and start bringing mass extinction on your second day in the jungle. Good balance, fun pursuit, and rich rewards when successful. Another hardship which I found myself masochistically enjoy is that the fish in a lake won’t be just circling around in a predestined path, they actually move around, and sometimes they have a spot where they gather up but the next day you go there and you find them way on the other side just swimming around doing fishy business. Neat. 

I’ll give a good immersiveness badge on environmental variety because the jungle does look beautiful, but I feel like there could be more. This is not a complaint, I’m fine with it as it is. Maybe a couple of more tree species and definitely some more animal species can be added. For example so far we only came across one species of snake. Should definitely be more snakes. Never enough snakes. 

Weather. This is gonna be a gold star for trying. But I do remind myself and anyone reading this is that this is still an early access game. Just that right now the rain comes and goes as if with a switch but hey, early access, not our first rodeo. Mostly though it’s that the rain drops are almost invisible so it’s sometimes hard to tell if it’s raining or not. 

Food and other needs. This one makes me really happy so throwing another good immersiveness badge here I mean looks like there’s more where they come from sheesh am I loving this game or what. Well I find all the survival mechanics in this game feel so natural and smooth. Green Hell has a simple and efficient and real enough system with fat, protein, carbs, and water needs. Sleep is also really well done I think, in fact it works so good that after one point my friends and I (who are playing on coop sandbox survival mode on Welcome to the Jungle difficulty) realized our eating/sleeping cycles have become like real life. You need that wholesome breakfast in the morning if you want it to be a good day. And a good afternoon nap is always useful. I mean, how much more real can that get? I do wish though there was more realism to the needs like poopin. Yes pooping yes I said I want to poop in my video game yoU KNOW WHAT YES I’M THAT GUY. When you think about it pooping is actually a big part of our everyday survival (Tried not pooping for a few days? That sh*t can kill you.) Plus you can use it for fun activities like throwing it on your friend’s face. No? Never done a poop fight? Live a little. Also on this topic I want to say the treatment of wounds and infections is just beautiful but I’ll let you discover all that for yourselves. The game doesn’t give you a helping hand in everything either. You have to learn what the healing herbs and useful ingredients are and look like, they won’t be shining up for you or even have their names written of top of them. Once you discover something it’ll be added to your notebook but the fact is, you’re not running around looking at pictures of herbs in your notebook, you have to remember them. Otherwise you just pass by so many blessings of the jungle. 

Crafting. One random thing I like: when you “craft” something, your character goes on to pretend like he’s doing something with his hands and ayy so cute I love that. It’s a very basic animation where it looks like he’s just learning to dance to disco music and is very confused about it but still kudos for trying. The craft system is a lot like the one in The Forest, with a little difference here and there but certainly all a success for me and my likeminded friends. I like that you start the game with some craft recipes in your notebook but then you add more to it as you discover stuff yourself. I like to discover. Thank you for letting us discover, Green Hell devs. Base building, so far so awesome. It looks a lot like how that one guy on youtube with the primitive technology videos does it. And I am a fan, if you couldn’t already guess that. 

Group work. This is a good one because the difficulty of the game is at such a balance that, yes you can survive on your own, but having friends just makes things so much better, unlike some other survival games where my friends and I would find ourselves not interacting with each other like not asking for help or team working, because hunting and building and gathering was so easy that everyone would end up doing their own stuff at some point. Here I find that it’s only when we deploy task distribution that we go off and do things on our own, but it’s still part of the team work. It’s incredibly fun to play with friends, I’ll say that. 

Exploration is really rewarding. My friends and I have played for 11 hours so far and the desire to go explore is strong, and every time we go out it’s always a fun time. Not just the items you find, but the whole oh sh*t we got lost, where’s the river, SNAKE!, aw nice view, omg look at that, let’s go this way, take a screenshot of me here, hunt, run, bandage, ANTHILL!, run, ooo nice spear, new craft recipe wooo!, and all that, is all really fun. I don’t know for how long it’ll keep going but it looks like it’ll make it far enough that I won’t feel like I wasted my money. 

Last point before conclusion; there needs to be a female character. YEAH YEAH PUT A CORK IN IT. All you feminism haters don’t even know what you’re hating on. Look, it’s 2020, don’t even wanna talk about it all over again, and I know that in single player the story goes around a man (much surprise) and maybe that’s not easily changeable, but at least for the coop there can be a female character that we can choose. Or even not choose, just like one does not choose to be born, or rather become, a woman, or a man, it’s okay not being able to choose your gender in game if that makes things easier for the devs to assign randomly. Again, I don’t know how difficult that is in terms of programming and design but, come on, worth it. 

So finally to conclude, yes it's always a labour to keep yourself healthy and leech-free, keep an eye out for the predators and crawling menaces of the jungle (respect though like that's their home turf) and just be on alert most of the time, but all this comes with really nice and immersive tools that are very helpful once you learn how to do things efficiently, and it’s just So. Much. Fun. I really recommend going into this game not having read any guides about it and just discover it all by yourselves. And stay hydrated. And wash your hands. No joke.

2022 edit: Base building sort of disappointing. Need more. MORE. More construction blocks (the mud walls look awful when dried), more decor/furniture. Definitely a must. Please devs. Please make this the next big update.

Tried this a while ago and did not get far. Started up again recently and realized why I never committed to this one.

They have inflated the difficulty of the game by simply not explaining the mechanics or having a good enough tutorial. Took me 2 hours of game play to figure out how to make small stone from big stones, since that was all I could find anywhere. That is not challenging, it's just bad design to not explain the basic mechanics of how to gather certain items. 

Have not been able to make it past day 1 or the starting area yet, because while trying to collect the few stones needed to make an axe, I am constantly bombarded with status effects. Status effects which I do not know how to cure yet since I was literally 5 minutes in after the tutorial. They're everywhere, I walk 5 ft in any direction and instant status effect. If not a status effect, then I run out of water too soon and I still haven't even been able to make a damn fire, let alone figure out how to get water so early.

There is a small tutorial that simply does not explain the basics of survival in this game well enough. It's bad design and needs improvement. I don't feel like I'm being allowed to play yet, simply because I don't know the controls/mechanics for any of the basics.

Will update this after I've taken a break from being so annoyed and given this another shot, but so far highly unimpressed with this. I heard great things, but it's a massive disappointment so far as it has provided zero challenging game play. Just artificially inflating difficulty by keeping you in the dark of how to play.

Update: 4 more hours in and still the same things, have not been able to construct anything. Had to turn on console commands to deal with the status effects since I've been infected by random things over 80 times now. For real, 80+ times in less than 7 hours of game play just trying to learn the mechanics and craft the most BASIC items. Seriously, this is the worst design ever. This game is not challenging, it's a waste of time.

After the tutorial, you are dropped in with nothing and while just trying to learn you are constantly bombarded with status effects every 2-3 minutes while walking through the terrain collecting basic items to make your basic tools. Took me until the 4-5 hour mark before I found a coconut to make a flask. Can't use that to boil water though. It doesn't work, so I'm guessing you need another item but the game does not tell you what is needed to do so. So I'm stuck dehydrating all the time because if you drink water that isn't boiled you get more status effects.

This game is not challenging or hard at all like so many supporters claim it is. It just doesn't tell you how to play. If the difficulty of your game is only in keeping players ignorant of mechanics, it's horribly designed. If I have to use youtube/google to learn to play your game, it's horribly designed and that quite literally takes all the fun away.

Not sure if I will continue at this point. Maybe I'll try again in a month or so when I'm ready to waste more of my time.
