I must admit that I have not played the two most recent big updates (Free DLC) and this review is based on playing from early access thru official release. 

To me, this is the gold standard of how the early access business model should work. From the get go, I thought this game had some pretty nice polish to it, even in very early access. Frequent updates and hotfixes kept it very stable and showed a nice flow to the the dev team's progression. I enjoyed the base mechanics throughout the process and also building in this world in both story and sandbox modes. Some pretty solid NPC AI with the local tribes as well. As elements were added, the game got better and better. 

Then it was "finished". The game was released with a full and compelling story mode. At $24.99 US, I had already gotten well more than my moneys worth and loved the game and its process.

But the dev team were not "finished" afterall. They continue to build upon this project. They clearly care for and love this game and the fans of the game. Top Notch game IMO.

If you're looking for a survival game that isn't going to hold your hand, and will likely destroy you for the first couple hours until you understand a bit better, this is for you. Also the primitive style building is quite enjoyable, and the story is surprisingly deep. If you're a survival lover, this game should absolutely be in your library.

How many ways can you die in a day. Get poisoned, get leeches, get worms, starve, get attacked by a puma, drink bad water, eat rotten food, sleep, go adventuring and get bit by a spider. Cant say how many times a group of us were just laughing at all the possibilities.  Exploring is an adventure as well as getting lost in the wilderness, oh did I mention dying. Lost track but its so much fun.

How this game has such positive reviews is actual schizophrenia to me. I spent the 1.2 hours I have trying to find rocks and dying to anything, and made absolutely no progress because all your important stuff despawns when you die. 

Yeah, eventually I'd become decent enough to something, but who cares? I can play a ton of other games and accomplish the same thing in a much shorter time. 

I just don't get what makes this game stand apart from something like The Forest which felt much more intuitive on top of better progression.

If you wanna fight through hell and back to build a small campfire, by all means play this, I'll be doing literally anything else.

Edit: Ok to be fair, I was a bit harsh. If anything this game is pretty realistic in a specific aspect. The pain I felt sitting in a chair playing this absolute time vampire is probably close to what it would really feel like to have worms burrow into your arm, and that alone is something truly special.

Needs more polishing.

Every single time you quit the game, your video settings will be reset. Namely, V-sync and fullscreen options, and since this game is quite poorly optimized. On a positive side, forgetting to go to those settings every time you start up the game, your PC will go into VROOOM mode and you can use your PC as a stove, or even a microwave, all thanks to this fantastic game!

It does not quite end there. This game lacks a LOT of video settings that are pretty much present in almost every other game, but not here. For example: there is no toggle for motion blur in-game. It is ON by default and you cant normally disable it (someone posted a way to disable it by rclicking the Green Hell in Steam library, going to general settings and adding the line "-noblur" in the launch options. Props goes to whoever wrote that).

Another weird feature of this game is, that it does not despawn majority of the items in the game. Every time you throw away some garbage on ground you no longer need, it will remain there until end of times, adding additional load onto the system. Every single stick, every single bone, every single coconut bowl you throw out of your inventory will be there, somewhere, you wont know it, but your PC will. An immersive feature, but not exactly performance-friendly, and there isnt an option to disable this either.

Crafting system is just awful. You discover crafting recipes by randomly combining items together. Something similar that Minecraft had ages ago. Simply put, if you wont look up online how to craft certain things, you will never know how to craft them, since game wont tell you. Me and my friend played for quite a long while without armor, because, we simply didnt know how to build it, which led to us constantly dying to wounds caused by hostile animals. There is very small chance someone will figure out how to craft the armor, as one of the items needed to craft it, can NOT fit in your inventory. As a matter of fact, there is a lot of good stuff you can craft out of items that you cant put in your inventory. You can carry them, but not actually have them with you. You have to drop them on the ground, grab and drop them in crafting menu and there you put the remaining items.
I will give you a quick small useful spoiler, the item you need to craft the armor with is a "banana leaf". I had to discover this information by looking it up online. Because, simply, game will never tell you that there even is armor you can make to begin with, other than from the one steam screenshot that has it.

To be clear, I DONT think this is a bad game. As a matter of fact, I think its really good, worth the price, however, with these issues present i simply can NOT recommend it in its current state.

There are too many things wrong with this game. Any one of them would be acceptable, but together they make the game too annoying to play.


Difficulty is expected in any survival game, but it's used to add undeserved length and depth to a game seriously lacking them. The difficulty is inconsistent, unrealistic, and in places just seems mean spirited. Often times the game forces you to take "the long way around", just as a time sink. Crafting is ridiculous, to the point of having to manually click and drag things individually onto what I assume is a trans-dimensional crafting-rock, given how seriously the game wants itself taken. If the only time you are realistic is when it inconveniences the player, then you are not trying to make the game honestly difficult. You're my manager at Michael's who refused to let us use the quantity key. 

Now let's talk about options, or the lack thereof. This game expects you to play a certain "way". From the inescapable options to the terrain and building snaps, it has a plan for you and doesn't really want you to step too far outside the box. There is a heartbeat..... I hate it, it's like the beep-beep in Legend of Zelda, and my dude constantly comments on how hungry and thirsty he is. I finally turned the sounds off because insta-death from things sneaking up on me was preferable to the annoyance. There is no option to disable any of this enforced tense atmosphere either. Let me turn off all the commentary and B.S. without also turning off the dangerous wild-animal sounds you assholes. I honestly can't think of a better definition of failure of purpose than what you did there. Put a slider in options, type Voice under it in a label, and then attach it to the right listener. 

Then there is the building system. I've only gotten to brush up against it so far, but from what I've seen it's more of the same. Each bit of wall has snap points and it's impossible to build a structure without them. The snap points aren't universal either, some half wall won't snap to my shed no matter how hard I try. I must assume this is an illegal use of long-sticks. In other words the game has decided the proper way to use the things you build (selective "realistic" difficulty again). Terrain however is irregular and indestructible. and from what I've seen the pre-generated structures are immutable as well. You can do ONE of these two things, but cannot do them both together and expect it to work. 

There is also the player's condition. There is a system of different nutrients you need to have to be balanced; fats is one, carbs another, it's all an interesting idea. There are also sleep and sanity, also interesting in an Eternal Darkness kind of way. Lose enough sanity and a hallucination shows up and kills you (?) I guess. It's not a cool hallucination either, just ordinary and boring. Not exactly realistic, but what have we come to expect. The game is only realistic to make itself harder, and unrealistic for the same reason. Which brings us to sustenance. Between sleep, nutrients, and a bevy of other difficulties my dude passes out more often than an Edwardian Broad in a tight laced corset. When you pass out you lose  things, like an ax. Losing things when you pass out next to your own fire is infuriating, and once again not very grounded in realism. This is another of the situations where you can have one or two of these things, but all together they are awful. 

This feels like a game with no identity outside of an artificially difficult, detail oriented clone of any other survival game; it's Minecraft someone slapped some graphics on. I know you devs wanna make a game, and you have a whole sack full of interesting ideas that will work if you put them together just-so, but if you take all those ideas and put them in one hand, and then poo in the other, imma tell you which one gets full faster. 

Lastly, all of these criticisms wing in a tightening gyre around one central cirticism: self determination. A survival game is not an excuse to make people play the game "the right way". It's a chance to for players to show off all the innovative ways they manage to survive, or more likely die.   

You devs start doing things like letting me turn my very atmospheric heartbeat off and I'll stop regarding you with such suspicion.

Yours 
S

It's one of those games where the gameplay is reliant on reading up on stuff on the internet due to the game design / balancing lacking in certain areas. Purists who've played it from the beginning will tell you that "It's realistic". Yeah, sitting in the comfort of your home punching buttons on a keyboard while colors flicker on a flat surface in front of you is very close to actually being in the Amazon rain forest... Phooey. Games should be fun first and foremost.

"Realism" in games should always take a backseat as designs "inspired" by it often leads to grinding and long-winded game mechanics that serve no purpose other than to frustrate the player. I'm not saying a game shouldn't let itself be inspired by how things are done in the real world. But it is very easy to take it too far. Green Hell does take it too far in some places in my opinion sometimes making the game feel like a chore to play.

Now, with that out of the way, the game is good! And when it doesn't grief you, it's actually really good. There's lots of exploration and adventure to be had in the world of Green Hell. And the story seems intriguing enough that I look forward to unraveling the plot as I go along.

I recommend playing it on custom difficulty and setting needs to low and combat to easy. Enable all encounters and disable leeches (a great example of a "realistic" mechanic that is ONLY annoying). With these settings you will be able to enjoy exploration, but still have to look out for snakes, big cats and so on. But you won't incessantly be forced to focus on your "needs". But it's there and needs attention once in a while, which can then be interesting enough.

It will also allow you to focus on base-building. It will also allow you swim in the water without having to remove leeches every 20 seconds (because that's just so much fun!).

Enough ranting. I recommend the game. The progression is pretty seamless, which is a good thing. And it allows you to pretty much play the way you want, as long as you don't play on the higher difficulties.

Jungle survival game, with an emphasis on survival!

When you first get going just staying alive is tough, any mistake or lapse in concentration can kill you, drinking dirty water gets you parasites, forgetting to wash your hands before you eat? Have some parasites. You didn't look where you were going & stepped on a rattlesnake? Now you're poisoned and have a fever. When you pass out from the fever you wake up and a worm has burrowed under your skin. You best dig that out before it gets infected...

Once you get used to day to day survival  the jungle itself becomes less daunting and the tribesman become the real threat, but again with some practice you'll be taking down groups of them without trouble.

The wound system & food system have some good depth. 

With wounds you need to find the right healing items for the type of wound. Antivenom/Antihistamines/anti infection all have their place.

With food you have to stay on top of your proteins, carbs, fats & hydration. So you need a varied diet to stay healthy.

It's a really great survival game and the story mode was a really nice surprise, it's good & hits the right notes to get you invested.

Brutal PvE jungle survival sim. I've only eaten around 11 hours of this up to now, but here's the story so far:

Life 1: Explored a lot, became poisoned by touching a frog, became sick by drinking dirty water, failed to craft anything, collected about six different types of mushroom, was stabbed to death at dusk by a painted native warrior guy who emerged from the bushes.

Lives 2-5: Figured out basic crafting, including an axe, a shelter, a campfire, and a throwing spear. Managed to live from 1-3 days each time, even killed some animals and cooked their meat. Came to understand that there are MANY ways to die, and MANY specific ways to survive the perils (eg. get bitten by a venomous snake, you'll need to find a particular type of plant or mushroom that works as an antidote. Figuring out WHICH is often a matter of trial and error, therefore you will die many times in early game (starvation, madness, lack of sleep, dehydration, sickness, poisoning, injuries) as you learn what resources you need in order to deal with a variety of threats.

Life 6: Cracked it! Lived several days, crafted armour, a meaningful base, had animal traps in place, had water collection options, fought off some natives in the night, developed improved weapons, resource managament and stable vital signs all completely sorted! Got bit by a spider and died because I didn't know which flower to eat.

This is a beautiful PvE experience, and it feels like there is a lot to go at in terms of crafting and developing more advanced ways to survive. Compared to other survival sims, the difficulty finding resources and the learning curve is probably about halfway between DayZ and 7 Days To Die/The Forest.

As a lover of survival games and realism, this game tries to combine both and nearly succeeds. However I feel a lot of the game is difficult just for the sake of being difficult. I've spent countless hours on sandbox survival games as well as story driven. This is by far one of the most realistic versions I have played. However, the inventory is clunky, tasks are monotonous and the game is by far the most unforgiving. If you're looking for a realistic survival simulator, then by all means buy this game. However I have a hard time recommending this for someone like me, who's looking for a seemingly realistic survival game with just enough difficulty to still be fun and challenging.

Edit: **Purchased Again**

After updates and additions to the game, I can safely recommend this game to any survival game enthusiast, plenty to do, steep learning curve but satisfying. Get the basics down, beat the story, then try the SoA mode.

It starts out quite intimidating, but the more you play (and, yes, die), the more in-control you'll feel. The story is involved and yet simple, and I never felt lost as to where I should go next. At 100 hours or so I had completed all the achievements, but barely scratched the surface of the DLC, which is at least as much content as the main game. And then there's 'survival' mode, which is basically just free-crafting without some of the story locations being accessible; though, honestly, you can treat story mode as 'survival' if you want to, since there's never a time limit or rush to complete the next objective.
I actually found it just as fun to play with friends as solo, but there's definitely a difficulty scale when you've got other people helping you out to gather/build/fight - everything does happen faster and easier, so crafting is a lot less painstaking if you've got someone devoted to deforesting and someone else churning out mud bricks.

very fun survival game, enjoyed being able to play the questline or just forever survival mode with friends. The game is very easy to understand with a basic tutorial, but near impossible to master. even with 100+ hours playing on the hardest difficulty setting, i still find myself in situations where the most likely outcome is my character dying...but, overall its a great game with many right ways to do whatever youd like to do, not many restrictions preventing you from at least trying things, and theres a very good wiki from community members one can look to for anything they missed or dont understand.

I finished the storyline on Tourist difficulty, so there was nothing hostile except the poison arrow frogs.

Honestly, the story is great, and the game is visually impressive. That's about it. That is why I can't recommend it.

The "tutorial" is just the prologue and doesn't actually teach you any of the critical game mechanics. It doesn't teach you how to harvest large rocks to get stones, or that you can throw said stones at coconuts at the tops of trees to knock them down. It doesn't teach you about any of the actual building mechanics. It doesn't teach you how to make weapons, or that you can open the crafting window and drag items on the ground onto your crafting rock.

Building is almost completely pointless. Following the story takes you all over a large map and there's no reason to ever return to a previous location, so you spend time building a base, then never see it again. The only thing you actually need to build is a bed on the rare occasion when you are too far away from ones in important locations. Nothing else is actually useful. Most of the buildings that would actually be mildly useful are only found as you progress the story. You can't make a second story to your buildings unless you happen to harvest mud from a water source. You can't even build a floor to prevent worm infestations.

Resources are also generally pointless. Fill up the loops on your bag with ropes and sticks and that's all you'll need to finish the story. Foraging for food is only needed until you get to the drug factory. After that you can find all the processed and packaged food you need at the important locations. Keep a pair of stone axes, a spear and a stone knife on you and you have all the tools you'll need. Replace a stone axe with the machete at the drug factory.

I have no idea why the devs touted this game as some amazing survival game with a groundbreaking building/crafting system, then made those things almost completely irrelevant. The first small village you come to should be a central location on the map, with the rest of the important locations spread out around it. That way at least you'd be able to build a base that was relevant for more than 15 minutes. Head out to an important spot, do what you need to do, then head back to your camp for rest and resupply.

Dense jungle, death and disease around every corner, what's there not to like? While it can be difficult at first, this game does a good job of making you pay attention to your surroundings (including sounds and weather) and to thoughtfully prepare for every trek through the jungle. Food/macronutrients, energy, and your condition have to be constantly managed; lack of nutrients, disease, wounds, and infection can put you in a death spiral. After I learned the basic rules, I didn't see anything I'd consider a "cheap shot," like hazards suddenly appearing nearby, resources that suddenly disappear when you're looking for them, and so on. I'm glad that the dev team is still actively working on what already looks like a well-balanced and polished game. Definitely recommended for survival game enthusiasts.

The game is great, very 'The Forest' esque. The map is fairly large with plenty of unique locations, and lots of crafting recipes that you can discover, the first time you randomly mash 2 things together and it shits out an item is very exciting. I think the amount of grind is perfect, progress still feels rewarding without being a chore. Building follows the same concept as The Forest, but is currently limited in "foundation" shape, I think a triangle frame would we fun to work with, maybe even free standing perimeter walls or fences?The game sometimes has extreme amounts of trouble in recognizing that you're looking at something when you're trying to build, if you're trying to make 2 storage containers inside of a shed, good luck. There's also currently no way to move a large quantity of items that don't fit in your backpack (long sticks, logs, mud, ect.) something that you could load up with 10 or 15 sticks at a time and subsequently move would be fantastic. Tool racks would be great, from what I know if you have any more than 4 tools you've just gotta leave one on the ground. All said and done the game is still very fun to play either by yourself or with friends, after a bit of a steep learning curve there's tons to do.

good and scary survival game

Green Hell is a game that is very good at encapsulating the essence of wilderness survival. Every mechanic is crafted to immerse you into a challenging and terrifying realistic situation that most people would never survive. It respects your time, doesn’t treat you like an idiot, and expects you to learn from your mistakes. It wants you to stroke that colourful frog, snarf down a handful of grubs, rub that pretty flower into your wound. You’ll probably die, sure, but then Green Hell wants you to die, too. Because in the forbidding depths of the jungle, that’s just how you learn.

This is an amazing experience. Game play is intuitive and yet complex and for some strange reason works as both anxiety inducer and anxiety reliever. 
For example, building your own cabins and quarters, that part is anxiety reducing, but then, you hear the damn cat coming after you, and while you are running to safety and snake gets to you, and now you kill the cat but you have lacerations, poisoned and you don't have enough bandages, so you triage yourself, get some food, and try to find more plants for medicine while you have fever, poison and infection... and suddenly energy levels dropped, so you can't move too much... 
Yeah... Great game!

I thoroughly enjoyed playing through the story mode solo.  It was more challenging than a lot of other survival games I have played but once you get the hang of things it became easier.  Being able to play with your volume fairly high was important and really let you be aware of your surroundings (what animals were out there).  I also really enjoyed the story itself.  I may have even got emotional a few times (which is rude to put in a survival game).  It was one of the best stories of a survival game that I have played.  Running around and just trying to survive the longest is also enjoyable.  I like making multiple camps and collecting all the things and now we can even have babies!  For me it's definitely not a one and done game.  If I feel like crying I may even do the story again later.

Graphics are excellent
Sounds/music is excellent.  The exception is for the positional part of it... It's hard to tell where a sound came from when hunting animals.
The story is dramatic and fun to follow.
The bad parts of the game:
Alot of the tech tree is completely useless and mostly a waste of time.
In a four player game, we felt like establishing a base and gathering / constructing was more risky than just moving along the story so we only made minimalist settlements 3-4 times during the game.
The fun also stops at the grind.  For example, if you want to make iron tool (mid/late game), you need soooo much wood to create charcoal, and the first ones you build will probably break faster than your rock ones because you got good/better at making those.  Lastly the in-game tutorial is lacking, you constantly need to check the wiki to find what's keeping your from building/doing something.  In multiplayer it even happened once where we learned a technology while no one knew how we managed to do it...
*BUG* We managed to get stuck at an infinite loading screen after trying to leave a military tent.  We fixed it by asking the 4th player who was doing something far from us to join us in the tent and to try leaving too. It fixed the problem but it was a waste of 10 minutes.
The part I was the most mad about was when I was alone in our makeshift camp and got attacked by 4 tribal warriors and they started destroying our chests, furnace, mud mixer and planter box.... It felt like an unnecessary part of the game loop.

I haven't finished the storyline yet, but I gotta say, this is now one of my favorite survival-esque games I've tried.  One major difference from the others I've played is that there is an ACTUAL story.  Many survival games are great, but the goal is really just survival.  While that's an option in this game, it does have quite an engaging story line.  

The survival mechanics all mostly make sense too, there's a weight limit AND a space limit in your bags, the fights aren't easy, and you could very easily die, but you can also easily strategize against it.  The building (while it can have it's annoying parts) is also very well done in my opinion, and you see it being built part by part.  There's lots I would add if I could, but it's still very much a game that can suck you in.

So uh.,  Over all this is a great game.  Despite the game breaking bugs (such as the guest on a MP game not being able to see the wandering tribesmen as they tear our base apart.)  

It truly is a survival game that takes into account many different aspects of survival.  Just hoping the devs fix some of these bugs and soon.

Green Hell is a relative rarity on the Survival genre, for despite not being a flawless game, it does not feel incomplete as so many other Survivals.

The base campaign feels lonesome at times, but you're in the jungle, it works out. The story is a simple one, nut with enough love and care poured into it.

Now, the Spirit of the Amazon (SoA) campaign. The additional maps have been designed better than the base campaign, Not only are they more interesting in general, but the layout is more on point, and nothing feels to be on your way too much. It can feel huge when you don't have a grip of where you stand, but once you know the map a little bit, going from one corner of the map to the opposite is not that bad.

I only played the game in the normal difficulty. Combat was not very exiting, the AI of the Waraha was quite lack-luster, specially if you come from something like The Forest (which I feel is less polished than Green Hell, but damn it, The Forest retains you with AI alone).

If you like survivals, you are going to enjoy this one. If you have VR, consider checking the VR version of it (bought separately).

While there is plenty to complain about (clunky inventory system, bizarre physics, nonsense spawns/despawns, annoyingly bad voice acting, and an incredibly useless tutorial), I have really enjoyed playing this game.  For one thing, the areas that are meant to be beautiful are truly breathtaking.  For another, it takes a very long time to run out of things to do.  There are always more blueprints to discover, more items to craft, more materials to gather, and somehow it never becomes too repetitive or dull.  If they would fix some of the other elements I mentioned, it could become a truly great game.

My friend compares this to The Long Dark.  I haven't played that, so I can't speak to it.

What I can say is, this is one of the deeper, more involved survival games out there; having multiple kinds of 'hunger' to track and balance, multiple status effects that have different impacts and feel important to resolve, and a pretty large map without quest markers or minimap (and indeed, the only in-game map is just that - a map with important locations sketched on, but without a player location indicator).

Only real complaint I have is the UI.  Awkward, clunky, and often requiring two different interfaces open at the same time to do anything, it's the real learning curve here. For example, if you get bitten by a spider, you have to first open the body examination tool, then open the backpack. If you open your backpack first, the body examination will close it. 

The information delivery is usually good (hovering over something you've eaten shows you all the effects you've discovered from it), but the gradual (and sometimes seemingly random) unlock of crafting and building recipes means you have to wander the physical world and just kinda stumble across a lot of the valuable recipes and structure blueprints that make an actual established base worth making.  Even then, because so many buildings have somewhat squirrely collision and building requirements, it can be hard to make anything big or broad.  You quickly learn that getting too settled anywhere, even in survival mode, doesn't actually serve you that well because the world is so big and anything you don't have nearby takes a LONG time to fetch.

There is, especially early game, a distinct awareness that you're squishy and taste good.  The UI and crafting and food needs learning curves make your first few play attempts almost guaranteed failures (I probably died five times before I made it to my second night)...but once you get the hang of it, learn what things give what nutrients, and climb the crafting tree a little bit...it's a really good experience.

The story itself is interesting, and has some really neat twists to it.  The lack of guidance on how to get from one step to another is a little frustrating, however, given how large the world is and how easily you can miss something important just by climbing the wrong side of a hill.  The map is EXTREMELY difficult to interpret if you don't have any map-reading experience or skills, and the game doesn't really tell you that you have a compass on your watch so you can end up running in circles a lot.  Learning how to track landmarks, or what you could use to mark where you've been and where you need to go, also takes time.

But with all that, this is still one of the first games I suggest to people, especially streamers, who are looking for a good survival game.  Not for the faint of heart or the easily discouraged. Save often.

So the game looks great, and is known for being hard and realistic. The combat is fairly well done, however there are NUMEROUS bugs. Way to many to be acceptable.

I DO NOT run mods at all, preferring to play these types of games vanilla as the developer intends. 

The Good:
1. Game-Play and combat are both very fluid, feels great to play on PC.
2. Graphics are very nicely done - Looks Amazing
3. The sound is great. Can easily hear the direction of a large cat sneaking up.
4. Developer is consistently releasing new content.

The Bad:
1. Unintelligent AI -
 The AI isn't that intelligent. Once you figure out how the AI behaves and where things spawn, the game get's a LOT easier. If you walk everywhere you can hear most things from a mile away. A big cat like a Jaguar or Puma will growl quite loudly EVERY TIME, and you can simply turn to the direction where you hear the sound, and line up a head shot. 

2. Diversity -
 Lack of diverse NPCs.  Almost every tribes person looks the same with little variant. Jaguar and Puma are basically the same just different skins, and only a few hunt-able animals. 

3. Everything is Unknown -
Almost all herbs and mushrooms are unknown. I understand it being unknown when you first pick it, but can't your character at least name it something in your inventory? Like instead of Unknown Mushroom, why not put it's actual name, or even something like Orange Mushroom? 

4. NOT Realistic - The things that are not realistic are VERY unrealistic.
Not as realistic as I thought it would be. So yeah you can get infected from wounds, and use different bandages to wrap those wounds, which is nice. However my guy shouldn't eat 4 steaks and then be STARVING like 4-6 hours later. Hungry yes, but not so weak he wants to sleep all the time. Nutrient depletion is way to high in default setting, and just becomes tedious.

This guy also doesn't get stronger or build more endurance. He can spend a year in the jungle and still not be able to carry more than 50 lbs, or chop down more than a few trees. 

5. Animal Husbandry - Seems like a punishment - and there is absolutely no need.
So the premise sounds nice, but the delivery is awful. Now there are bugs, which is understandable with a new content patch. Animals disappearing or escaping their pen is one such bug.

HOWEVER having animals in general seems like a punishment rather than a benefit. You CONSTANTLY have to provide them with food and water, and pick up their droppings or they will eat them and get poisoned and die.

They REALLY missed the mark with this one. The point of these kind of game-play mechanics is usually to benefit the player, not make them constantly micro manage some animals. Why would I want to spend my time constantly gathering food for MY food when I could just walk a few feet and kill 2-3 in the wild? 

Animals in general don't eat feces unless they are young, and if they do they usually don't get sick. I mean there are outliers, but if most animals behaved this way and got sick and died this often because of this, well there would only be a handful of species on the entire planet. 

On top of that, there are way to many animals out in the wild in this game to really warrant trying to raise your own.

6. The building system - very lackluster/simple and problematic
So yeah, I get that they want the building system to be simple, and they use a Modular + Ghost/Blueprint system.  Problem is you can only place one bp ghost at a time when making a building. This makes it very difficult to try and map out a base. You have to place a ghost, finish it, then snap on another ghost and finish that and so on. Well if the area you were building is at a small incline, you might not end up being able to finish the building how you planned. NOT to mention the fact that sometimes the ghost just won't snap to your building pieces for no apparent reason. Also there seems to be multiple snapping points that are not always easy to detect, and can make HUGE problems later down the line when it's too late to do anything about it other than chopping down your base and starting over.

Building is a HUGE part of the survival genre and this system is terrible. What worries me is it seems like they are adding new pieces soon, and haven't fixed the current issues that plague their building system.

7. No Ability to have Dedicated Servers -
Dedicated servers are HUGE for this kind of game, and for some reason the developer is vocal against having them. The multiplayer is Peer to Peer, which means one player hosts the game acting as the server, while their friends join them. Problem is the host has to be online for their friends to play.

A dedicated server acts as the host, so people can come and go as they have time. I'm not saying the developer should shell out the money to host official servers themselves, but allowing players, and companies to host their own dedicated servers seems pretty standard for the survival genre - and I'm baffled the devs seem so against it. I'm not sure if it's because they lack the skills to do so or what.

8. BUGS - There's some game-breaking ones that have been in for YEARS

A. Can't use in-game menus -

One bug I've gotten about 3 times so far is right after combat while my bow is equipped (have only experienced it with bow so far) , I can't open any of the in-game menus. Not inventory, or character inspection. This means that if I got hit during the fight I can't heal my character. I end up having to save + quit (ESC menu still works)

B. Coconut Shell not Working - 
I harvested a coconut, and then harvested the shell instead of eating the inside out first, and when I placed the coconut it would disappear most of the time. Then if it didn't disappear it wouldn't catch water or work at a cooking station. The coconuts I chopped then ate while still on the ground seemed to work just fine. Couldn't replicate with other saves, but happened consistently with this save, so not sure what caused it.


C. NPCs walking through base walls -
Not sure what caused this bug, or how wide-spread it is,but enemies, animals and human alike can walk through your base walls. So you'll get pinned inside your base getting hit by a tribes person or large cat, and will be unable to put a gap in between you because you can't walk through walls.

I've tried verifying my steam files, restarting PC and still happens. From searching Google I can see that this bug has been around since at least 2018 and hasn't been fixed. The answer I got from a guide in their official Discord channel "It must be complicated and has to do with physics". Now there are work a rounds like building a wall of palm leaf stands around your base which I don't believe they can clip through, and I do understand that complicated bugs can take some time - but this is a pretty major bug and it's been roughly 4 years. In that time they could have completely rebuilt the game from scratch.

I understand that the Developer is rather small, and is trying to balance new content with fixing bugs, but frankly when you have a major bug that has been around for 4 years you're doing something wrong.

 It shouldn't even be out of early access in this state. Don't bother.

I love this game--it's definitely my favourite survival game but the glitches are sooo fucking game breaking and ruins the whole experience. i want to be able to experience story mode as its supposed to, but i'll either not be able to use my grappling hook/gun, predators and enemies walk through my mud walls and kill me, randomly spawn in with max insomnia with poison and a fever (without being bitten), glitched infected wounds, and the worst one yet--not even being able to place down a fire under a ritual pot to progress the story. My friend and I were pretty desperate to bypass this, trying out mods to fix story mode items not spawning/working but even the fucking mods are glitchy its tragic. I beg for the devs to fix these bugs that have been around for as long as i first got the game (at least a year now, maybe 2?)

I'm still going to leave a positive review/recommendation because if you love survival games, this is one of the best ones your gonna find (realism wise) and is great fun with friends + a decent story if you're into that (even on survival mode without story is good, but the commentary added in storymode makes the first experience better imo)
This game could be bloody amazing if it werent glitchy, and if the glitches eventually get patched, you should play this game.

It kind of depends. Do you enjoy wandering around for three or four days (in game) searching for the only coconut in the entire Amazon rain forest, while you slowly die of dehydration, despite the fact that it rains every single day and anybody with an ounce of common sense would be able to deal with the situation simply by CUPPING HIS HAND???!!!!

Don't ask me about the story, because I'm only interested in the survival aspect. It wasn't too bad, for the most part. You have to build a shelter to protect your campfire or it goes out in 2 seconds, which drove me crazy, but isn't too far-fetched. Surviving off small animals and grubs works okay (though I assure you, people can eat roasted grubs without going insane). These aspects were better balanced than in some games.

But the water situation is so absolutely stupid, I can't stand it, particularly because I had to listen to him simpering on and on about how thirsty he was, WHILE RAIN WAS POURING DOWN ON HIM. He could have survived by sucking on his own SHIRT.

Yes, you might pick up dangerous microbes from drinking river water in the jungle without boiling it.

No, rain is not going to hurt you. Drink it, you moron.

------------------
EDIT: As I often do, once I get used to the more infuriating aspects of a survival game, I'm changing my review to "recommended." But everything I said still stands. Water management is absurd. Not to mention the fact that you pick up leeches from EVERYTHING that makes you dirty, regardless of how far away from the river you might be. (EDIT2: I looked it up. Yes, you can get leeches ANYWHERE in the rainforest. There are varieties of "land leeches" that will latch onto you wherever there are damp leaves.) You can also get worms under the skin, which makes me want to hurl every time it happens. This can happen simply from sleeping out in the forest without shelter. For some reason. Ugh. 

Having said that, it's still the best survival game I've played. Keep in mind, I'm only recommending the story mode option in the game that doesn't have predators or tribesmen trying to kill you as you build your camp. I'll probably try that later, but I'm not sure I'll enjoy it. Animal predators are always highly over-exaggerated in games. (In real life, they only hunt when HUNGRY and ignore prey the rest of the time. In other words, a T-Rex or whatever is unlikely to come after you, after it kills half your party. It's full. It will save you for later.) Evil tribesmen... well, it's a bit of a stereotype, but I suppose they could be a serious problem, if you encountered them.

Quick Survival Guide:
~ Horde Rocks and sticks (especially long sticks and big rocks)
~ You can eat almost every mushroom from the ground + snails maggots etc
~dont worry about drinking dirty water most mushrooms can heal parastites
~CRAFT BOW EARLY no seriously one Headshot can kill almost every enemy in the game
~Watch out for the sounds, every danger has some sound cue to warn you
~Craft some armor, it can help you survive big cat attacks and locals trying to kill you

This game is truly a challenging survival game. The beginning of the game immediately grabbed my attention as I was able to put in hours without realizing. Just loading into the world and playing without knowing how to do anything made the game a lot of fun.
The inventory and crafting system in this game was a step above anything I've tried. The way the audio blends in with the environment made it that more immersive. One thing I would want to see is a darker night time. 
I am thankful to have found this leech ridden game and to the people who worked on it, since they did such a good job. 

Whoever is interested in this game and they don't know if they should, I highly recommend. If you don't like it, you can always return it within 2 hours.

The survival system in this game is punishing- in that it is surprisingly realistic. You have to maintain your mind and body in the jungle: a place that seems hellbent on killing you. It's a challenge to newcomers and veterans alike in the Survival genre, and through pleasantly customise-able difficulty options you can choose just how punishing you want to go.

As for the story? It was fantastic. I was kept guessing at every turn as I unraveled the mystery, and there were multiple times where I gasped out loud. No spoilers, but be prepared to get shocked and get SAD. It's also astounding how much story you can glean from the world around you in all the little details.

The world feels alive in ways that are both beautiful and terrifying. The survival methods make me think back to my own wilderness survival courses. The environment is a delight to look at and explore, though you'll find yourself cursing it often as you get bitten by ants, or stung by a stingray, or mauled by another bloody jaguar. By the way, treat those scratches: infection is a nasty way to go.

All in all, I can't recommend this game enough purely based on the Story mode. I have yet to try out the other campaign or the sandbox survival. I'm excited to do both, though.
